Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of KalobaNaso nasal spray in the treatment of common cold.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Nasal mucosal inflammation due to common colds are highly prevalent throughout the world and are commonly treated with systemic drugs. The common cold is a mild acute upper respiratory infection caused by a variety of viruses, which result in nasal congestion, runny nose, blocked nose, and sneezing. The symptoms occur from the day of infection with the virus to 7-14 days. Symptoms of the common cold are usually mild; however, they can be very disruptive to the daily lives of patients, particularly adolescents and young adults who may return to the study site or clinic for a nasal or throat culture taken up to 3 times per day. This may occur over a period of several days to a week in order to assess microbial cultures. A large portion of these patients develop an inflammatory response to the virus within the nasal cavity, known as "rhinitis". A study in patients in Japan suggests that up to six times more patients suffered from nasal congestion due to a blocked nasal cavity, than in adults. This inflammation is characterized by the presence of an inflammatory response in the blood, which includes an increase in an immune cell called a T cell, and T cells are activated after infection with the virus. The immune system is activated through the presence of specific proteins called cytokines. These cytokines (eg, interleukin-4 and interferon-gamma) cause an increase in the number of T cells which leads to inflammation of the nasal mucosa. In adults, the cytokines involved in this response are interleukin-17 (IL-17), IL-5, IL-9, and other cytokines, including Interferon-beta (IFN-beta) and Interleukin-2 (IL-2). Inhibition of these various cytokines has been found effective as a treatment for various inflammatory diseases including rheumatoid arth

Study Description
=================
-----------------
A study of the effects of the following intervention on disease-related health outcomes for older lung cancer patients: comprehensive geriatric assessment and care management (with access to the University of Michigan National Cancer Institute Community Clinical Oncology Program-supported geriatric service, if indicated), followed by standard of care.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A geriatric service can help cancer patients receive timely, appropriate care to address the adverse effects of cancer and treatment. However, geriatric assessments and geriatric services for patients with non-small cell lung cancer are lacking from an oncology standpoint. Our objective is to determine the efficacy of implementing a comprehensive geriatric assessment for patients with non-small cell lung cancer at risk for adverse treatment effects, focusing on those over the age of 75 living in Michigan. We plan to enroll up to 120 individuals over age 75 being treated at the University of Michigan Comprehensive Cancer Center for non-small cell lung cancer. This is a phase 2 clinical trial designed to obtain pilot data with the intention of progressing to a larger trial, evaluating the effects of incorporating geriatric assessment and care management services at community oncology practices. In the event that the intervention proves promising, we intend on implementing the intervention in community cancer clinics and expanding the intervention to patients receiving care at community cancer clinics.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In addition to primary data collection and analysis of the association between heart failure and dementia, the study will assess the occurrence of a neuropsychiatric clinical picture among people with heart failure and the potential predictive role of biomarkers. Participation to the study will be limited to medical and/or non-medical files already entered in the national registry of people with heart failure. In order to improve detection of dementia and psychiatric illness, patients will be questioned using scales for patient self-report, informant or professional, the results of these scales being systematically linked to an available diagnosis of heart failure.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The results will allow assessment of the rate of neuropsychiatric illness in a contemporary cohort of people with heart failure. This study will focus on the association with clinical factors (comorbidity and treatment of heart failure), cognitive function, biomarkers possibly associated to increased risk of this type of cardiovascular disease in the general population. It will also help to assess the potential predictive role of biomarkers (blood levels of the biologically active hormone of angiotensin II) and the potential association of these biomarkers and neuropsychiatric illness in people with heart failure. The results of this study will be important for optimizing medical management of patients with heart failure. Study design: All patients included in the national registry of heart failure who have signed the consent will be invited to participate in this multicentric prospective study. Each patient will be asked to indicate another heart failure patient of a similar age category and sex. No new patient with cognitive impairment will be recruited. The intervention is identical for the two groups - one group will not receive any treatment (control group), the other group will receive biomarkers for clinical management (levosimendan).

Echocardiography, Biological Markers, and Neuro Psychiatric Symptoms in Heart Failure

Heart Failure

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Myocardial protection during coronary artery bypass graft surgery is a leading topic in cardiac surgery. Indeed, although recent guidelines state that there is no difference between myocardial protection methods and cardiac preservation technologies, the European consensus proposes that cardioplegia should be the primary mode of myocardial protection during heart surgery. However, recent studies highlight a trend in favor of myocardial protection, mainly using extracorporeal circulation in patients undergoing heart surgery. Nevertheless, although promising, these results only concern a minority of hospitals and patients. AIMS: The purpose of this pilot study was to analyze the safety and feasibility of a pharmacological myocardial protection strategy compared to a cardioplegic strategy in patients undergoing heart surgery in a real‐life context.METHODS: This study is a prospective, randomized, multicenter, open‐label study including patients undergoing isolated or associated left heart surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass and extracorporeal circulation. Following randomization, the patients will receive a cardioplegic or pharmacological strategy. The primary endpoint is the rate of ischemic‐related arrhythmias (including atrial arrhythmias (AA), atrio‐ventricular block (AVB) > 2nd degree at discharge). Secondary endpoints include composite endpoints at 30 days post‐operative (Mace‐3 score, echocardiographic evaluation of systolic and diastolic dysfunction), functional status (NYHA function score, 6‐MWD, LVEF evaluated by radionuclide ventriculography), and adverse events (myocardial infarction, cardiogenic shock, ventilation, and renal replacement therapy duration). Finally, an economic evaluation will be performed on the same inclusion population.CONCLUSIONS: This study is the first to assess the feasibility of a pharmacological myocardial protection strategy compared to a cardioplegic strategy. If this study demonstrates its interest, the subsequent randomized controlled trial (RCT) will allow us to assess the effect of pharmacological myocardial protection on clinical outcomes.TRIAL REGISTRATION: Clinical Trials -

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men worldwide and has the highest incidence of cancer-specific death in men. Hormonotherapy, as a treatment for prostate cancer, may cause metabolic diseases and cardiovascular disease, such as type 2 diabetes mellitus(T2DM) and cardiovascular disease. The aim of the present study was to analyze metabolic and vascular dysfunction and assess whether there is any correlation between the development of metabolic and vascular disease associated with hormonotherapy and patients with prostate cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Data from patients with newly diagnosed prostate cancer in our hospital was retrospectively analyzed. Patients were included if they were over 40 years old, and received androgen deprivation therapy (ADT, GnRH agonists or antagonists) or metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) therapy. Subjects will be screened with a fasting plasma insulin level <60 micro-IU/mL and a Homeostatic index ≤1.86(SI unit: μIU/mL * mmol/mL) and glucose tolerance (Fasting blood glucose level <6.1 mmol/L, 75g OGTT <7.8 mmol/L). Patients were excluded if they have a past medical history of diabetes, known to take medications affecting glucose metabolism, have a fasting plasma insulin level ≥60 micro-IU/mL, and a homeostatic index exceeded 1.86. 2 hours after the glucose load were used for glucose measurement, at least three of the following six clinical and biochemical parameters of the OGTT: plasma glucose ≥7.8 mmol/L, insulin ≥250 picomoles/L, and blood pressure >140/90 mmHg. Brief Summary

-----------------
The aim is to compare the effect of topical EMLA cream and skin incision on pain intensity felt by patients undergoing a surgical procedure on the lower limb. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This clinical trial is a prospective, multicenter, single-blind, parallel-randomized, controlled multi phase 2 study designed to study the efficacy and safety of DSP-7888 in patients with severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Based on the preliminary study results, DSP-7888 for treatment of severe or critical COVID-19 (SAS) is selected as the most promising drug among DSP-7888 and three other anti-SARS-CoV-2 drugs with the help of a machine learning model. In the phase 2 clinical trial, this is a randomized, double-blind controlled study in which DSP-7888 or placebo is administered once a day.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) can cause lower respiratory tract infections such as viral pneumonia and even acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), requiring intensive care unit (ICU) transfer, mechanical ventilation, and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). However, the optimal drug treatment of COVID-19 has not been found. At the present stage of the COVID-19, the development of efficacious antiviral drugs is the most urgent need for patients with COVID‐19. Due to its convenient method and simple operation, intravenous infusion has been extensively applied to the treatment of SAS. Therefore, investigators designed and conducted an exploratory study to screen effective drugs in a limited number of patients with COVID-19, and a multiphase clinical trial was carried out to further verify their efficacy while expanding the sample size. According to the results of preliminary research, DSP-7888 emerged as the most promising candidate. Based on the results, DSP-7888 for treatment of severe or critical COVID-19 (SAS) was selected as the most promising drug among DSP-7888 and three other anti-SARS-CoV-2 drugs with the help of a machine learning model. Reasoning: This arm serves as the control group to compare the impact of the interventions to standard care. By not implementing any changes to the standard after visit procedure, researchers can assess the effectiveness of the interventions in improving patient comprehension.

2. Experimental: Standardized After Visit Instructions Only
- Participant Group/Arm: Standardized After Visit Instructions Only
- Intervention/Treatment: Behavioral: Standardized After Visit Instructions Only
- The intervention took a standardized approach to after visit instructions which included a customizable template that would review patients' conditions, changes in any medications, and any future labs, imaging, or referrals.
Reasoning: This arm allows researchers to evaluate the impact of standardized after visit instructions alone on patient comprehension. By providing patients with a structured and consistent format for post-visit instructions, the researchers can assess whether this approach improves patient understanding of their health information.

3. Active Comparator: Standardized After Visit Instructions & Teach Back
- Participant Group/Arm: Standardized After Visit Instructions & Teach Back
- Intervention/Treatment: Behavioral: Standardized After Visit Instructions & Teach Back
- This intervention included the Standardized After Visit Instructions and included teach back, a process by which patients restate in their own words their understanding of their condition, what was discussed in the visit, and what potential changes were made
Reasoning: This arm allows researchers to evaluate the impact of combining standardized after visit instructions with the teach-back method on patient comprehension. By incorporating a feedback mechanism where patients repeat back the information discussed during the visit, researchers can assess whether this interactive approach further enhances patient understanding compared to standardized instructions alone.

=================
Purpose and Overview: To assess the effect of the Decision Tool to improve knowledge and perceived risk compared to the conventional Spanish information in women receiving maintenance chemotherapy for ovarian cancer in the community setting. 

Design and Approach: This is a cluster randomized controlled trial. Eligible participants will be invited to complete surveys at baseline and 3 months. Outcomes will be knowledge and perceived risk. Participants will also complete an acceptability survey.

Detailed Description
-----------------
An estimated 22,530 women will be diagnosed with ovarian cancer this year, 14,030 of whom will die from the disease (1,957-2016 National Cancer Institute Surveillance and Epidemiology and End Results Program). The overall five-year survival rate (SEER 10) is 47.6%. The most robust treatment approach for ovarian cancer is surgery followed by chemotherapy. Patients are recommended to receive at least six cycles of adjuvant chemotherapy. Evidence suggests that the administration of up to 12 additional maintenance cytotoxic chemotherapy cycles after completing the standard six cycles is associated with improved overall survival compared to observation alone. Nonetheless, in reality, approximately 50% of patients elect to receive maintenance chemotherapy. The decision to elect or not to elect additional chemotherapy is particularly relevant to women with ovarian cancer because chemotherapy can elicit significant toxicities, including myelosuppression, alopecia, and peripheral neuropathy. Moreover, many patients have received multiple medical treatments with significant side effects and may not have the desire to accept more therapy. Because maintenance chemotherapy is not universally available and is often provided only in academic medical centers, patients in community hospitals may not be informed about this treatment option. A Shared Decision Tool (SDT) consisting of a fact sheet in Spanish providing information about the benefits and risks of treatment has been created that allows women under treatment to obtain information, reflect on their preferences, discuss their options with their clinicians, and consider whether to accept or decline this treatment option. Abstract:
Background: Implant‐supported overdentures provide greater masticatory efficiency, less bone resorption, and improved oral health compared to conventional dentures. There are, however, limitations of the current denture design with a standard attachment system. Moreover, overdenture prosthetic construction with computer‐aided design and computer‐aided manufacturing (CAD/ CAM) is known to cause fabrication errors due to the limitations in intra‐oral scanners or CAD systems. Thus, the aim of this study was to introduce a new scanning and CAD/CAM method to fabricate a new overdenture prototype and determine its clinical applicability. Methods: A total of 24 patients with good oral, systemic health, and a bilateral full‐arch edentulous jaw with a minimum height of the residual alveolar ridge of 6 mm were selected. Two sets of complete denture (maxilla and mandible) were fabricated for each patient. After initial denture construction, impressions, surgical stents, and guide pins were fabricated for implant placement. Implants were inserted for both the maxillary and mandibular jaw at an average of 8 weeks after the surgical procedure. After the second stage surgery and occlusal adjustment, two sets of complete denture (maxilla and mandible) were fabricated. Then, the mandibular complete denture was fabricated at two different methods. One complete denture was fabricated with a conventional method, and the other complete denture was fabricated at a digitized method (3Shape Exocad software). Patients were followed at 2, 4, and 6 weeks after the implant placement for evaluation. A digital scanner (Bilbray 3D i500 Scanner; Carestream Dental, Atlanta, GA, USA) was used to scan the two maxillary complete dentures and two mandibular complete dentures over the first one‐year follow‐up. Patients were instructed to perform chewing of hard and soft textured food and evaluated by the Percival Occluzer (Percival Instrument Co., Inc., Mundelein, IL, USA)

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Temporomandibular dysfunction (TMD) is a common problem that occurs mainly in young and middle-aged adults. The mandibular condyle is crucial in TMD patients, and the conventional mandibular overdenture has been the conventional treatment option. Nevertheless, it is a challenge to achieve the ideal position for the mandibular overdenture. Computer-aided design and computer-aided manufacturing (CAD/CAM) technology offer precision in the mandibular overdenture position and is widely used in modern prosthodontics.

Detailed Description
-----------------
There is a lack of clinical evidence regarding the effect of CAD/CAM milling on overdenture bases between CAD/CAM milled and conventional mandibular overdentures. This study aimed to explore the effect of CAD/CAM mandibular overdentures on temporomandibular joint (TMJ) function. It was hypothesized that the CAD/CAM mandibular overdenture is superior in restoring TMJ biomechanics and function. Patients with a maxillary complete conventional complete denture or a complete mandibular conventional complete denture were included. They were randomly divided into experimental and control groups. At first, patients in the experimental group were treated with CAD/CAM mandibular overdentures while patients in the control group received conventional mandibular overdentures. TMJ sounds, joint laxity, mouth opening, headache intensity, pain threshold, occlusal function, and oral quality of life were assessed during and after treatment.

Official Title
-----------------
Comparison Between Computer-Assisted Design and Computer-Aided Manufacturing and Conventional Mandibular Overdenture in Patients With Complete Dentures

Conditions

Missing Teeth

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Device: computer-aided design and computer-aided manufacturing (CAD/CAM) treatment
* Other: conventional mandibular overdenture (control treatment)

[/TITLE] [BREAK] [CONTEXT] Implant dentures provide an effective and long-lasting option for edentulous patients, offering a high level of stability, comfort, and function while preserving oral health. However, the surgical procedure itself can be painful and cause discomfort for patients. [ABSTRACT] [EN] Implant dentures have become a popular choice for edentulous patients due to their numerous advantages such as high stability, comfort, and function while preserving oral health. However, the surgical procedure for implant placement can be painful and cause discomfort for patients. Research has shown that injecting hyaluronic acid into the implant socket before implantation can help reduce post-implantation pain and promote faster healing. In this study, we evaluated the efficacy of hyaluronic acid injection in reducing post-implantation pain in 70 edentulous patients undergoing implant surgery. Patients were randomly assigned to two groups: the experimental group received hyaluronic acid injection into the implant socket, while the control group did not receive any intervention. Pain intensity and duration, patient satisfaction, and complications were assessed at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-surgery, and the data were analyzed using appropriate statistical methods. The results showed that the patients in the experimental group had significantly lower pain intensity and duration compared to the control group, and had higher levels of satisfaction with their treatment. There were no serious complications in either group, and no significant differences in implant success and failure rates were observed. In conclusion, our study demonstrates that hyaluronic acid injection before implantation can effectively reduce post-implantation pain and improve patient outcomes, with no significant adverse effects or complications. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to investigate whether patients with a stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) in the context of a small vessel cerebrovascular disease have a better response to physical therapy with an inexperienced physiotherapist compared to an experienced physiotherapist based on their neurological deficits such as ataxia, and whether this effect is independent of lesions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary aim of this study was to examine the short term effect of 6 weekly sessions of physical therapy with different levels of experience on arm and leg ataxia in patients with a neurological lesion of the brain. Patients with a stroke or TIA in the context of small vessel disease participated in the study. The ataxia was evaluated using four subtests of the Movement Intention Test by a blinded assessor, both at pre-treatment and 6 weeks after first treatment session. The intensity of ataxia in the upper and lower extremities was analyzed regarding a different level of experience. The effect of treatment was compared to another group with small-vessel disease without ataxia and a third non-patient group with small-vessel disease based on their scores of depression and anxiety. The patients with ataxia and non-patients were analyzed based on their lesion distribution. We also analyzed how the intensity of depression and anxiety influenced the treatment response.

Official Title
-----------------
Efficacy of Physiotherapy for Upper and Lower Limb Ataxia in Patients With Small Vessel Lesions- a Randomized Controlled Trial

Conditions

Stroke, Transient Ischemic Attack, Ataxia, Parkinson's Disease

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This Phase 1, open-label, dose escalation study will evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of 3 doses of NTLA-2001 administered via a single intravenous (IV) infusion, followed by monthly or fortnightly dose escalation to determine the maximum tolerated dose, and tolerability, safety, and pharmacokinetics of repeated dosing of this agent in this indication.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an investigator- and subject-blinded, Phase 1 (Part 1) and Part 2b (Part 2) clinical study. This study will enroll patients with documented ATTR Amyloidosis Cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM). The Part 1 dose-escalation study will evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of 3 initial doses of NTLA-2001 administered as a single IV infusion. Following the Part 1 dose-escalation study, the Part 2b study will assess the safety, tolerability, and PK of repeated dosing of NTLA-2001 in patients whose PK profile at the end of the 28-day (Day 29) follow-up period following the first dose (Day 1) of NTLA-2001 indicates that multiple doses are warranted. Patients must be clinically stable with no change in prescribed background therapies during the entire study duration.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This Phase 3 trial is a double-blind, randomized (2:1), placebo-controlled, multicenter, safety and efficacy study to evaluate NTLA-2001 in patients with polyneuropathy (PN) and cardiomyopathy due to the transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR-PN/CM).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 3 clinical study of ATTR-PN/CM participants to assess the efficacy and safety of NTLA-2001 (ISIS-TtrRx) over a five-year period of treatment. Treatment-naive participants with symptomatic ATTR-PN/CM will be randomized (2:1) to receive intravenous infusions of NTLA-2001 at 55 mg, 2:1 randomization 3:1 or placebo. The primary hypothesis of the study is that NTLA-2001 treatment is sufficient to reduce the rate of decline in the composite primary endpoint of change from baseline to Weeks 96 and 144 in the NT-proBNP and 6-minute walking distance (6MWD). 55 mg is the maximum therapeutic dose for ATTR-PN/CM based on pre-clinical data and a dose-ranging clinical trial previously conducted. In these studies, 55 mg was found to significantly reduce TTR protein in the blood compared to placebo. Other doses have been evaluated in an ATTR-CM only study. In ATTR-CM only studies, higher doses of NTLA-2001 were associated with increased rate of hepatic dysfunction. These higher doses have been shown to be better tolerated in ATTR-PN/CM when combined with vitamin A supplementation, resulting in long-term stability of LDL cholesterol. The 55 mg dose has been shown to also be well tolerated and have better liver safety profile in ATTR-PN/CM. This dose is well supported based on the previous studies using biomarkers and biopsy assessments.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this research is to find out if there is an association between depression and glycaemic control in type 1 diabetes. A secondary objective is to determine if depressive symptoms can predict a patient's quality of life, diabetes distress, and treatment satisfaction (satisfaction from using insulin, blood glucose tests, insulin pumps, glucose sensors, pump insulin, and carbohydrate counting). Lastly, investigators want to see if there is an association between HbA1c (glycated hemoglobin) levels and depressive symptoms as well as a relationship between depressive symptoms, diabetes distress, and treatment satisfaction.

Detailed Description
-----------------
BACKGROUND: Treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus requires multiple daily injections of insulin. Patients with diabetes must constantly monitor their insulin and blood glucose levels with the use of various blood glucose meters, and must learn about carbohydrate counting to be able to estimate accurately the number of carbohydrates they should eat. These are a lot of responsibilities to remember every day, which can create stress and depressive symptoms. Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to investigate whether depression was negatively related to glycemic control among pediatric Type 1 diabetics. Method: This study was a retrospective data analysis. The medical records of pediatric Type 1 diabetes patients visiting the Pediatrics Department were retrospectively assessed in the period from 01/2021 to 02/2022. A total of 104 patients were randomly selected for the study. Their levels of depression (based on the PHQ‐9 and DTSQ) and glycemic control (based on HbA1c levels) were assessed using a questionnaire. Results: Significant differences in PHQ‐9 scores, DTSQ scores, and HbA1c levels (p < 0.001) were found between the depressed and nondepressed patients. A statistically significant positive correlation (r = 0.782, p < 0.001) was found between the patients' PHQ‐9 and DTSQ scores, indicating that the higher the patient's PHQ‐9 score, the weaker their treatment satisfaction. A positive correlation between DTSQ scores and HbA1c levels was also found (r = 0.291, p = 0.023), indicating that the better the treatment satisfaction, the better the patients' glycemic control. Conclusion: The findings of this study indicated that depression in pediatric patients with Type 1 diabetes is negatively associated with their glycemic control, suggesting that healthcare providers should consider depression treatment as part of their treatment approach in improving glycemic control.

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to determine if 4 weeks of treatment with MRI-713 is effective in symptomatic adults with mild to moderate Alzheimer's Disease by assessing change in disease severity based on ADAS-cog14 compared to placebo treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will randomize participants to either MRI-713 or matching placebo treatment to continue for 15 months. Following the end of study treatment, participants will be followed for an additional 15-month period of open-label MRI-713 treatment. Throughout the study, standardized AD and normal aging assessments will be administered and cognitive function will be assessed. Safety will be assessed throughout the study by adverse event reporting and routine, periodic laboratory tests. Participants will receive brain MRI scans throughout the study to estimate regional volume loss due to disease and the effect of MRI-713 on MRI metrics.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
Chronic postoperative pain (ChPOP) is an important complication of orthopedic surgery. The use of hot air balloons to deliver local anesthesia is a new, promising development in this field. Hot air balloon (HAB) anesthesia is an advanced technique that allows the delivery of high concentrations of local anesthetics into a small volume of space around the nerve, leading to effective anesthesia and a significant reduction in the risk of ChPOP. However, compared to the traditional saline injection, it is not clear exactly how using a hot air balloon affects pain levels and the amounts of postoperative pain medications used. This study will investigate whether using a hot air balloon for local anesthesia reduces postoperative pain and pain medication use compared to saline injection during total knee replacement (TKR). The study will include forty adult patients who are candidates for TKR with ChPOP. In this interventional study, 20 patients in each group will be randomly assigned to receive either a hot air balloon or a standard saline injection during surgery. Both treatment groups will receive standard postoperative care, including pain medication and physical therapy. The study will last for a total of twelve weeks and will involve multiple follow-up visits to assess pain levels, pain medication use, and the patients' overall recovery. The study is innovative because it uses HAB anesthesia in conjunction with local anesthetic injection to prevent postoperative pain. It is also innovative because it uses a patient survey to evaluate postoperative pain and patient satisfaction with the method of local anesthetic injection. I noticed. Can you explain to me what it means? 

* An observational study involves observing participants without directly intervening. It can be conducted by observing the participant's behavior, testing physiological reactions, or asking participants to complete questionnaires.
* The study phase refers to the point in the research process where the study is conducted. In clinical research, study phases refer to the sequential steps of the drug development process. The preclinical phase involves testing the safety and efficacy of a drug in non-clinical trials, such as lab experiments. The clinical study phase involves testing the safety and efficacy of the drug in humans.
* Phase 1 clinical trials typically evaluate a new drug's safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics (the body's absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of the drug).
* Phase 2 clinical trials evaluate the safety and efficacy of the drug in a larger group of people, usually a few hundred.
* Phase 3 clinical trials evaluate the safety and efficacy of the drug in a large group of people (often thousands), and they are designed to collect data that will help determine whether the drug is effective and safe enough to be approved for use by the general population.

Abstract:
A randomised, double‐blind, multi‐centre, placebo‐controlled trial to compare once daily administration of the anti‐angiogenic monoclonal antibody R51658 (BMS‐275291, bevacizumab biosimilar), to those of conventional oral antivascular endothelial growth factor inhibitor (Avastin(®) 600 mg every 8 weeks) was conducted in 73 patients with non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who had progressed on standard treatments, including cytotoxic chemotherapy and Erlotinib at two centres in India. The primary endpoints for PFS and overall survival were met. The rate of adverse events (AE) in the bevacizumab biosimilar arm was 80% (50/62) which was lower than in the Avastin(®) arm (63/65, 97%). Of particular interest was the difference in the rate of neutropenia reported by the two treatment arms. The incidence of grade 3 or 4 neutropenia was significantly lower (5.6% versus 30.8%, P < 0.05), as was the requirement for prophylactic colony stimulating factor (5/62 versus 14/65). The response rate in the bevacizumab biosimilar arm was similar to that with Avastin(®) (11/62 versus 10/65). Two patient deaths in the trial were considered by the investigator to be due to disease progression. In conclusion, this bevacizumab biosimilar is well tolerated, easy to administer and has a comparable response rate as compared to the reference product.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
BACKGROUND SUMMARY AND RATIONALE The prevalence of shoulder arthroscopy has been rising 300% during the past 20 years, which is one of the most common orthopaedic surgeries. Shoulder arthroscopy involves multiple irrigation and suction cycles, thus there is a significant fluid shift into the extravascular compartment with a consequent risk of postoperative fluid volume overload and pulmonary complications (PE). However, due to the absence of a standard fluid management strategy during shoulder arthroscopy, 30% of patients develop symptomatic pulmonary edema (PPE), and postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) are the cause of increased length of hospital stay and costs, and increased readmissions and morbidity. Thus, there is a need for developing a standard fluid management strategy without increasing adverse outcomes to decrease PPCs and costs. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of different intraoperative fluid management strategies on hemodynamics and pulmonary complications in patients undergoing shoulder arthroscopy. METHODS AND ANALYSIS This pragmatic, randomized, controlled trial will enroll 162 adult patients of either sex undergoing shoulder arthroscopy. Participants will be randomly assigned to either liberal or restrictive fluid management strategies: the 'liberal' strategy group will receive iso-oncotic crystalloid solution to maintain a fluid balance goal of 10% above preoperative body weight during surgery, and the 'restrictive' strategy group will be managed with a fluid balance goal of 0-3% above preoperative body weight during surgery. Cardiovascular instability will be managed with either vasoactive drugs, or packed red blood cells, or vasopressin, or both. The primary outcome measure will be the development of symptomatic PPE. Cardiac biomarkers of myocardial injury, lung injury, renal injury, and electrolyte imbalances will be also assessed. Discussion Trial results will show which of the two intraoperative fluid management strategies

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The investigators propose to identify a subset of patients with early rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with high levels of the circulating inflammatory marker YKL-40 (y KL-40, chitinase-3 like-1) as a biomarker to guide early therapeutic intervention. Specifically, we propose to treat patients with elevated baseline plasma yKL-40 with methotrexate, as compared to placebo, to prevent disease progression and the development of erosive disease in RA. We speculate that patients with elevated yKL-40 are at higher risk for disease progression and may be good candidates for rapid and aggressive treatment to improve long-term outcomes.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the FIRST clinical trial is to provide the first evidence for the performance of infratentorial navigation-guided laser ablation as compared to conventional techniques of radiofrequency ablation in epilepsy surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Laser Interstitial Therapy (LITT) can be realized by using a laser fiber and a specialized laser head which is advanced into the target area percutaneously and placed intracerebrally under endoscopic visualization (Tuberositas LITT with Sparrow and FIRST; ELA Neurosciences, Inc. Tübingen, Germany). The precise, computer-assisted intraoperative targeting and the minimally invasive approach of this intracerebrally applied laser technique are intended to provide high ablative accuracy and good clinical results in patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy. The FIRST design replicates our institutional pilot trial. The sample size of 30 patients (one additional patient is added after interim analysis) will evaluate both safety and efficacy of infratentorial NaviFUS (Tuberositas LITT with Sparrow) vs. conventional technique of radiofrequency (RF) coagulation. In this multi-center, non-comparative, prospective, observational study, the primary objectives are safety (adverse events, adverse drug reactions, serious adverse events), and efficacy (seizure freedom rate). Outcomes of the pilot trial were seizure freedom rate (SFR) at 12 months and excellent/high probability of seizure freedom at 24 months.

Study

Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Acute and chronic pain is highly prevalent among Veterans with recent battle-related war injuries. The most prevalent combat injuries are traumatic limb injuries or traumas to the head. Currently, medications are widely used to treat combat related pain, but they have many limitations. Veterans receiving narcotics through Veterans Health Affairs (VHA) suffer from under treatment of their chronic pain, as well as negative physical and mental health outcomes due to the misuse of opioids, including: tolerance (higher doses to effectively control pain), hyperalgesia (intense pain to mild stimuli), impaired immune function, and cognitive impairment. This lack of effective pain medication is particularly problematic because combat related injuries are often associated with chronic pain, limiting rehabilitation, physical recovery and the resumption of normal duties. There is a clear need to develop new medications that can provide analgesia without the side effects associated with current opioid based treatments. There has been tremendous interest in the medicinal potential of cannabinoids as they present an alternative and potentially more effective method for the management of pain. These compounds exist in the body's endocannabinoid system, a system that is activated by external cannabinoids through the activation of the CB1 and CB2 receptors. They elicit several anti-nociceptive effects, suggesting a possible role for these receptor mediators in the treatment of pain. Recent evidence suggests that the endocannabinoid anandamide is released following tissue injury from surgical and chronic inflammatory pain stimuli in humans. In addition, studies have shown that repeated daily administration of exogenous anandamide exerts anti-nociceptive effects when administered at low doses. Anandamide is rapidly degraded by the enzyme FAAH (fatty acid amide hydrolase). Inhibition of this enzyme, could extend the duration of pain relief following acute injury and would therefore serve as a rationale for the use of FAAH inhibitors. Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To identify reasons for early termination (ET) or not continuing to trial intervention after the first 6‐month appointment in the PATHS randomized, open‐label clinical trial.METHODS: One hundred sixty clinicians were randomized to either the usual care (UC) or a care‐management (CM)‐plus‐guideline intervention. The intervention included care managers implementing individualized action plans to achieve goals. We conducted qualitative interviews with 39 parents who had not responded to the first 6‐month CM appointment, 30 parents who terminated during the first 6 months, 10 parents who terminated after the first 6 months, and 29 parent advocates who worked with parents in CM. We employed a phenomenological approach using constant comparison analysis to develop patterns among and between the different interview groups.RESULTS: We identified 5 key themes: (1) parent experiences of stress leading to EMs; (2) parent experiences of stress as a barrier to responding to CM; (3) issues related to timing of the trial; (4) issues related to the CM intervention; and (5) issues related to the UC intervention.CONCLUSIONS: Parents had varying levels of stress that increased the likelihood of ET or nonresponse. Timing was a key factor in parent EMs, with some parents preferring the first 6 months to be a trial of the intervention, whereas others did not want to wait. Among the issues related to the CM intervention, parents were reluctant to open up to someone new. For parents on the UC randomization arm, the intervention did not align well with their parenting experiences and therefore was not particularly relevant for them. Based on our findings, we identified a number of strategies to improve enrollment and retention in CM.

Abstract:
Background: A small randomized controlled trial by the Department of Clinical and Rehabilitation Neurosciences at the National Institute for Health Research, University College London Hospitals (UCLH) showed that a motor‐cable‐driven system (MCDS), a robotic rehabilitation device that provides intensive, repetitive movement exercises, was effective in improving wrist and forearm function in both subacute and chronic stroke patients. However, there were no significant differences between acuities. To avoid potential effects of the natural history of rehabilitation, it is important to focus on acute‐phase stroke patients. Objective: To establish the feasibility of conducting a phase III randomized, controlled trial comparing functional use and upper limb function in acute‐phase stroke patients who were treated using either a MCDS or conventional rehabilitation exercises (CTRL). Method: The study is a pilot study that will focus on acute stroke patients. The patient groups will be randomized to either the CTRL group or MCDS group. Both groups will receive the same amount of rehabilitation exercise sessions, but the MCDS group will use MCDS for their rehabilitation exercises, which consists of wrist/forearm movement, whereas the CTRL group will use physiotherapy‐led exercises. Participants will be assessed at three clinical sessions, and the outcome measures will be the Fugl‐Meyer Motor Assessment – upper limb (UE) score, Action Research Arm Test, and functional use tests such as Box andBlocks Test, and nine‐hole peg test. The outcome measures will be assessed at baseline and 4, 8, 12, 16, 20 weeks. Both groups will receive the same amount of rehabilitation physical therapy. In addition, we intend to follow up patients in both groups at 24 weeks to observe their long‐term progress. Sample size: 80 volunteers in both groups are planned. The primary outcomes are Fugl‐Meyer Motor Assessment - upper limb, Action Research Arm Test, and functional use tests. Recruitment: We will recruit patients for the study from UCLH and other facilities in the UK.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to explore the correlations among vasorin level, kidney disease (acute kidney injury) and poor outcomes in patients with septic shock. In addition, the relationship between vasorin expression, cytokines and cell proliferation/apoptosis will also be explored.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of this study is to explore the correlations among vasorin level, kidney disease (acute kidney injury) and poor outcomes in patients with septic shock. First enrolled 60 sepsis patients and 30 ICU control patients. The researchers will collect detailed data of hemodynamic parameters, organ failures, urine output, vasorin, cytokines and cells proliferation/apoptosis information. Then, they will collect 12 months mortality and ICU-free days within 12 months for follow-up and assess the correlation between the vasorin level and mortality and ICU-free days. Second enrolled 40 septic shock patients with vasorin elevation and then divided them into vasorin positive group (≥10000 pg/mL) and vasorin negative group (<10000 pg/mL). The 4 groups will conduct a comparative study and explore the reasons for vasorin elevation, correlations among vasorin level, cytokines, kidney damage and prognosis in septic shock patients through the changes of inflammatory cytokines and cells proliferation/apoptosis, blood vessel dilation, and kidney cell function. A prospective, randomized, multi-center, two-group, non-controlled clinical study was planned. The subjects of this study were sepsis patients who met the sepsis guidelines of American College of Chest Physicians/Society of Critical Care Medicine (2016) (17-125 years old) and acute kidney injury patients who met the Acute Kidney Injury Network criteria. The participants will be screened and selected by inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of the IMAGINE study is to provide evidence of the effect of erythropoetin (EPO) in a patient-centered cohort of HCT patients with anemia during neutrophil depletion (ND). Specifically, the study assesses the impact of EPO (in addition to standard care) during ND on the risk of developing acute kidney injury (AKI) within the first 28 days after transplant and 6 months after HCT. The study uses an established risk score index (KDIGO) to evaluate this outcome. A secondary objective is to assess the impact of EPO during ND on all-cause transplant-related mortality (TRM) at 100 days after HCT, and 6 and 12 months after HCT. These findings may be used to modify current HCT guidelines for the use of EPO during ND.

=================
Background and objectives:Septic shock is a life-threatening complication of sepsis characterized by low blood pressure and evidence of inadequate organ perfusion despite administration of adequate fluid resuscitation. Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common complication of septic shock, occurring in up to 40% of patients, and is associated with increased morbidity, mortality, and costs. Despite intensive care and treatment with sepsis bundles, the prognosis for such patients remains poor.  In this setting, the early identification of those patients at risk of progressing to AKI may help guide appropriate individualized therapy to prevent or limit its development. 

Rationale for the study: In recent years, increasing attention has been paid to the role of proinflammatory cytokines such as interleukin-6 (IL-6) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) in the pathogenesis and progression of sepsis-related AKI. Abstract:
Background: Pain associated with menstruation can have negative effects on work, school and leisure activities and is one of the most frequently reported reasons for seeking care in adolescents. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a coconut water supplement combined with dietary dark chocolate in the management of menstrual pain compared to nonsteroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) in adolescent women (N = 50; 15‐17 y) with primary dysmenorrhea. Methods: Participants were randomized into three groups: dark chocolate and coconut water supplementation (DM), dark chocolate supplementation (MC), and a control group receiving NSAIDs (NSAID). The study design included a baseline questionnaire regarding demographics, medical history, smoking, and daily oral contraceptive use, followed by one week of supplementation with or without NSAIDs. Participants recorded their pain scores and evaluated their levels of satisfaction using a standardized online questionnaire. Analyses included descriptive statistics, analysis of variance, and the post hoc Tukey and Kruskal‐Wallis tests. Results: The participants' mean age was 17 and the majority were adolescent women. Adolescents in the DM group reported lower levels of pain than those in the NSAID group (p = 0.002). The highest satisfaction with treatment was reported by those in the DM group. There were no statistically significant differences in the use of the supplements between adolescent women. However, satisfaction was positively related to pain intensity. Conclusion: Our study suggests that dark chocolate and coconut water supplementation could be an effective strategy for managing menstrual pain due to dysmenorrhea in adolescent women. Although the satisfaction scores were satisfactory in all participants, more research is needed to determine whether there is a link between pain intensity and the use of supplements with a possible synergistic effect.

Description
=================
The study will consist of two phases: a first screening and inclusion phase and a second intervention and follow-up phase. During the first, subjects who present at the emergency department with symptoms suggesting acute appendicitis will be recruited. In the emergency department, patients will receive routine testing, including both laboratory and imaging evaluations. They will be included in the study if they meet the eligibility criteria mentioned above. They will then be randomly assigned to receive either antibiotics or observation followed by surgery if necessary. If they are allocated to the antibiotic group, they will be treated with a standardized regimen of ciprofloxacin, metronidazole, and amoxicillin/clavulanic acid for a total of 7 days, followed by surgery if necessary. If they are allocated to the observation group, they will undergo imaging evaluation after 48 hours and surgery will be performed if the imaging shows appendicitis. Clinical tests will be performed throughout the study to monitor the patient's health and response to treatment. The primary outcome measure will be the duration of hospital stay. Secondary outcome measures will include the occurrence of complications, patient satisfaction, and the cost-effectiveness of the treatment regimen. A final follow-up will be conducted 4 weeks after the intervention to assess post-discharge outcomes, including adverse events and readmission rates. The study will use a randomized, double-blind, single-center design. The study is expected to enroll 100 participants, with a statistical power of 80% and a significance level of 5%, ensuring that the study results are statistically significant and robust. The aim of the study is to determine the best treatment approach for suspected acute appendicitis while minimizing the risk of complications and cost. The results of the study will be presented at academic conferences and published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, contributing to the body of knowledge in this field and guiding future research. The study will also improve the care and management of patients with suspected acute appendicitis, increasing diagnostic accuracy, and reducing unnecessary surgeries

Effects of oral administration of S-adenosyl-L-methionine on exercise recovery in humans

Abstract:
The effect of S‐adenosyl‐L‐methionine (AdoMet) on exercise recovery in humans is not well understood and may be different between athletes and non‐athlete control groups. The purpose of this investigation was to measure serum catecholamines and cortisol, heart rate, body temperature, and performance parameters during and following a 2 min Wingate anaerobic power test in response to oral administration of AdoMet (600mg or placebo) to both trained (n = 14) and non trained (n = 8) athletes. All subjects underwent two sessions, seven days apart, with one randomized to a treatment and the other to a placebo condition. Data were analysed by repeated ANOVA analysis. Peak heart rate and serum cortisol were increased immediately after the test from baseline in the placebo condition in both groups. Performance was marginally improved after AdoMet in the placebo and the exercise intensity of the Wingate. Oral consumption of S‐AdoMet did not affect the magnitude of catecholamine responses during and following the Wingate in either group. There is no evidence that S‐AdoMet ingestion improves either post exercise recovery or performance within a large group of athletes or healthy sedentary individuals.

Study population
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Tumours of the adrenal gland are rare with the annual incidence per 100,000 being estimated as 0.6 males and 0.3 females. The most common tumours are adrenal cortical tumours such as adenoma (40-70%), adenocortical carcinoma (ACC) (30-40%) and pheochromocytoma (PCC) (10-18%). Clinical symptoms are either very suggestive for an underlying adrenocortical tumour or the diagnosis is established by chance due to abnormal findings on cross sectional imaging examinations, such as computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of the abdomen performed in patients with a variety of other abdominal or extra abdominal clinical problems. Diagnosis is usually established by biopsy, either percutaneous or by surgical biopsy. If possible surgical exploration is still the gold standard. However, in many patients adrenal tumour cannot be proven by biopsy and imaging findings are often insufficient for a reliable diagnosis. The main reasons may be the absence of distinct clinical features, or a non specific biologic profile of the adenoma. This is particularly the case with cortical benign neoplasms, which are often smaller than 3 cm, the biopsy yield is low and the biologic profile is similar to non neoplastic cortical tissue. The distinction between nodular hyperplasia, ectopic cortisol secreting tumour and adenoma is often difficult to make. In such cases medical therapy or surgical treatment without preoperative diagnosis is a debated topic. Several prospective randomized studies are ongoing to investigate the risk of recurrence after medical treatment with Mitotane alone versus Mitotane plus surgery. To date no prospective randomized study has been published investigating the outcome of surgical therapy versus follow-up with medical treatment with Mitotane alone for patients with ACC. This study aims to evaluate and compare the clinical outcome after radical surgical adrenalectomy versus follow-up with mitotane mon

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aims: The incidence of gallstones and gallbladder cancer is on the rise globally. Endoscopic ultrasound-guided cholangioscopy (EUS-C) and cystogastro-duodenoscopy (EUS-CD) are effective for the treatment of gallstones and gallbladder cancer. Lumen apposing metal stent (LAMS) is associated with less postoperative pain and fewer complications compared with endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting, but further studies are required to investigate EUS-C/EUS-CD guided LAMS in the treatment of gallbladder disease. However, these studies are still insufficient, and the diagnostic value and safety of LUMEN apposing metal stent guided cholangioscopy and cystogastro-duodenoscopy are still unknown, particularly its application in patients with a high risk of postoperative complications. In this study, we aim to investigate the diagnostic value and safety of endoscopic ultrasound-guided gallbladder treatment using LAMS under dynamic contrast-enhanced ultrasound and optical coherence tomography guidance on different status of cholecystectomy. Intervention

The intervention for this study is rTMS. The participants will receive anodal and sham stimulation to the left dorso-lateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) of the brain. The procedure will be randomized and double-blind, meaning that participants will not know whether they are receiving active or sham stimulation. The parameters of the stimulation will be set to 1 Hz, 0.8-1.0 mT intensity, and 10 Hz, 80% motor threshold intensity. A total of 10 stimulations will be administered per stimulation session, and 20 stimulation sessions will be completed over the course of 10 weeks. One stimulation session will be performed twice a week for a total of 5 consecutive days, followed by an off period of 2 days. The participants will receive 3 weeks of anodal stimulation followed by 3 weeks of sham stimulation, resulting in 4 weeks of active stimulation and 6 weeks of sham stimulation. Additionally, a 4-day washout period will be observed between active and sham stimulation. The participants will continue to receive monthly rTMS for 12 months after receiving active or sham stimulations.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this research study is to determine if the combination of PET and MRI are better than PET alone at identifying breast cancer in women who have had biopsy-proven benign breast disease. Breasts that are biopsy-proven benign are typically followed to make sure that there is no cancer present. PET may be able to determine which women with benign breast disease are truly benign (i.e., no cancer) and which women will need more evaluation for breast cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
For the preliminary study, women 18 years of age or older with biopsy-proven benign breast disease will be eligible to participate. They will undergo a breast MRI, contrast-enhanced mammogram, PET scan, and MRI-guided biopsy to measure the accuracy of these studies in terms of their ability to detect small areas of breast cancer. The results will indicate whether these methods can successfully replace PET alone. This screening portion of the study will only be about 3 to 4 weeks in duration. Based on the results, we will have sufficient data to justify the cost and time of a full-scale study. Once the preliminary study is complete, these results will be shared with breast cancer scientists around the world and will play a major role in the design of a larger multi-center study. For the full-scale study, women 25 years of age or older with biopsy-proven benign breast disease will be eligible to participate. They will undergo a breast MRI, contrast-enhanced mammogram, and PET scan to determine which modality (MRI, mammogram, or PET scan) might be the most effective method. If a subject is found to have a high degree of suspicion (75 to 100%) of having breast cancer, based on the results of an initial PET scan, then biopsy will be performed unless no lesions are detected. If a subject is found to have a moderately high degree of suspicion (25 to 75%) of having breast cancer, then biopsy will be performed. If no lesions or a small number of small lesions are detected, then subjects will be monitored with repeat imaging at 6

Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease who will undergo real repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) sessions.
Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves 4 daily 25-minute high-frequency rTMS sessions over one week using a 70-mm figure-eight coil at 20Hz. Target localization will be performed with a stereotaxic neuronavigation system.
Reasoning: This arm is essential to test the efficacy of non-invasive stimulation techniques, specifically real rTMS, in modulating the default mode network (DMN) in individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease. Background
-----------------
Brain metastasis represents a serious condition and is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality among patients with cancer, especially for those with advanced breast cancer . The estimated overall mortality rate for patients with brain metastasis is approximately 70% during the first 1-2 yrs, with a median survival time of 8-12 months . Patients with brain metastasis are typically first managed with a combination of radiation therapy and surgery . There have been significant advances in tumor management in recent years, but limited treatment modalities are available to effectively treat brain metastases. Patients with leptomeningeal disease involving the spinal cord may have significant neurological deficits, reduced quality of life (QOL), functional impairment, and premature death . Although there is no standard of care for treating brain metastases, several studies have demonstrated the potential benefit of whole-brain radiotherapy (WBRT) (or stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) ) . NovoTTF-200T 1 (optune) is a tumor-treating fields (TTF) device that uses low-intensity alternating electric fields to disrupt mitosis, resulting in arrested cell division and cell death. NovoTTF-200T 1 is FDA-approved for the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma , gliosarcoma , and malignant melanoma . Preliminary data suggest that NovoTTF-200T 1 may be an effective treatment for patients with leptomeningeal metastases of the spine. The present study is a prospective, multi-center, single-arm study that will include 15 patients who have previously received WBRT/SRS treatment but continue to have leptomeningeal metastases of the spine in patients with recurrent breast cancer. The objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of NovoTTF-200T 1 in these patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This proposal aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of pro-biotics after liver surgery on ICU patients' outcome and microbiota. A Prospective, randomized, double blind clinical trial will be performed.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Rationale: The management of severe sepsis and intra-abdominal infections in patients after liver surgery requires the use of wide antibiotic spectrum antibiotics. Recent findings about human microbiota, especially the gut microbiota, and its strong interaction with various tissues and systems, are starting to shed new light on a potential pathogenetic pathway leading from intestinal epithelium damage to multiorgan dysfunction. The gut-liver axis is emerging as a major actor in systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and sepsis, and gut permeability and translocation to the liver and systemic circulation have been linked to clinical outcomes in patients with major hepatic or abdominal surgery. This suggests that strategies targeting modulation of the gut microbiota could represent a new approach to prevent sepsis. As yet, no RCTs have investigated the effect of orally administered probiotics on SIRS and sepsis induced by various surgical techniques. Moreover, the optimal moment to treat and the best period of treatment is still unknown. A Prospective, randomized, double blind clinical trial will be performed. The study outcomes are ICU length of stay, organ dysfunction, hospital length of stay and mortality. The investigators hypothesize that the probiotic therapy will reduce the incidence of gut permeability, SIRS, sepsis and organ dysfunction, with a consequent reduction in the ICU length of stay, and an improvement in clinical outcomes and mortality.

Prophylactic Treatment of Probiotics in Patients After Hepatectomy - RANDOMIZED, DOUBLE BLIND PROSPECTIVE CLINICAL TRIAL

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this prospective, multi-site trial is to study the surgical characteristics of laparoscopic antegrade modular pancreatosplenectomy (LRAMPS) and laparoscopic en-bloc pancreatoduodenectomy (LEPC) and to compare the clinical outcomes after the two procedures in terms of hospital stay, complications and mortality in an Asian population.

Detailed Description
-----------------
LRAMPS was first described by Rene Tome in Belgium in 2010. It is a technique of pancreatosplenectomy that allows pancreatic cancer or benign lesions that occur on the left (i.e., more than 75% of the pancreas) to be resected en-bloc. It is performed in three parts: the spleen (splenectomy), left pancreas followed by splenectomy and the posterior wall of the stomach and pancreatoduodenectomy (PDD)/pancreatectoduodenectomy (PD) is performed during the second part. The last and final step is the reconstruction with duodeno-gastrojejunostomy (DG) and gastroduodenostomy (GD). In contrast, for patients with right or central pancreatic lesions, we will perform LEP for en-bloc resection. In recent series, LEP has been shown to have better oncological outcomes than LP due to better lymph node resection. LRAMPS has been performed more than 3000 times worldwide, and the 5-year survival rate of low-risk pancreatic cancer patients (stage A/B) is about 72%, which is comparable to those of LP and LEP . There is some difference in operative time between the two groups, which may lead to faster postoperative recovery and more rapid mobilization. In this study, we will compare the surgical characteristics of LRAMPS and LEP in terms of tumor location and surgical outcomes in terms of operative time, length of stay, complications, and long-term survival.

Brief Summary

The objective of this study was to investigate whether different methods of transplantation for liver cancer. Detailed Description

This is an open-label, multi-center, phase III clinical study. Inclusion criteria and exclusion criteria of patients will be explained as follows: Inclusion criteria: (1) diagnosed as HCC after tumor resection; (2) 1-3 intrahepatic lesions on abdominal CT as a target lesion, ≤ 5 lesions in total, each lesion diameter<10cm; (3) Child-Pugh grade (CPG) grade ≤7 points; (4) Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) score 0-2; (5) Adequate liver function, that is, total bilirubin <100 μmol/L, alanine aminotransferase(ALT), and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) ≤ 3 × ULN. Study Arm 1:
Participant Group/Arm: LRAMPS group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LRAMPS
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic radical antegrade modular pancreatosplenectomy (LRAMPS) surgery. This arm is necessary to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LRAMPS with those undergoing LDP. The LRAMPS procedure involves the removal of Gerota's fascia and perirenal fat capsule, with the option to perform anterior or posterior LRAMPS depending on the resection of the left adrenal gland. The removal of specific lymph nodes is also outlined based on the tumor location.

Study Arm 2:
Participant Group/Arm: LDP group
Intervention/Treatment: Procedure: LDP
Patients who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will undergo laparoscopic distal pancreatosplecnectomy (LDP) surgery. This arm is essential to compare the outcomes of patients undergoing LDP with those undergoing LRAMPS. The LDP procedure involves dissection behind the fusion fascia and the removal of specific lymph nodes based on the tumor location. This arm allows for a comparison of outcomes between LDP and LRAMPS in the context of early-stage left-sided pancreatic cancer.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study aims to study the effects of high-fat meals on appetite and satiety and on physiological markers of the gastrointestinal tract in healthy lean and overweight or obese older adults. The study will be conducted at the Laboratory of Neuro Imaging in a randomized, parallel, double-blind controlled study, including measurements of physiological markers (blood glucose, insulin, GLP-1, PYY, cholecystokinin, ghrelin, and leptin) at different time-points in a subgroup of subjects. The measurements will be performed during a three-hour test period and participants are asked to abstain from all food and beverage except for water. Participants will be served meals of 40%, 50%, 60%, or 70% fat and will be asked to rate their satiety.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Obesity is a common and multifactorial disease characterized by an increase in fat mass that is associated with decreased life expectancy and adversely affects the quality of life and health. Obesity often develops due to increased food intake, leading to weight gain and ultimately obesity. Increased energy intake due to larger portion sizes, unhealthy snacking, low levels of physical activity, increased consumption of sweet snacks or beverages are all factors that may contribute to the development of obesity in society. Increased fat consumption is considered as a risk factor for obesity and weight gain, however, little is known about how high-fat meals affect appetite and satiety and whether this is different in healthy lean and overweight or obese individuals. The purpose of this study is to examine if fat increases appetite or suppresses satiety to a different extent in healthy lean and overweight or obese older adults. By better understanding this relationship, we hope to improve dietary guidelines, thus increasing the overall health of older adults.

Official Title
-----------------
Food Choice and Gastrointestinal Hormones in Older Adults

Obesity

Study Overview

Brief Summary

The purpose of this study is to test the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of a single treatment of ATR-351 administered topically in persons with Netherton syndrome.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study is designed to test the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of a single treatment of ATR12-351 administered topically to adults with Netherton syndrome. The study will consist of 3 parts: PK/PD screening, PK/PD treatment, and follow-up. PK/PD screening will last up to 12 weeks (visits 1-4), and PK/PD treatment will consist of a single topical application of ATR12-351 on each side of the body (back and buttocks) and a vehicle control on each side of the body (back and buttocks), alternating every 12 hours for 12 weeks (visits 5-10). The follow-up visit (visit 11) will take place 8 weeks after the last visit. Primary objectives include measuring the systemic concentration of ATR12-351 (i.e., PK analysis) and assessing specific PK/PD biomarkers for neutrophil activation and chemotaxis. Secondary objectives include assessing local (to the treatment and control site) skin barrier, dryness and scaling, inflammation, and subjective symptomology; assessing systemic safety as measured by adverse events and clinical laboratory evaluations; evaluating anti-ATR12-351 antibody status; assessing gene expression of pro-inflammatory biomarkers (IL-8 and ELANE) following drug administration using a

A total of 50 patients (25 females, 25 males) will be randomly assigned (according to a pre-determined distribution scheme) to either the control or the experimental groups. The enrolled patients will then undergo a second survey, where they will be asked about their post-treatment psoriasis status and their experience with the treatment. The results of this second survey will be used to compare the effectiveness and safety of the two treatment approaches.

The test group was more satisfied with the achieved effect and reported no side effects. The control group reported more side effects and was less satisfied with the achieved effect. Conclusion: Zantogin® Gel has clinical effectiveness for mild to moderate acne vulgaris and acne rosacea and is very well tolerated. Effectiveness Zantogin® Gel is achieved without side effects and without interactions with other drugs.

A Phase 4, Prospective, 12-month Observational Study to Evaluate the Effects of Zantogin® Gel Topical Treatment on Quality of Life and Vaginal Health in Women with Genitourinary Syndrome of Menopause (GSM)

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Vaginal atrophy is the most common physical symptom of genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM). The prevalence of GSM increases with age and reaches around 60% at menopausal age. One cause of GSM is the decreased amount of estrogen (a female sex hormone). Menopause is a natural process that usually occurs at around 45-55 years of age, and in many cases is followed by postmenopausal symptoms such as vaginal dryness. When used as a gel applied twice a week for 12 weeks in the vagina, Zantogin® Gel (with the active ingredient lactobacillus) can reduce vaginal and dyspareunia symptoms. With the use of this drug in postmenopausal women, the microbiota and the vaginal pH were changed to premenopausal levels within 4 weeks, and the frequency of using pain-relieving drugs decreased. Based on these results, this study will evaluate the efficacy of Zantogin® Gel in long-term vaginal therapy and quality of life improvement in women with GSM.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a 12-month multi-center prospective observational study designed to evaluate the effectiveness of vaginal Zantogin® Gel as a long-term vulvovaginal treatment in menopausal women with vaginal atrophy and genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM). Study participants received a prescription for Zantogin® Gel 0.1% vaginal and were instructed to apply twice a week for 3 months. Primary Endpoints: Evaluation of sexual function and vaginal function after using Zantogin Gel for 3 months, Evaluation of the number and type of infections of the vagina, urethra and urinary

The gel is a colorless, clear, and odorless product that needs to be applied daily or at least every 48 hours for a period of two weeks.

Abstract:
AIM: To study the effect and safety of the addition of nigella sativa hydroalcoholic extract nano liposome (NSHAE‐NL) to the standard drug regimen on inflammatory markers, oral symptoms, and side effects in patients with periodontitis.MATERIALS AND METHODS: Patients diagnosed with stage 1 or 2 periodontal disease received the standard periodontal treatment protocol in the placebo group or the NSHAE‐NL supplementation to the standard regimen in the clinical group. Serum hs‐CRP, PTX3 levels and NBS were measured 1 week prior to the intervention and 3 months after the commencement of the treatment protocol. A visual analogue scale (VAS) was also determined before the initiation of the study and 3 months after the intervention.RESULTS: Twenty male patients (mean age±SD years: 35.00±1.69) were included in this trial. Mean clinical measurements were in the 3rd and 4th quartiles for all variables. At the baseline, there was no difference between the clinical and the placebo groups regarding the variables. The serum levels of hs‐CRP, PTX3, IL‐1β, IL‐12, and IL‐17 decreased significantly in the clinical group and 3 months after the protocol, while there was no change in the placebo group except for IL‐1β that decreased significantly in the placebo group. Also, the NBS increased significantly for both groups, but no statistical difference was found between the groups and there were no side effects.CONCLUSIONS: The addition of NSHAE‐NL (80 mg/day) to the standard protocol may have a beneficial effect on periodontal diseases and can be considered as an adjuvant to the standard drug regimen.

Abstract:
Background: Burn injuries impact around 180,000 patients and 255,000 emergency visits across the world every year. It is the most common cause of hospitalization among children and the third most severe injury in the United States. Burn injuries can cause physical, psychological, and social problems, in addition to disfigurement, pain, and disability [1,2]. As the incidence of burn injuries appears to be increasing every year, the need for burn care is growing, but the development of burn care and support systems is inadequate. Peer education has been recognized as an effective and powerful alternative method for health behavior change. However, there are no peer education studies targeting patient‐centered health outcomes specific to burn patients. Therefore, we aimed to develop and implement a peer education program for burn patients and verify the effectiveness of the program. Methods: This feasibility study is being conducted as a prospective randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of peer education on core health outcomes specific for burn patients. We used a sequential explanatory‐mixed methods design in this study. Fifty‐four recently admitted hemodynamically stable patients with burn injuries meeting the inclusion criteria were enrolled and randomly allocated to the intervention or intervention group. The peer educator was a male adult patient who participated in the program five years earlier. The peer educator provided interventions by making educational materials, having one‐on‐one consultations with patients, and holding group discussions. The control group will continue to receive routine care for burn patients in the department. Data were collected using a questionnaire before and after the intervention. The primary outcome was perceived peer support, and the secondary outcome was self‐efficacy. Outcome measurements were compared among the two groups using chi‐squared and Student's t‐tests. Key exclusion criteria
=================

Brief summary
=================
Burns often result in substantial psychosocial and physical impairments, with a potential for high mortality rates and lifelong health and social care needs. At present the treatment consists of intensive treatment of the injuries in the first month, and extensive physical rehabilitation during the following months. Psychological problems such as anxiety, depression, and psychosocial isolation should be detected early and appropriately treated. However, burn patients often suffer from a lack of social support, which may result in further isolation and impairments. As treatment of psychological problems, patients benefit from peer support by trained peers. There has been no systematic assessment of the effectiveness of training peers. The aim of the study is to assess whether peer education during admission to the burn unit has a beneficial effect on short and long-term recovery of burns patients.
