Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This phase I trial studies the side effects and best dose of MEDI9197 and if it works in treating patients with ovarian cancer that has just been diagnosed (recurrent) ovarian cancer, fallopian tube cancer, or primary peritoneal cancer that may have spread to other parts of the body. MEDI9197 is a monoclonal antibody, which is made of proteins that can locate and bind to PD-1. When MEDI9197 binds to PD-1, some of the tumor cells may die. Giving MEDI9197 may allow the body's immune system to attack the cancer, and may interfere with the ability of tumor cells to grow and spread.

Detailed Description
-----------------
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES: I. To estimate the toxicity associated with MEDI9197, MEDI973 and doxorubicin hydrochloride (DXR) administered to patients with recurrent ovarian cancer, primary peritoneal cancer or fallopian tube cancer (R/R EOC) as a combination treatment. SECONDARY OBJECTIVES: I. Assess pathological responses in subjects treated with the combination of MEDI9197, MEDI973 and DXR as measured by changes in tumor burden. II. Objective tumor response rate in all treated patients using response evaluation criteria in solid tumors (RECIST 1.1) and immunotherapy-adapted Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (iamRECIST) III. To characterize the immunological response. OUTLINE: This is a multicenter, dose escalation, open-label, phase I trial of MEDI9197, MEDI973 or DXR. Patients receive MEDI9197 intravenously (IV) over 60 minutes on days 1 and 15, MEDI973 IV on day 3, and DXR IV over 5-10 minutes on day 1. Courses repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease

=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background: The gastrointestinal syndrome can manifest as acute diarrhea (AD), cholera, acute gastroenteritis, as well as chronic diarrhea and related to several forms of colitis. The clinical management of patients with these infections relies on the maintenance of fluid balance. Despite the significant development in therapeutic antidiarrheal drugs, this syndrome remains responsible for many deaths worldwide. Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this work is to describe the experience with radiometric imaging and dosimetry of the human male and female pelvis at low dose (8 microSv per examination) of a novel prostatic cancer imaging agent 68Ga-PSMA-14 with the use of SPECT/CT and PET/CT imaging systems. The investigators have used a commercially available radiotracer and evaluated the radiotracer kinetic on patients, in whom it is known that the normal biodistribution of the probe is very limited due to the presence of a normal and an enlarged prostate. All patients have undergone multiple imaging sessions during baseline and at one week and one month post injection in order to evaluate the radiokinetic over this time span and to study the dosimetry of PET/CT and SPECT/CT in male patients, and the dosimetry of PET/CT only in female patients. The investigators aim to use the current data to further develop the current PSMA-14 probe using the 68Ga radiolabel.

AIMS: To determine if the number of episodes of moderate/severe haemorrhage (MSH) can be reduced by transfusing erythrocyte concentrates enriched with iron particles.METHODS AND RESULTS: Methaemoglobin enriched red cell concentrates (MEC; n = 21) were tested in a randomised, comparative, non‐ blinded trial vs. commercially available red cell concentrates (RC; n = 14). MEC had significantly lower haematocrit and Fe2+ compared to RC (19.1% vs 22.9% p < 0.0001; 47 μg Fe2+/l vs 108 μg Fe2+/l, p < 0.0001). The median number of platelet transfusions was lower during MEC treatment than during RC treatment (p = 0.007), with significantly fewer days receiving any transfusions (p = 0.022). However, there were no differences in total MSH or the number of MSHs resulting in hospital admission.CONCLUSIONS: There was a trend towards less total MSH associated with MEC treatment, but the number of MSH requiring hospitalisation was unaffected when RC or MEC were used.TRIAL REGISTRATION NUMBER: NCT02673975. This randomised controlled study does not meet the criteria for reporting preferred reporting items for randomized trials (CONSORT).

Intervention Description:: Cerebral Palsy is a neurologic disorder that permanently affects motor activity during the first year of the brain's development. The causes of cognitive disabilities caused by Cerebral Palsy include prenatal injury caused by physical stress on the fetus or hypoxic damage due to intrapartum asphyxia. When brain injury is severe, cognitive impairment may persist. It is a disease characterized by slow and gradual development of symptoms, inadequate physical growth, and low intelligence and cognition. It is classified into spastic spasticity, hypotonic spasticity, extrapyramidal spasticity, and mixed spasticity according to the degree of movement and posture. 
Intrathecal recombinant human insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) was approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration in 1999. It can be used for the treatment of infantile muscle spasticity caused by cerebral palsy in addition to muscle relaxants and botulinum toxin. IGF-1 is an anabolic hormone secreted from the liver with stimulatory effects on muscle growth, fat metabolism, and bone formation.

Abstract:
Objectives: Although intrapleural fibrinolytic therapy with recombinant human tissue plasminogen activator (r‐tPA) is commonly used in the treatment of parapneumonic complications, several aspects of the treatment require study. In addition, intrapleural DNase has been increasingly used to dissolve clotted pleural effusion. However, data regarding both the use of r‐tPA and DNase for pleural infections is limited in the literature. Methods and Results: A prospective, randomized trial was conducted and enrolled patients with parapneumonic effusions and/or pleural infection. We randomized patients to low‐dose intrapleural r‐tPA (N=23) or standard‐dose intrapleural tPA plus intrapleural DNase (N=23), according to predetermined inclusion and exclusion criteria. The primary outcomes were (a) hospitalization for pleural infection, (b) overall hospitalization and the need for mechanical ventilation as a function of predetermined clinical outcome, and (c) pleurodesis at 180 days. We noted a trend toward increased use of intrapleural antibiotic or fibrinolytics in the r‐tPA group as compared with the r‐tPA plus DNase group (55% versus 24%, P=0.07). The hospitalization rate (93% versus 81%, P=0.43), overall hospitalization (242+/‐73 days versus 252+/‐77 days, P=0.84), mechanical ventilation use (79% versus 70%, P=0.97), and pleurodesis (26% versus 27%, P=0.62) rates were comparable for low‐dose r‐tPA and r‐tPA plus DNase groups. Conclusion: Based on our study results, we can not recommend either the use of low‐dose r‐tPA or the combination of r‐tPA plus DNase as an effective therapy for parapneumonic effusion and/or pleural infection.

Abstract:
Objectives: To investigate if there are differences in health status outcomes for children with congenital heart disease (CHD) treated with homecare or hospitalbased inpatient medical follow‐up. In Australia and some other Western countries, there is a paradigm shift towards hospital‐in‐the‐home (HITH) for paediatric post cardiac surgery rehabilitation. An important component for paediatric patients to be discharged from hospital is effective medication administration techniques at home. The present clinical trial aimed to evaluate whether an electronic system for administration of oral medications was equally effective as the currently established administration methods: home nursing visits or hospital‐based medication administration by nursing staff. Methods: This was a multicentre, single‐blind, randomized and controlled trial of 132 children. Children from 23 cardiac intensive care units were allocated by block randomization (1:1:1) to receive medication via an electronic administration system (e‐track), a nurse‐administered oral medication in a hospital‐based inpatient setting (nursing‐track) or administering the medication at home as usual (regular‐track). The primary outcome was achievement of the medication target of >80% adherence. Results: The trial was terminated prematurely after four interim analyses indicated an increased risk of nonconcomitant drug intake in the two intervention groups (e‐track/nursing‐track), potentially leading to adverse health events. No significant differences were found between the three groups in achieving the medication target of >80% adherence. For medication adherence, there was a significant difference between 18 children who were ≥7 months of age or who had a pre‐operative diagnosis of heart disease vs. 114 who were <7 months of age or who had a post‐operative diagnosis of heart disease. For time to medication administration, there was a significant difference between 12 children with a ventricular septal defect and 40 children with other heart diseases. Conclusions: In this trial, a more robust assessment of potential risks associated with the use of electronic administration systems could not be performed. OBJECTIVES: This study aimed to examine the efficacy and safety of a new formula, Lumix Xenon, in relieving the symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). BACKGROUND: IBS is one of the most common functional gastrointestinal disorders, with an estimated prevalence of 10‐15% in industrialized societies. The pathogenesis of IBS is still unclear, and various studies have shown that increased levels of neuroinflammation and dysregulation of the intestinal microbiota play important roles. Lumix Xenon contains extracts of traditional Chinese herbal medicines, which have demonstrated antioxidant, anti‐inflammatory, and intestinal health‐promoting effects. This study aimed to investigate the efficacy and safety of Lumix Xenon in IBS patients.METHODS: A total of 96 patients with IBS were randomly assigned to receive Lumix Xenon capsules (2 capsules, 3 times/day, for 12 weeks) or placebo capsules. The efficacy and patient acceptance of Lumix Xenon were compared with those of placebo from the patient's acceptance, gastrointestinal function, inflammatory factor level, and fecal microbiota composition. The safety of Lumix Xenon was assessed based on the adverse events reported by the patients.RESULTS: The administration of Lumix Xenon resulted in significantly greater patient acceptance than the placebo group. Lumix Xenon group showed a pronounced therapeutic effect on relieving abdominal pain, relieving bloating, alleviating abdominal distension, and improving stool consistency. It also significantly reduced the levels of interleukin‐1β and inflammatory bowel disease symptom scores. Lumix Xenon treatment resulted in a significant increase in the abundance of potentially beneficial bacterial taxa, such as Bacteroides, Parabacteroides, Akkermansia, and Bifidobacterium, while significantly reducing the abundance of potentially harmful bacterial taxa, such as Dialister and Ruminococcaceae. Abstract:
Background: Risk factors for cerebral hypoperfusion (CHP) after thoracic aortic surgery are largely unknown. This study evaluated the use of near‐infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) to investigate risk factors for CHP after thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR), and the efficacy of neuraxial anesthesia. Methods: This was a prospective, double‐blind, and randomised trial. A total of 45 patients were assigned into three groups, including the neuraxial anesthesia group (n = 15), the general anesthesia group 1 (GAP1; n = 15), and the general anesthesia group 2 (GAP2; n = 15). The neuraxial anesthesia group received general anesthesia combined with thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) anesthesia, while GAP1 and GAP2 groups received general anesthesia only. We used the NIRS index as the primary outcome indicator. Furthermore, other indicators, such as the incidence of postoperative complications, and the incidence of new ischaemic brain injury within 24 h after operation and within 28 days postoperatively, were observed. Results: After 24 h, the cerebral oxygen saturation (StO2) of GAP1 was higher than that of GAP2 in both the left and right frontal lobe regions, while the cerebral oxygenated haemoglobin index (rSO2) and total haemoglobin index (tHb) of GAP2 were higher than that of GAP1 (P < 0.05). Further observation found that there was no significant difference in postoperative complications among the three groups (P > 0.05). There was no significant difference in the incidence of new ischaemic brain injury within 24 h after operation and within 28 days

In contrast, no evidence of fungal colonization and infection was found; and fungus is thought to be an opportunistic pathogen. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the efficacy and safety of 21-day subretinal ranibizumab injections after 11-month intravitreal injections in eyes with choroidal neovascularization secondary to pathologic myopia. Study patients who met criteria for the first time in the previous study will be randomized into 2 groups: control group (intraocular injection of ranibizumab after 1 month) and experimental group (intravitreal injection of ranibizumab after 1 month and 20 injections of ranibizumab subretinal injection after 20 weeks)

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study was to establish the effects of intravitreal ranibizumab injections and its efficacy and safety, and 15 eyes of 15 patients with choroidal neovascularization secondary to pathologic myopia (13 women; 2 men) were enrolled from July 19, 2017 to August 30, 2020. All patients received only a monthly injection of intravitreal ranibizumab. The results of this pilot study showed that there is a tendency for visual acuity to improve regardless of treatment with ranibizumab, but that improvement in visual acuity is more significant in the group that received more frequent intravitreal injections. This study was designed to assess the efficacy and adverse effects of intravitreal ranibizumab for choroidal neovascularization secondary to pathologic myopia by comparing the two groups. We are conducting a prospective randomized controlled trial of 12 patients with unilateral choroidal neovascularization associated with pathologic myopia who met the clinical inclusion and exclusion criteria during a 16-month observation period from December 19, 2018 to December 17, 2019.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with severe burns may have delayed healing and are prone to serious complications due to the loss of the skin barrier and the release of pro-inflammatory mediators and cellular stress responses associated with burn injuries. Recent studies found that topical allantoin administration can suppress cellular stress responses and promote re-epithelization in skin cell injury models. Moreover, topical allantoin significantly enhanced wound healing and survival rate in burned pigs. However, the current evidence is limited to animal models and the clinical evidence of allantoin's benefit as an agent for treating burn injuries remains unclear. Thus, this study aims to evaluate the clinical efficacy and potential mechanism of action of topical allantoin treatment in patients with severe burn injuries. The researchers will conduct a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial to investigate the wound healing effects of allantoin gel administration in patients with severe burns and will explore the underlying molecular mechanisms involved. The clinical trial will involve two intervention arms: allantoin gel and placebo gel. Patients in the allantoin group will be instructed to apply the allantoin gel to the burn area (one hour before and after grafting) until the 15th day after grafting. The placebo group will receive the placebo gel treatment in the same way. The investigators will monitor the progress of wound healing by taking clinical photographs and assessing the changes in wound size and the degree of re-epithelialization at regular intervals. The investigators will compare clinical parameters, including body temperature and hemoglobin, to evaluate the clinical efficacy of allantoin gel. In addition, the researchers will investigate the molecular mechanisms of burn wound healing, including the expression of stress response markers (SOD, CAT, and GPx) and inflammatory mediators (IL-6, iNOS, and PGE2). Blood samples will be collected to measure the levels of stress response markers and inflammatory mediators. Moreover, the researchers will assess the expression of stress response markers and inflammatory mediators in wound biopsy samples. The clinical trial will enroll 42 patients with severe burns, which is a sufficient sample size to detect significant differences

Assessment: Primary outcome: pain intensity using a numerical rating scale (NRS) Secondary outcomes: opioid consumption, respiratory compliance, functional status, and adverse events

Time Frame: Participants will be observed for 7 days


Interventions: 1) Ultrasound-guided continuous serratus anterior plane block: Participants will receive ultrasound-guided continuous serratus anterior plane block using a catheter inserted under the rib cage. Local anesthetics will be administered through the catheter continuously for up to 7 days. 2) Dexmedetomidine infusion: Participants will receive a continuous infusion of dexmedetomidine through a peripheral intravenous line for up to 7 days. 

Data Collection: We'll collect data on pain intensity using a numerical rating scale (NRS), opioid consumption, respiratory compliance, functional status, and adverse events

Target Sample Size: We aim to enroll 100 participants (50 in each group)

As I mentioned earlier, the serratus anterior plane block with levobupivacaine is a relatively new technique that has not been studied extensively in patients with multiple rib fractures. We believe that this approach might be effective in reducing postoperative pain and opioid use, and the addition of the fentanyl infusion in Group F would provide an additional benefit for pain management.

The second study arm is the SAP block plus dexmedetomidine infusion group. In this arm, patients will receive an ultrasound-guided SAP block followed by a continuous infusion of dexmedetomidine at a rate of 0.2 mcg/kg/hr for the first 24 hours. This arm is designated as Group SD.

This arm is necessary to compare its effectiveness to the first study arm. Dexmedetomidine has been shown to provide effective pain control in patients with multiple rib fractures, and its use is well-established in the field of pain management. By comparing this intervention to the first study arm, we can determine the optimal pain control strategy for these patients.

Abstract:
Background: Perioperative hypoxia, defined as oxygen supplement <85%, is common in obese patients undergoing sedation endoscopy. High‐flow nasal cannula (HFNC) and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) can be used interchangeably during general anesthesia. We hypothesized that compared to HFNC, CPAP would improve oxygenation and reduce the frequency of desaturations in obese high‐risk patients undergoing sedation endoscopy. Patients and Methods: A multicenter, randomized, unblinded clinical trial was carried out on adult and obese high‐risk patients (ASA class ≥3 and/or BMI ≥30 kg/m²) scheduled for elective gastrointestinal endoscopy with deep sedation. The interventions included two devices: a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine (SuperNO2VA™ Et, Vyaire Medical, Haguenau, France) and a nasal oxygen cannula. The primary outcome, the frequency of desaturations, was compared to the standard procedure of using nasal oxygen cannula. The secondary outcomes were the number of apneas per hour and oxygen supplement requirements. Results: Thirty patients were included and randomized to a group using CPAP (n = 15) or nasal oxygen (n = 15). There were no significant differences between groups in terms of oxygen supplement requirements (CPAP 36.1%; nasal oxygen 41.5%; p = 0.684), the number of apneas per hour (CPAP 10.31 ± 37.29; nasal oxygen 82.28 ± 135.71; p = 0.645), or the frequency of desaturations (CPAP 0.07 ± 0.48; nasal oxygen 0.31 ± 0.60; p = 0.253). No adverse effects were noted. Conclusion: During sedation endoscopy, the use of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) did not help improve oxygenation and did not reduce the frequency

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the safety of RAD301 ([68Ga]-Trivehexin) in healthy volunteers and patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The secondary objective of this study is to assess the effect of RAD301 on the distribution of immune-cell subsets in the tumor microenvironment and the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of RAD301 in patients with PDAC.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a First-in-human, two-part, phase Ib, open-label, dose-escalation clinical study of RAD301 administered to patients with advanced and/or metastatic, previously treated PDAC in the United States and Canada. The study will be conducted in two parts: Part A (screening and treatment) and Part B (scanning and blood collection) over a total of approximately 15 weeks. The study will enroll at a single site a total of 26 evaluable subjects: 3 dose escalation and 8 dose de-escalation subjects in the first part and, if applicable, 8 dose expansion subjects based on safety, pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) data in Part A and confirmation of data trend line from Part A after a minimum of 5 evaluable subjects in Part B.

Abstract:
Trial Description: The purpose of this study is to develop and validate diagnostic criteria for patients with primary hyperoxaluria (PH). The investigators will accomplish this by assessing the accuracy of the diagnostic criteria. Specifically, the investigators plan to perform a cross‐sectional study of PH patients through a centralized laboratory and a clinical team of metabolic‐genetic experts. The investigators hypothesize that the currently available diagnostic criteria are poorly performing because the diagnostic criteria are limited to two tests each of which has high sensitivity, but at the expense of low specificity. In addition, the current criteria are insufficiently able to differentiate between the four forms of PH: PH types 1, 2, 3, and 4. The four forms of PH are differentially treated and have varying phenotypes, and these differences are clinically important. By contrast, the investigators propose a new, streamlined panel of assays that have a high negative predictive value for PH and can therefore reduce the number of unnecessary kidney biopsies that are currently performed to confirm the diagnosis: liver magnesium chelation (LMC) and urnine glyoxylate levels. Together with a new criterion for genetic confirmation, the investigators will evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of these diagnostic criteria. The investigators will recruit 1000 patients with oxalate stones that have been confirmed by LMC or kidney biopsy and 300 subjects undergoing screening evaluation for oxalate urolithiasis that have normal liver function. The investigators will compare test results from these patients to published criteria to evaluate and validate LMC cutoffs and to evaluate the combination of these novel diagnostic criteria with conventional tests to improve the current diagnostic criteria. By performing this research project, the investigators will better understand PH, which would facilitate early interventions with a goal of preventing end‐stage kidney disease. Study Population: There is a strong belief that PH is underdiagnosed due to underutilization of the currently used diagnostic criteria. This is due to the fact that these tests have high sensitivities but poor specificities. Study Overview
-----------------
Brief Summary
-----------------
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is one of the most prevalent types of kidney cancer in adults. Around 63,000 cases are diagnosed every year, and approximately 13,500 patients die from the disease in the US alone. There are a few standard therapies for metastatic renal cancer, including surgery, immunotherapy, and targeted therapy. However, most patients suffer from recurrent diseases, and no standard of care remains effective for all patients. Metastatic disease is heterogeneous, and the treatment landscape is complex. Although recent advances in immunotherapy have improved outcomes for patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma, it is imperative to evaluate and monitor the response to therapy. Early identification of patients who will benefit from these therapies is critical. Circulating exosomes are potential biomarkers that can provide such information and help physicians to make informed treatment decisions. However, their biological significance and clinical utility remain unknown. Therefore, this study aims to investigate the role of circulating exosomes in predicting treatment response in patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors or combination therapy. Abstract:
AIM: To determine the effects of prenatal vitamin D supplementation on postpartum depression (PPD).BACKGROUND: The current data examining the relationship between PPD and 25‐hydroxyvitamin D (25(OH)D) are conflicting.METHODS: We conducted a secondary analysis on 419 pregnant women in Iran's Kurdistan area, who underwent prenatal screening (PS). A single‐dose (50000 IU at 24 weeks) and a 3‐month course (6000 IU per day from 22 weeks to 34 weeks) of vitamin D supplementation were applied only to the participants with PS deficiency.RESULTS: We observed the following differences 3 months after delivery: in the singleton subgroup, 40% of postpartum women without supplementation developed PPD compared to 22% with one‐time supplementation and 19% with a course (p < 0.05). The multiple logistic regression model with prenatal care, type of pregnancy, mode of delivery, gestational age, birth weight, number of births, and postpartum complications as confounders revealed that women with PPD were twice as likely to not take folic acid supplements compared to women without PPD in the course group (adjusted odds ratio: 2.39; 95% confidence interval: 1.09‐5.24; p = 0.029).CONCLUSION: The prenatal course of vitamin D supplementation has a potential protective effect against PPD in singleton women.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to investigate the efficacy of the Empowered Relief (ER) caregiver and child pain management program on pain outcomes in pediatric acute pain episodes. The current study will compare participant pain outcomes in acute pain episodes between a treatment arm and a wait-list control arm.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The goal of this study is to evaluate the feasibility and potential efficacy of psycho-education pain management (ER) caregiver interventions in children hospitalized with acute pain or procedural pain. Children undergoing procedural pain will receive usual care alone (control), while children with acute pain without a procedural component will receive the caregiver intervention which will include psychoeducation, relaxation, meditation, self-hypnosis, and distraction. Children in both groups will return to the clinic the following week for assessment of pain intensity, mood, and behaviors. The aim is to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the ER caregiver intervention in children with acute pain. Pain will be assessed using the child-reported Face Pain Scale-R and mood using the State-Trait Anger Expression Inventory and Pain Catastrophizing Scale short form. Behavioral changes of the child will be assessed using the Child Behavior Checklist short form and clinician ratings of the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale.

Since there are already many studies that have established the accuracy of FFR in assessing the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis, we can use this as the comparison.

Study Overview

Brief Summary

The primary aim of this prospective clinical trial is to determine the safety and efficacy of autologous mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) from bone marrow (BM-MSCs), adipose tissue (AT-MSCs), or both sources in participants with end-stage peripheral artery disease (PAD) who are not suitable for a surgical intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The incidence and prevalence of PAD is high among older people especially for those older than 50 years and older adults (age 65 years and older). In 2012, cardiovascular diseases resulted in 1,223,000 deaths (11.8% of all deaths) . Diabetes is an important risk factor for PAD. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimates that every year 60,000 - 150,000 individuals who have diabetes die from vascular complications, which can include PAD . Currently, vascular bypass surgery or an endovascular approach is the standard of care for patients with PAD. Unfortunately, many patients who have PAD cannot have these surgical procedures due to a high surgical risk or disease progression . Treatment with stem cells is currently FDA-approved for hematologic disorders, but is investigational for many other diseases including PAD . Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) could potentially be used to promote new blood vessel growth through the process of neovascularization.

Pilot Study of Autologous Mesenchymal Stem Cells for PAD Unsuitable for Vascular Intervention

groundtruth: Since your study is focused on evaluating the accuracy of a new diagnostic test, I would recommend classifying it as a Phase II study. This phase typically involves testing the efficacy and safety of new interventions or techniques.

For participant inclusion, you could consider stable angina pectoris, unstable angina pectoris, or individuals who have passed the acute phase of myocardial infarction. The age requirement should be set at 18 years or older, and written informed consent is essential. Additionally, participants should have intermediate coronary lesions with diameter stenosis ranging from 30% to 80% as estimated by visual examination from coronary angiography.

Participants should be excluded if they are ineligible for diagnostic IVUS or FFR examination, have undergone prior coronary artery bypass grafting of the interrogated vessels, experienced myocardial infarction within 72 hours of coronary angiography, or have severe heart failure. Serum creatinine levels greater than 150 umol/L or glomerular filtration rates below 45 ml/kg/1.73 m2 should also be considered exclusions. Furthermore, individuals with allergies to the contrast agent or adenosine, life expectancy of less than 2 years, IVUS pullback that does not cover the entire lesion, or severe myocardial bridge in the interrogated vessel should be excluded from the study.

Based on the information you provided, I suggest having two study arms. The first arm will focus on pressure wire-based fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the participant group. The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic test: fractional flow reserve (FFR). This arm is necessary as FFR is a well-established standard reference for assessing the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis. By using pressure wire-based FFR as a comparison, we can evaluate the accuracy of the new diagnostic test, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR).

The second study arm should involve participants who will undergo intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)-based ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR). The intervention/treatment for this arm should be the diagnostic tests: ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS). This arm is important as it focuses on the new diagnostic test, UFR, which is the main intervention being evaluated in this trial. By combining UFR with IVUS, we aim to assess the functional significance of coronary artery stenosis in a more comprehensive manner. The use of IVUS will provide detailed imaging of the coronary vessels, enhancing the accuracy of UFR calculations.

Definitely! In addition to ECoG, there are two other common interventions used in awake surgery: direct cortical stimulation (DCS) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). 

1. Direct cortical stimulation (DCS): during the surgical procedure, a brief electric current is applied directly to the brain's cortical tissue. This usually results in the temporary disruption of brain function in the stimulated area, providing information about which regions are important for specific functions. 

2. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI): a noninvasive technique that uses magnetic fields and radio waves to measure blood flow in the brain. Faster blood flow to specific areas of the brain suggests that those areas are involved in a specific function. 

Both DCS and fMRI can be useful interventions in awake surgery, and they have been shown to reduce the risk of neurological deficits in patients who undergo surgery to remove brain tumors. 

If you are still interested in using ECoG as the primary intervention, it is important to note that awake surgery under ECoG monitoring with titrated sedation is the least invasive method. This personalized approach harnesses the patient's immune system to target and eliminate cancer cells.

OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the performance of the MOS‐VAS‐Dx in assessing visual outcome after glaucoma filtration surgery.DESIGN: A prospective non‐randomized study.PATIENTS AND METHODS: Eyes with a primary diagnosis of primary open‐angle glaucoma (n = 37) with planned visually guided glaucoma filtration surgery were recruited. The rationale is to use both plasma ctDNA and FFPE blocks to identify molecular features that can predict drug response in the adjuvant setting. 

The rationale for the collection of the samples before surgery is to ensure that they are collected during a critical period in the tumor, with potentially high EGFR expression levels prior to treatment. 

4 to 8 weeks after surgery was chosen to account for the required interval after surgery for wound healing, and before starting osimertinib, to minimize the chance of acquiring resistance-conferring mutations during treatment initiation. 

Every 6 months was chosen as a reasonable time frame for regularly checking patient follow-up and EGFR status. 

If the study finds that EGFR-driven resistance occurs in a specific subset of patients upon relapse, plasma ctDNA will be tested to identify whether there are differences in the mutations between the plasma and the FFPE tissue in these patients. 

The rationale for the early relapse sampling is to investigate whether there are EGFR-driven resistant mutations in plasma ctDNA prior to tissue biopsy. 

The rationale for the late relapse sampling is to assess whether there are late recurrences due to additional mechanisms of EGFR-independent resistance.

Abstract:
Background: The prognosis of non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients in the adjuvant setting is highly variable, making identifying patients at increased risk of recurrence crucial for tailoring treatment strategies and improving outcomes. Despite advances in genomic profiling, there is still a need for more sensitive and specific biomarkers to better predict the risk of recurrence and guide treatment decisions. Circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) has emerged as a promising biomarker for NSCLC, and its detection in the plasma of patients with EGFR mutations has been associated with a worse prognosis. However, the clinical utility of ctDNA as a prognostic marker in the adjuvant setting of NSCLC is unknown. In this study, we performed a nested case‐control study to investigate the prognostic value of ctDNA in the adjuvant setting of completely resected pIB‐IIIA non‐small cell lung cancer with common EGFRmutations. Methods: We randomly selected 100 patients from the GeparNRG‐JACCARO Adjuvant Lung Cancer Trial (ALTTO trial) who underwent complete resection for pIB‐IIIA non‐small cell lung cancer with common EGFR mutations (Del19 or L858R). The 100 patients were randomly divided into a case group (n = 25) and a control group (n = 75). Blood samples were collected at baseline and at 6 months after surgery. ctDNA was extracted from plasma and analyzed using a digital droplet PCR (ddPCR) assay for EGFR mutations. The primary outcome was progression‐free survival (PFS). Results: The median follow‐up duration was 42.7 months. In the case group, 29 patients (116%)progressed on/after adjuvant erlotinib compared to 29 patients (38.7%) in the control group (hazard ratio [HR] = 0.28, 95% CI = 0.12‐0.68, P <.001). Firstly, the participants in this arm will provide valuable data on molecular prognostic factors and resistance mechanisms to osimertinib in the adjuvant treatment of completely resected pIB-IIIA NSCLC with common EGFR mutations. Brief summary
=================
In many countries worldwide, most healthcare service users are managed by healthcare practitioners (HCPs) who are neither trained in psychology or mental health nursing, nor do they have access to regular mental health specialists. In such settings, such as primary care clinic or child care institutions, there are few tools readily available for family caregivers to seek help from. In recent years, an increasing emphasis has been placed on mental health as an important contributor to disability, including cognitive decline, depressive symptoms and lower quality of life (Peskind & Potter, 2020; Peskind, Potter, & Schuster, 2020). Many children with visual impairments display a higher level of mental distress compared to those with normal vision  and this is likely be related to increased anxiety and depression (Obeid & Stothard, 2019). Therefore, supporting primary caregivers' mental health could in turn contribute to the enhancement of overall quality of life for these young children and their caregivers. 
This study has an applied research design, focusing on the intervention development for caregivers of children with visual impairments aged 0-6 years. Participants will go through a five-week web-based intervention involving interactive sessions with a Registered Practical Nurse. The objectives of this intervention is to enhance caregivers' mental health and well-being. Caregivers will be trained to utilize the tools learned to practice self-care and effectively navigate through challenges arising from caring for children with visual impairments. Furthermore, the outcomes will be measured to examine the effectiveness of the intervention in improving the mental health and well-being of primary caregivers of children with visual impairments.

Intervention Description:: Participants will complete one of four baseline periods that will end with the administration of a treatment protocol. The duration of the intervention protocol is designed to align with each participant's baseline duration. Participants were assigned to a baseline duration based on the length of their musical phrase that was used to assess state anxiety levels. A randomized, within-subjects study design will be used to collect state anxiety and momentary audio recordings within a repeated measures design. After the baseline period is completed, the participants will be subjected to their assigned musical phrase and state anxiety levels will assessed every two minutes for up to 25 minutes. The number of minutes for baseline is randomized and corresponds to the length of each participant's musical phrase. The phrases were chosen as it was the length of musical phrase that the participants used during self-reporting (i.e., using a scale from 1 to 10) to track their state anxiety levels. Participants assigned to 10 minutes of baseline were instructed to use a musical phrase of 10 measures and had no intervention protocol assigned as this was below their assigned baseline. Participants assigned to 12 minutes of baseline were instructed to use a musical phrase of 12 measures and had no intervention protocol assigned. The intervention protocols will be administered for participants assigned 14 or 16 minutes of baseline. Participants assigned to the 14-minute baseline will be instructed to use a musical phrase of 14 measures and listen to a combination of spoken word recordings, music and poetry samples for 25 minutes. For the 16-minute baseline, participants will be instructed to use a musical phrase of 16 measures. An intervention protocol will not be administered to participants with 16 minutes of baseline anxiety.

Abstract:
Background: Extracranial‐intracranial (ECIC) bypass is the mainstay of treatment in internal carotid stenosis (ICS). While the effect of intensive antiplatelet therapy (IPT) with ticagrelor and/or aspirin remains unclear in patients with ECIC bypass, the safety and efficacy of long‐term dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) in patients with ECIC bypass after intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is unknown. This study aimed to assess the optimal timing of IPT cessation after ECIC bypass following ICH. Methods: This was a retrospective, data‐linkage study using the National Health Insurance Research Database of Taiwan. We screened 158 patients with ICH and ECIC bypass from 2003 to 2015. Subsequent IPT after ICH and ICS was classified based on the 2017 European Stroke Organization (ESO) guidelines. ICH volume and the functional prognosis were evaluated. Results: Of the 158 patients, 36 were treated with DAPT after ECIC bypass. The mean duration of DAPT ranged from six weeks to four weeks. The most common reason for DAPT cessation was scheduled surgery. The mean ICH volume was significantly lower in the DAPT group than in the anticoagulant group. ICH volumes were comparable between the six‐week DAPT group and the four‐week DAPT group (P = 0.757). Moreover, the six‐week DAPT group showed better functional prognosis and higher rates of ICH and ICS recurrences than the other groups (P = 0.031 and P = 0.041). Conclusions: Our findings suggest that the optimal duration of DAPT in patients with ICH and ECIC bypass remains uncertain and may need to be individualized based on factors such as ICT recurrences and risk of stroke recurrences.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating disease that affects the quality of life of patients with it, and is often caused by uncontrolled hypertension, the most common cause of mortality worldwide. 70% of ICH patients have hypertensive hemorrhage, and the incidence of ICH also increases with age. In addition, studies have shown that there is a close relationship between blood fibrinogen (FIB) and ICH, and abnormal changes in plasma FIB level are associated with the severity of ICH. FIB is a marker of myocardial injury, thrombotic myocardial infarction and atherosclerosis. In some studies of ischemic stroke and myocardial infarction, FIB levels are related to the degree of injury and prognosis, and in the process of spontaneous fibrinolysis, fibrinogen increases first and then decreases, and fibrinogen deficiency is a predictor of a bad prognosis after stroke. When fibrinogen increases or decreases significantly, the prognosis of patients is affected. Therefore, the mechanism of abnormal plasma FIB in ICH patients is still unclear. This study focuses on the mechanism of pathophysiological increase of plasma FIB in ICH patients, the effects of intravenous fibrinogen reduction on the pathophysiological process of ICH and the improvement of the prognosis of ICH patients, and to assess the value of fibrinogen reduction as a new prognostic target for ICH. The traditional way of artificial intelligence training has been transformed from "large data" to "little data". However, the application of these methods to the field of molecules will bring unimaginable data challenges. Abstract:
INTRODUCTION: A significant proportion of patients with immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) are refractory to standard glucocorticoid therapy and often require second‐line treatments to achieve a remission. Therapies that can safely address the causes of a patient's ITP refractory to glucocorticoids are needed. A clinical trial is currently underway in which patients with refractory ITP will receive CM313 injection, an antibody that depletes abnormal B cells.METHODS AND RESULTS: This interventional, blinded (double‐blind, placebo‐controlled), multi‐center clinical trial of an anti‐CD38 antibody (CM313 injection) aims to recruit patients with primary ITP who have received previous glucocorticoid therapy and then failed such therapy. The primary objective will be to assess CM313 injections for the treatment of immune thrombocytopenia. Efficacy will be assessed by platelet count (measured in milligrams per deciliter of fluid; mg/dL) on day 28 and day 56 of treatment. Secondary objectives include safety assessments and evaluating the use of CM313 antibody therapy to promote an ongoing platelet response. The investigators plan to enroll up to 42 patients in the study and anticipate a total of 4‐8 treatment cycles, depending on the response to treatment. The study is expected to enroll 5‐10 new patients every month throughout 2022 and 2023.CONCLUSION: The CM313 injection clinical trial offers a potential treatment option for patients with refractory immune thrombocytopenia who have failed glucocorticoid therapy, and it will likely be completed in 2023.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) is a technique that provides qualitative and quantitative information on a wide range of materials and is a technique that has been developed to study cancer and other diseases. Our study evaluates the feasibility of using hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and imaging software to image breast lesions and predict which ones are benign and which are cancerous. The system used is the 109-channel hyperspectral camera system developed by the team at the Nanjing University of Science and Technology. This is a feasibility study based on a single center. A total of 260 patients will be recruited in three phases to collect images: the first 50 are to determine the detection parameters used in the imaging system; the next 150 patients are to train the imaging system to establish the accuracy of disease prediction; and the final 60 patients are to validate the performance of the imaging system (verification model).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) is based on the idea of using a wide band of wavelengths to obtain information about the optical properties of material, such as molecule size and refractive index, to form an image, which provides quantitative and classification information on a wide range of materials and is an emerging imaging technology of practicality. Our study evaluates the feasibility of using imaging systems and related imaging software to classify breast health and disease status. This study is a prospective multicenter single-arm study based on a single center. A total of 250 patients will be enrolled and divided into three consecutive phases: the first 50 are used to determine the detection parameters used in the imaging system; the next 150 patients are used to train the imaging system to establish the accuracy of disease prediction; and the final 60 patients are used to validate the performance of the imaging system (verification model). Patient groups The patients recruited in the study had undergone routine preoperative screening as part of their routine care and underwent a complete preoperative physical examination. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A study to asses safety and efficacy of PuraCath® in pediatric catheterization of congenital heart diseases.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, paired, multicenter observational study. Two sets of catheterization procedures in 26 pediatric patients will be performed: with (intervention) and without (control) PuraCath. The study will be conducted at a minimum of four pediatric hospitals from three countries. Patients will be divided into two cohorts each, one for right-side cardiac catheterization (femoral approach) and the other for left-side (radial approach). If 26 patients cannot be found in the population of each institution, more patients will be recruited from the other study centers. In each center (up to 6 interventions), a consecutive sampling will be used and no interim analysis will be performed. All interventions will be performed by at least two different operators. The use of other devices by the operator is not recommended during both procedures (intervention/control). The safety of the procedure will be assessed during the intervention at the time of cannulation and before removal. If pain occurs at any moment prior to cannulation, pain management will be performed by the physician as usual. At the end of the procedure, the patients will report if they felt any pain during the intervention. At the discharge visit, both patients and parents/guardian will assess the pain intensity felt during the procedure, and the pain relief after hemostasis.

PuraCath® in Paediatric Cardiac Catheterization

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to establish whether there is a difference in the efficacy and safety of the combination of intravenous low-dose hydrocortisone and dexmedetomidine on post-concussion symptoms among the concussed patients in the early treatment compared with standard therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Dexamethasone (Dex) is approved for severe head injury, which may be caused by trauma or stroke. Concussion is a mild brain injury caused by trauma, which is milder than stroke. Concussion commonly presents as headache, memory loss, dizziness, and reduced consciousness after head injury. Post-concussion syndrome (PCS) is a set of symptoms that often occur one to several weeks after concussion and last for weeks or even months. The symptoms cause considerable loss of productivity and economic burden for the individual and the society. In recent years, a clinical guideline recommends that low-dose dexamethasone (0.1-0.5 mg/kg) is widely used to treat PCS, and the efficacy should be evaluated in randomized controlled studies. The main adverse reaction of dex is postural hypotension, which may lead to a decline of blood pressure, cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP), and cerebral blood flow (CBF). Previous studies have shown that exogenous administration of corticosteroid can relieve inflammatory responses of brain injury, increase the expression of heat shock protein 72 (HSP72), and enhance the neurocognitive function. However, its effect on PCS is unclear. This study aimed to establish whether combining low-dose hydrocortisone (Hydro) (1 mg/kg/d) and dex is beneficial for treating PCS after mild traumatic brain injury (TBI). The investigators hypothesized that administering low-dose Hydro combined with dex in the early treatment of post-TBI improved clinical outcomes, CPP and CBF, and reduced biomarkers levels of systemic and CNS inflammation and intracranial pressure in patients with concussion.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The prognostic relevance of chronic kidney disease (CKD) on outcome of pancreas transplantation (PT) remains controversial, especially in recipients of all‐kidney pancreas transplantation or living‐donor transplantation. Our study was aimed to examine the effect of pancreas and kidney transplantation (PKT) in patients with CKD G3‐4 on long‐term clinical outcomes.METHODS: A total of 212 consecutive patients who underwent simultaneous or sequential pancreas and kidney transplantation between May of 2008 and July of 2021 were included. We analyzed patients with non‐diabetic kidney (NDKD), diabetic kidney (DKD) and diabetes‐independent kidney disease (DIKD) and the incidence of major renal adverse events (MAKE) and metabolic adverse events (METAKE).RESULTS: Twenty‐two patients (n = 22, 10.4%) had NDKD, 128 (n = 128, 60.3%) had DKD, and 62 (n = 62, 29.2%) had DIKD. There were no differences in patient survival or graft survival. NDKD patients had a higher incidence of pre‐transplant diabetic retinopathy and hepatitis C virus infection. Post‐transplant, DIKD patients had a greater rate of graft failure, cardiovascular complication, METAKE, and MAKE. Although there was no difference in long‐term graft survival, NDKD patients had a lower rate of pancreas loss than DKD or DIKD patients. DKD patients were more likely to have C‐reactive protein > 10 mg/L on day 1 and day 3 after surgery.CONCLUSION: PT for end‐stage kidney disease patients with a better prognosis is recommended. Patients with NDKD could achieve better insulin sensitivity and lower graft loss than DKD patients. However, patients with DKD had better

Sure, in the endoscopic total adenoidectomy group, patients will undergo an endoscopic total adenoidectomy as part of their standard treatment. At our institution, an endoscopic total adenoidectomy involves using a 4mm telescope to remove all of the adenoid tissue through the mouth. This procedure is performed under general anesthesia and typically takes about 15 to 30 minutes. In the endoscopic partial adenoidectomy group, patients will undergo an endoscopic partial adenoidectomy as part of their standard treatment. This procedure involves removing only a portion of the adenoid tissue, leaving a remnant of adenoid tissue in the nasopharynx. This procedure is performed using the same method as the endoscopic total adenoidectomy but takes about 5 to 10 minutes.

Abstract:
Hospitalized older adults comprise a population vulnerable to malnourishment and undernourishment. This study sought to compare the impact of nutritional interventions in these patients using anthropometric measurements and dietitian‐led recommendations. A secondary analysis of a prospective, randomized control trial comprising patients sixty‐five years and older who were hospitalized and deemed malnourished at four university‐affiliated hospitals was performed. Participants with dementia, those who remained in the hospital for more than five days, and those who were discharged to long‐term care were excluded. The intervention arm received an additional dietitian‐educated, nurse‐administered 5‐day menu of 25‐1,000 extra kcal/day, while the control arm continued usual hospital‐based care. The primary outcome was body mass index (BMI). Nutritional interventions did not significantly improve the median post‐discharge BMI (p=0.751). However, we showed that the intervention provided nutritional interventions early in an older adult's hospitalization course. This intervention may serve as a foundation for further research to evaluate the impact of early nutritional support among hospitalized older adults.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To assess the effectiveness and tolerability of long‐term treatment with the 5‐HT1A partial agonist aripiprazole in inefficient SSRI responders.METHOD: Forty‐six nonpsychotic patients with a clinically significant response to a therapeutic trial of an SSRI for several weeks received flexible doses (5‐25 mg/d) of a single oral dose of aripiprazole. Primary outcome measures included the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression and Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) scores. Secondary outcome measures included global assessments. Patients were assessed in a double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, parallel 8‐week trial followed by an open‐label continuation till week 16.RESULTS: A 32.6% decrease in HAM‐D score and 95% CI compared with baseline score for aripiprazole was observed. However, aripiprazole group values were not significantly different from the values of placebo and patients receiving an augmenting agent. Patients reporting at least one adverse event were 36 for aripiprazole versus 23.1% for placebo (P=.23). The most frequent adverse events were nausea, akathisia, agitation, and vomiting.CONCLUSIONS: The aripiprazole dose used in this trial was not effective in this population. (2004 American College of Neuropsychopharmacology).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This prospective observational study was designed to assess the influence of intra peritoneal instillation (IPI) with a combination of MTX and Cetuximab (Cmab) on the efficacy and safety in the treatment of peritoneal recurrence of colorectal cancer. The study is sponsored by the Beijing Dongzhimen Hospital of Beijing University of Chinese Medicine in Beijing, China, and will be conducted in a phase II, multicentric, single-arm, open-label, non-randomized study design. A total of 20 patients are planned to enroll in Dongzhimen Hospital.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The research objective of this trial is to assess the influence of intra peritoneal instillation (IPI) with a combination of MTX and Cmab on the efficacy and safety in the treatment of peritoneal recurrence of colorectal cancer. The treatment time of each patient is within 15-20 minutes, and the study treatment is repeated once a week. It will also be monitored for clinical efficacy at 1month, 2months, 3months, 4months, 6months, 8months, 10months, 12months and 16months after the first dose of study treatment. The results of this study will be used to provide guidance for the subsequent phase II study.

That sounds like a really interesting study! So, let me ask you what are you trying to evaluate or what are the objectives of your study? 

Abstract:
Background: Mood disorders frequently contribute to treatment‐resistant psychosis, with patients often being burdened by comorbid anxiety and depressive symptoms during episodes and beyond. In this study, we tested the efficacy of cognitive enhancement and acceptance‐based therapy (CEAT; Witt et al., 2014) in patients with recurrent depressive disorder (DD; ICD‐10 F32.0‐39.2) and psychosis with a long‐term history who met diagnostic criteria for psychotic features (PF; Diener, et al., 2020). Methods: The study was a randomized controlled trial. Patients were randomized into a standard clinical condition or standard clinical care plus CEAT. Outcomes were assessed at baseline and at 6 weeks post‐randomization in the German Language Assessment and Treatment in Schizophrenia (GLATESS), including scores for cognitive ability, insight, and quality of life. Results: In 62 patients undergoing a mean length of 26 weeks of CEAT, a significant main effect of CEAT was found across time, with significant improvements in quality of life and in insight into the presence of psychosis, whereas cognitive symptoms remained overall stable over all measurement periods. A significant interaction effect indicated that treatment gains were significant only among patients with psychosis. In patients without psychosis, CEAT was as effective as standard clinical care overall. Finally, a significant main effect for sex showed that women displayed greater improvements in quality of life in the CEAT condition, compared to men. Conclusions: The findings indicate that CEAT can be a valuable adjunct for treatment‐resistant patients, particularly those with psychosis. Overall, a trend towards better outcomes was found for women. In conclusion, we argue that the incorporation of CEAT into evidence‐based clinical care might be a useful adjunct in the treatment of comorbid psychotic disorders.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a protocol designed to treat participants with metastatic, castrate-resistant prostate cancer, who are not candidates for approved therapies or any standard of care.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an open label, single-site, phase 1/2 study evaluating a PSA-directed autologous T cell receptor (TCR) therapy targeting an 8-mer epitope of the prostate specific membrane antigen (PSMA) and a 4-mer domain-specific epitope in the context of a major histocompatibility complex class I type II groove. TmPSMA-02 is a product consisting of autologous CD4+, CD8+ T cells transduced with a lentiviral vector (LV) encoding a PSMA-specific TCR targeting an 8-mer epitope of the prostate specific membrane antigen (PSMA) and a HCMV-derived TCR targeting a 4-mer domain-specific epitope that is present in up to 47% of patients, in the context of a human leukocyte antigen type II groove (HLATII).

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to learn more about a new technique for relieving chronic pain in post-heart transplant patients on long-term immunosuppressant therapy. In this study, patients are randomized to receive either a sham procedure (placebo treatment) or the new technique, which is called transcranial random noxious stimulation (RNS). RNS involves a small, hand-held device that is held lightly against the scalp at the area of chronic pain for ten minutes. Sham treatment is a pretend procedure. The purpose of the sham procedure is to ensure that neither the doctors nor patients know which procedure is being utilized. This is important because research has shown that positive and negative expectations about treatment can influence its effectiveness (a concept called conditioning). The sham treatment is designed so that patients do not detect which treatment they are receiving. To help ensure that patients in both groups have a positive study experience, all patients also receive an educational session about pain management and lifestyle issues. There are 30 study participants for this study.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Heart transplantation has saved thousands of lives in the past 50 years. However, it has caused chronic pain, sleep disruption, fatigue and other symptoms in some patients. These symptoms are often challenging to treat. Although heart transplant recipients are given powerful medications to prevent rejection of the transplanted organ, these medications may worsen these symptoms. Chronic pain that occurs in these patients is multifactorial and poorly understood. In some individuals, it may be related to medication toxicity. In others, it may be caused by post-operative pain that is no longer treated with conventional therapies. An alternative technique to treat chronic pain is to stimulate the brain. This is done using a small hand-held device. This procedure, known as transcranial random noxious stimulation (RNS), is applied to the scalp for 10 minutes per day. In patients undergoing heart transplantation, we hope to determine if this technique helps to reduce chronic pain. We will recruit 15 heart transplant patients who have persistent chronic pain from a variety of causes. All participants will be interviewed and will complete questionnaires before, during

Intervention Description: Connect-Home Plus will be delivered in the skilled nursing facility and via telephone after discharge. It will introduce organizational structure to support delivery of transitional care processes, including the use of electronic health record (EHR) templates, Connect-Home Plus Toolkit, and staff training. The intervention will consist of two steps. In Step 1, SNF nurses, therapists, and social workers will develop a Transition Plan of Care and prepare the patient and caregiver to manage the illness and functional needs. In Step 2, a dementia caregiving specialist will make three calls to the patient's home within 30 days of discharge. The intervention will focus on key care needs such as home safety, symptom management, medication reconciliation, function and activity, and coordination of follow-up medical care.

Absolutely. The experimental arm, labeled as the Intervention arm, aims to test the effectiveness of the Connect-Home Plus program in improving transitional care for patients with Alzheimer's Disease and other dementias and their caregivers. By introducing new organizational structures and processes, we aim to enhance the delivery of transitional care in skilled nursing facilities and after discharge. This arm includes the development of a Transition Plan of Care, preparation of patients and caregivers, and follow-up calls by a dementia caregiving specialist. The intervention focuses on key care needs, such as home safety, symptom management, medication reconciliation, function and activity, and coordination of follow-up medical care. This study arm is crucial to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and impact of the Connect-Home Plus program on patient and caregiver outcomes.

Indeed. The inclusion of structured processes and follow-up support plays a vital role in improving patient outcomes, reducing caregiver burden, and enhancing the overall quality of care during the transition from SNF to home. The two-step intervention approach ensures comprehensive addressing of key care needs, and the use of technology and training tools further enhances transitional care delivery. By evaluating the impact of the Connect-Home Plus program, this study arm will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of tailored transitional care for individuals with Alzheimer's Disease and other dementias.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This 2-cohort, open-label, Phase 3 study is designed to further assess the antitumor activities and safety of 3 dosing regimens of NKT2152 and Sasanlimab (Sas) in combination with Palbociclib (Palbo) in participants with locally advanced or metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) who are treatment naïve or who have demonstrated resistance or intolerance to checkpoint inhibitor (CPI) monotherapy. The 2 cohorts are 1) first-line treatment of ccRCC and 2) second-line treatment of ccRCC.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 3 multicenter study to assess the antitumor activities and safety of NKT2152 and Sasanlimab (Sas) in combination with Palbociclib (Palbo) in participants with locally advanced or metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) who are treatment naïve or who have demonstrated resistance or intolerance to checkpoint inhibitor (CPI) monotherapy. Approximately 79 participants will be randomized 1:1:1 to each of the 3 treatment arms in 8 stages: Arm 1: NKT2152 and combination of Sasanlimab and Palbociclib Arm 2: Sasanlimab and combination of NKT2152 and Palbociclib Arm 3: Palbociclib combined with combination of NKT2152 and Sasanlimab The participants in all arms will receive the study drugs until demonstration of disease progression per immune RECIST 1.1, treatment discontinuation by investigator, any Grade 4 related adverse events, withdrawal of consent or meeting any of the withdrawal criteria specified in the study protocol. Study drug dose reductions or drug holiday may occur if participants are not tolerating the study drugs or have insufficient therapeutic benefit from the study drugs. The primary objective (Primary Endpoint) of the trial is to assess the safety and tolerability of NKT2152, palbociclib and sasanlimab when administered to Participants with locally advanced or unresectable metastatic ccRCC. Abstract:
Introduction: Epidural transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is an accepted method of postoperative pain relief following lower abdominal surgery. The aim of this study was to evaluate whether preoperative pre‐emptive TAP block compared with conventional multimodal analgesia effectively reduces postoperative opioid requirements for analgesia in patients undergoing lower abdominal surgery. Materials and Methods: Thirty American Society of Anesthesiologists I and II patients undergoing lower abdominal surgery were included in the study and randomly divided into two groups: The experimental and control groups. Patients in the experimental group received pre‐emptive bilateral pre‐TAP blocks, and patients in the control group were given conventional multimodal analgesia. Postoperative analgesia was provided by patient‐controlled intravenous administration of fentanyl and acetaminophen. The primary outcome was opioid consumption within 24 hours during the intra and postoperative period, secondary outcomes were the numerical rating scale (NRS) recorded in the postanesthesia care unit (PACU) and 12 hours after surgery and NRS scores for pain intensity and sensory and motor functions at regular intervals for the first 36 hours postoperatively. Analgesia consumption and side effects were also recorded. The results were analyzed using Student's t‐test. Results: The postoperative fentanyl consumption (p<0.007) as well as acetaminophen consumption (p<0.001) 24 hours postoperatively was significantly decreased in the TAP group compared with the control group. The postoperative pain scores 12 hours after surgery were also significantly lower in the TAP group at rest (p=0.001) and during coughing (p=0.001). In addition, the time between arrival at the PACU and the patients' first demand for IV fentanyl injection was significantly higher (p=0.001) in the TAP group. The total

I am pleased to report that the trial has been successfully completed and the results have been published in a reputable medical journal. We found that hamstring stretching alongside conventional therapy resulted in greater improvements in pain and function compared to conventional therapy alone after 12 weeks. We concluded that hamstring stretching is a valuable addition to conventional therapy for the treatment of plantar fasciitis. Overall, the trial was a great success, and we were able to provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of hamstring stretching in the management of this common foot condition.

In the experimental group, we have the "Experimental Group" as the participant group/arm. The intervention/treatment includes hamstring stretching, cold pack application, stretching of plantar fascia, and strengthening of plantar fascia and calf muscles. The hamstring stretching will be the main focus, performed three times a week for two weeks. Each session will last approximately 20 minutes, with a 30-second rest period between stretching repetitions. The goal is to achieve mild discomfort sustained for 30 seconds during each repetition.

The control group consists of the "Control Group" as the participant group/arm. The intervention/treatment for this group involves cold pack application for 7 to 10 minutes, followed by stretching of the plantar fascia through toe stretches and towel scrunches. Additionally, calf muscle stretching will be performed. After stretching exercises, there will be strengthening through towel curls and heel raises. Each exercise will be done for two sets, lasting 30 seconds, and repeated twice a day.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Trial registration: ChiCTR2200069832; Registered 11 July 2022. The incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID‐19) is growing rapidly in China, especially outside of Wuhan now. However, no specific treatment has yet been found for this disease. The current study was designed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of interferon (IFN)‐α2b combined with ribavirin (RBV) therapy in COVID‐19 pneumonia patients in Wuhan, China.METHODS/DESIGN: Eligible patients will be randomly sequenced into an IFN‐α2b + RBV group and a control group at a ratio of 1:1. IFN‐α2b (400,000 U intramuscular injection [IM], once daily for three doses) combined with RBV (400 mg twice per day, orally) for 3 days will be administered to patients in the IFN‐α2b + RBV group. Only RBV (400 mg twice per day, orally) for 3 days will be administered to patients in the control group. The clinical efficacy of the two groups will be compared.DISCUSSION: Previous studies have shown that IFN‐α2b and ribavirin have the potential to be effective drugs in the treatment of COVID‐19 patients with mild symptoms. This study aims to further evaluate the efficacy of the combined therapy in treating patients with mild symptoms of COVID‐19.TRIAL REGISTRATION: ChiCTR2200069832; Registered 11 July 2022.

Introduction
Coronavirus disease (COVID-19), caused by coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2), is a global pandemic. 
 This virus, which causes an acute respiratory disease, first appeared in December 2019 in the city of Wuhan, Hubei province, China, and quickly spread across the world. It mainly spreads through droplets (by breathing, touching objects or other people), secretions from the nose when coughing or sneezing and close

The settings for flow-controlled ventilation in the Experimental arm are still under evaluation and will be determined based on the patient's respiratory mechanics. 

Study design
=================
Single-center, prospective, randomized study

Description
=================
The study will enroll approximately 70 patients with body mass index between 17 and 36 kg/m2. Patients will be randomly allocated to either the flow-controlled ventilation group or the pressure-controlled ventilation group using a 1:1 allocation ratio. Patents will be randomized at the beginning of the surgery, and the randomization will be performed in a concealed manner using a computer-based random number sequence generator. The study aims to assess whether the use of flow-controlled ventilation during robot-assisted laparoscopic surgery is superior to pressure-controlled ventilation in terms of maintaining carbon dioxide levels and postoperative recovery time. The study will also evaluate the effects of both ventilation approaches on hemodynamics, respiratory mechanics, patient comfort level, and postoperative ventilator settings.

The first study arm could be an active comparator arm, where participants receive Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT). The NRT used will be a combination therapy involving transdermal nicotine patches combined with faster-acting oral products like gum or lozenges. The strength of nicotine patches will range from 7 to 21 mg, and for gum or lozenges, the strength will be 1-4 mg. Participants will use a daily nicotine patch along with ad libitum use of the faster-acting lozenge to manage nicotine cravings. A 12-week supply of NRT will be provided. This arm represents the standard treatment for smoking cessation and allows us to compare the effectiveness of EC against a recognized and proven method.

For the second study arm, we can have an experimental arm where participants are randomized to receive Electronic Cigarettes (EC). Participants in this arm will be provided with an EC starter kit, including a personal vaping device with an integrated battery and three commonly used e-liquid flavors (tobacco, menthol, and fruit) with a nicotine concentration of 18-20 mg/ml. EC will be supplied for a total of 12 weeks. This arm allows us to evaluate the efficacy and safety of EC as a smoking cessation tool compared to NRT, and also assess the cost-effectiveness of using EC compared to NRT in the Pakistani population.

Abstract:
Background: The COVID‐19 pandemic has presented novel challenges in airway management for children. Video laryngoscopy (VL) has been proposed because of the anticipated decrease in oropharyngeal secretions and better glottic view. This study was designed to assess the feasibility of VL in children aged 0‐36 months in routine anaesthetic practice. Methods: A prospective, observational study was performed on a single centre with a two‐group design. During a 4‐month period, a total of 600 children underwent routine general anaesthesia for elective surgery. Anaesthesia was induced with VL in 300 children (VG) and with direct laryngoscopy in a straight blade (DB) in the other 300 children (DG). The primary objective was the glottic view after the second intubation attempt. The secondary objectives were the rate of successful VL, the view grade, the time to successful endotracheal intubation and overall success rate, adverse events and number of attempts with each laryngoscopic technique. Results: The median age in VG (35 months) and DG (40 months) groups were comparable (P = 0.610). The percentage of successful VL on the first attempt was significantly higher in VG (88%) than DG (72%) (P < 0.001). The overall success rate in the VG and DG groups was 100% and 99.7%, respectively. The overall success rate in the first three attempts was higher in the VG group. The glottic view on the second attempt was significantly better in the VG group (2.6 vs 1.0, P < 0.001). A more favourable glottic view for both groups decreased the odds of repeated attempts at laryngoscopy. The number of laryngoscopic trials before successful intubation was lower in the VG group

Abstract:
Background: The purpose of the study was to analyse the effects of different preoperative exercise intensities on functional recovery of patients undergoing major surgery. Methods: A total of 86 patients undergoing major urethral surgery (retropubic prostatectomy) were included in the study and distributed into four groups: rest, low and moderate intensities of physical exercise. The following clinical variables were assessed: age, Body Mass Index (BMI), American Society of Anaesthesiologists (ASA I‐II), functional exercise capacity (VO2max), postoperative recovery ‐ time to first flatus, time to oral food intake, time to hospital discharge, time to convalescence and hospital stay. Results: Patients of group 1, 2 and 4 did not differ for any variable analyzed. However, the group 3 (moderate‐intensity physical exercise) showed a negative correlation between VO2max, time to first flatus and time to hospital discharge when compared to the group 1 (rest). There were no differences in postoperative recovery ‐ time to food intake, time to convalescence and hospital stay. In a multivariable regression analysis, time to food and hospital discharge were associated with lower VO2max (‐4.02 and ‐3.82, respectively, p<0.05). Conclusion: Low and moderate exercise intensity did not improve postoperative recovery parameters of patients undergoing major urethral surgery. Further studies are necessary to determine whether exercise intervention with higher intensities positively impacts the postoperative recovery process.

[ANSWER] The primary outcome is based on the HADS score pre- and post-intervention. The HADS is a validated short screening questionnaire to quantify the presence of anxiety and depressive symptoms. The questionnaire consists of two sub-scales (depression, anxiety), with each item scored from 0 to 3, and a total score range from 0 to 21. A score of 8 or higher indicates clinical relevance.
