Study hypothesis
=================
Background: There is a high prevalence of insulin resistance and pre-diabetes in patients with liver diseases in general and those related to viral causes. On the other hand, metformin has multiple mechanisms of action, some of which directly affect the liver. The aim of this study is to assess the effect of metformin in patients with chronic hepatitis C. Methods: Patients diagnosed with type 2 diabetes or glucose intolerance and patients with chronic hepatitis C (CHC) who do not present advanced liver disease, not on anti-viral therapy (NAF) and with fasting plasma glucose ≤ 200 mg/dl will be recruited. Patients will be randomly allocated to the two groups; the control group (group A) will receive NAF therapy only and treatment with metformin will be left according to clinical criteria. The experimental group will receive the same therapy as the control group but plus treatment with metformin. In both groups, metabolic parameters will be evaluated at baseline and in each visit, and changes in insulin resistance will be evaluated with the homeostatic model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMA-IR). A biopsy of the liver will be performed at the beginning and at six months, in order to find changes in the fibrosis score (Ishak fibrosis score). All patients will undergo three-dimensional ultrasound at the beginning and at the end of the study to assess possible alterations in the amount of fat, volume and echogenicity, and to follow up on the change of hepatic function (FibroScan®). Results from the experimental group will be compared with those of the control group to assess the effectiveness of metformin for the treatment of metabolic abnormalities and its effect on liver fibrosis. Larger studies are needed to confirm these results.

Abstract:
The presence of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is associated with a higher risk of recurrence in patients with endometrial cancer. This work aims to analyze the predictive value of ctDNA for recurrence and survival.
Introduction: Circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) is a cell‐free DNA present in the blood that originates from tumor cells.1 In recent decades, the detection of ctDNA through plasma analysis has increasingly been of interest in several types of cancer.2 CtDNA detection is becoming an important predictive and prognostic factor in breast cancer,3 colon cancer, and lung cancer. It has also been shown that the presence of ctDNA is associated with a higher risk of recurrence in patients with endometrial cancer.
This work aims to analyze the predictive value of ctDNA for recurrence and survival. It is a prospective matched-cases study. This project has received funding from the “French Agency for Cancer Research".
Study design: This prospective matched-cases, non-interventional study is co-led by INSERM, Université Côte d’Azur, and Groupe

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Intrauterine insemination (IUI) is a common assisted reproductive technologies (ART) procedure for couples with unexplained infertility. This study will help in identifying the factors that contribute to successful outcomes in patients undergoing IUI through a post-wash total motile sperm count (TMSC) over 5x10^5 .

Detailed Description
-----------------
Although intrauterine insemination (IUI) is a common treatment for infertile couples, the success rate is still modest. To improve the success rate of IUI, it is important to identify factors that are associated with positive outcomes. One of the most important factors is the post-wash total motile sperm count (TMSC). Previous studies have shown that there may be a link between the post-wash TMSC and the success rate of IUI. However, these studies have had limited sample sizes and have not been conducted in a randomized controlled setting. In the current study, we aim to investigate the relationship between the post-wash TMSC and the success rate of IUI. We will recruit 120 infertile couples who will undergo IUI using fresh semen in our hospital. The couples will be divided into two groups based on the post-wash TMSC: Group 1 (high-quality sperm) will have a post-wash TMSC of ≥ 5 million/ml, and Group 2 (low-quality sperm) will have a post-wash TMSC of < 5 million/ml. All couples who do not undergo any other treatment or use any other assisted reproductive technologies (ART). All couples will be monitored until they achieve pregnancy or until they have been trying for 12 months without success. The primary outcome measure will be the clinical pregnancy rate at 8 weeks of gestation. The secondary outcome measures will be the implantation rate

Infertility is a common problem that affects one in six couples. Intrauterine insemination (IUI) is a fertility treatment that involves the transfer of sperm directly into the uterus to increase the chances of fertilization and pregnancy.
Study Arm 2: Fresh Sperm Injection Patients undergoing fresh sperm injection. The intervention/treatment is the transfer of fresh sperm, which is directly inserted into the cervix or uterus.

The 3 x 10^6 cut-off value is considered a threshold value for clinically good semen quality. We expect to see higher pregnancy rates in Intrauterine insemination patients with post-wash TMSC >3 x 10^6, which will be evaluated against the control group.

Description

Aim of the study The study aims to assess the predictive abilities of semen quality (motility, concentration, morphology, sperm DNA fragmentation and biochemical) and endocrinological parameters in patients with low total motile sperm count (TMSC). Study methodology Semen analysis results of all patients referred for semen analysis in the reproductive medicine unit of Isfahan Reproductive Sciences Research Center who met the indications for intrauterine insemination (IUI), based on the International WHO 2010 criteria, will be studied and the study population will be divided into two groups: those with sperm motility above and below 3 x 106 TMSC. In both groups, pregnancy rate and other pregnancy factors will be examined (biochemical tests, endocrinological parameters and sperm DNA fragmentation) in order to determine the factors that affect pregnancy outcomes. Samples are collected with the help of the patient. In order to control any possible bias during the research, no hormonal or andrological treatments will be performed for the patients during participation in the study. All information in the questionnaire for the endocrine profile, biochemical tests, sperm DNA fragmentation analysis and the results will be recorded in electronic files and kept for up to 25 years, based on the law of Iran. The researchers are responsible for obtaining approval from the ethics committee of Isfahan Reproductive Sciences Research Center. In this study, statistical tests such as chi-square and logistic regression were used to determine the relationship between different variables and pregnancy outcomes. The software SPSS version 20 will be used for statistical analysis according to the test method.

Evaluation of the Predictive Role of Semen Quality, Endocrinology and Biochemistry in Low Sperm Counts: A Prospective,

groundtruth: Study Arm 1: Intrauterine insemination Patients undergoing intrauterine insemination. The intervention/treatment is the standard procedure of intrauterine insemination, which involves the transfer of sperm into the fallopian tube through a specialized cannula.

This study arm serves as the control group for comparing the pregnancy rates based on post-wash total motile sperm count. By having a standard procedure group, we can accurately assess the impact of post-wash TMSC on the success of intrauterine insemination.
Study Arm 2: Intrauterine insemination Patients with post-wash TMSC >3 x 10^6. The intervention/treatment is the same standard procedure as the control group.

This study arm is designed to evaluate the pregnancy rates of patients with a post-wash total motile sperm count above the recommended threshold of 3 x 10^6. By including this group, we can determine if there is a significant difference in pregnancy rates compared to the control group, thus validating the recommended threshold value for post-wash TMSC.
Study Arm 3: Intrauterine insemination Patients with post-wash TMSC <3 x 10^6. The intervention/treatment is the same standard procedure as the control group.

This study arm is essential to assess the pregnancy rates of patients with a post-wash total motile sperm count below the recommended threshold of 3 x 10^6. By including this group, we can determine if there is a significant difference in pregnancy rates compared to the control group and the group with post-wash TMSC above the threshold. This arm will help determine the impact of lower post-wash TMSC on the success of intrauterine insemination.

Abstract:
This study compares the clinical outcomes in knee joint preserved arthroplasty with the conventional total hip arthroplasty in patients with severe avascular necrosis of the hip treated with the acetabular cup of 1‐13 mm of anteversion. We retrospectively examined 85 patients. Among them, 36 patients received a 1‐13 mm of anteversion primary total hip arthroplasty with a cemented prosthesis (group A), which have been reported as the indicators to prevent avascular necrosis, and 49 patients received a 15‐27 mm of anteversion primary THA with a cemented prosthesis (group B). The postoperative Harris Hip Scores for both groups were 79.5±9.7 and 78.9±11.9, respectively. There were no significant differences in all outcome variables at all follow‐ups. No dislocations were detected in group A, but 3 dislocations were detected in group B (6.1%). In group A, no periprosthetic fractures were detected after the surgery, but in 3 patients in group B, 1 periprosthetic fracture was seen in the femur, 1 in the greater trochanter, and 1 in the femoral neck during the follow‐up period. No acetabular radiolucent lines were noted in group A, while 3 cases of radiolucent lines were seen in group B. The prosthetic survival rate in group A was 100%, but the rate of the prosthetic survival in group B was 90.9%. However, no statistical significant difference of clinical results was detected between group A and group B regardless of age and gender. In both groups, postoperative Harris Hip Scores were satisfactory with good function. The postoperative results in group A were no inferior than those in group B.

In this interventional, phase 2 randomized controlled trial, patients with hip fracture will be randomized in a standardized, unbiased allocation to either a control group (CG), followed by a conventional rehabilitation treatment, or an experimental group (EG), followed by Robot-Assisted Gait Training (RAGT). The aim of the trial is to detect whether the RAGT influences the 6MWT distance (6 minutes walking test), the Timed up and Go time (TUG) and the Berg Balance Test (BBS) after two weeks of rehabilitation.
The study follows the SPIRIT guidelines.
Randomization process
=================
Randomization will be performed centrally after patient inclusion by means of computer-based random block assignment, using block permutations of random size to achieve a study population with a balanced number of group A and B patients.

The primary outcome after two weeks of in-hospital rehabilitation is the improvement of gait ability after two weeks of standardized rehabilitation treatment with and without additional Robot-Assisted Gait Training in patients who have suffered from an acute hip fracture and, therefore, require in-hospital rehabilitation.
The primary outcome is the 6 Minute Walking Test (6MWT), measured using the “6-minute walk test measuring protocol”

Abstract:
Background: Prostate cancer (PCa) is one of the most commonly diagnosed tumors and the second most frequent cause of male cancer‐related death worldwide. The standard treatment for localized PCa is surgical management with radical prostatectomy or radiotherapy. Despite the efficacy of treatment, relapses and local and/or distant recurrences still represent a problem for most patients. In this regard, new diagnostic modalities could contribute to improving patients' survival and life expectancy. The purpose of this observational study is to evaluate the diagnostic value of choline positron emission computed tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) as a diagnostic test for metastatic PCa. Methods and results: This study is a retrospective review based on medical records of a tertiary center with more than 1328 patients affected by PCa. Medical records of a total of 85 PCa patients who underwent choline 11 C PET/CT examination between 2020 and 2021 were included. Overall, 56 patients had pathological lesions (group 1) and 29 had a negative scan at the time (group 2). Results: The mean interval from the date of surgery and/or radiotherapy was 5.87 years (range 0.9‐15.4 years). Overall, 22 patients (26.1%) had relapses of disease (6 non‐castrated and 16 castrated). The median PSA level at time of exam was 4.6 ng/mL (range 0.12‐24.12 ng/mL), and among the patients affected by biochemical recurrence, the median PSA value was 4.6 ng/mL (range 0.1‐14.5 ng/mL). Overall, a total of 17 patients (20.0%) had a positive scan, which showed 4 positive bone metastases, 2 positive lymph nodes, and 5 positive lymph nodes with bone involvement. In terms of interventions, for the experimental arm, stopping sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) early after identifying a favorable EEG pattern is our primary intervention. Study type
=================
Interventional

Study design
=================
Parallel

Description
=================
In this study, we aim to evaluate the feasibility and safety of early weaning from ICU treatment in patients with a favourable EEG pattern after successful targeted temperature management (TTM). We will conduct a prospective, randomized, controlled pilot study involving 29 patients hospitalized in the intensive care unit (ICU) after a successful cardiac arrest.
We will randomly assign patients into 2 groups: the experimental arm and the control arm.
The experimental arm will consist of 15 patients who will receive early weaning from sedation and TTM within 12 hours after the initiation of targeted temperature management (TTM). The intervention in the experimental arm will involve the cessation of sedative medications as soon as the patient is stable and has a favourable EEG pattern. The temperature will be decreased to a target temperature of 34°C for 24 hours. Neuroimaging studies (computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)) will be performed to assess the neurological status of the patient, and if the neuroimaging results are within acceptable ranges, the patient will be allowed to wean off sedation and TTM within 12 hours. The experimental intervention will end when the patient is fully weaned off sedation and TTM. We expect the duration of ICU stay to be about a week.
The control arm will consist of 14 patients who will receive standard care as per the American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guidelines for the management of comatose patients. The intervention in the control arm will involve the cessation of sedative medications as soon as the patient is stable and has a favourable EEG pattern.

I'm glad you agree. Now, let's summarize the full study arms we've designed:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Early cessation of sedation and TTM
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm includes patients who will undergo early cessation of sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) after a cardiac arrest with a favorable EEG pattern.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The intervention involves stopping sedation and TTM early, within 12 hours of identifying a favorable EEG pattern, and potentially weaning from mechanical ventilation if appropriate.
   - Reasoning: This arm is essential to assess the feasibility and safety of early weaning from ICU treatment in patients with a favorable EEG pattern. By comparing outcomes in this group to the standard care group, the study can determine if early cessation of sedation and TTM is a viable option for these patients.

2. No Intervention: Standard Care
   - Participant Group/Arm: This arm consists of patients who will receive standard care, including sedation and targeted temperature management (TTM) for at least 24-48 hours post-cardiac arrest.
   - Intervention/Treatment: The control group will not undergo early cessation of sedation and TTM, as per standard care protocols.
   - Reasoning: This arm serves as a comparison group to evaluate the impact of early cessation of sedation and TTM in the experimental group. By having a control group receiving standard care, the study can determine if the experimental intervention leads to better outcomes compared to the standard approach. This arm helps establish the baseline for comparison and provides valuable insights into the potential benefits of early weaning from ICU treatment.

-----------------
The goal of this study is to reduce the impact of skin cancer by improving early detection, especially in high-risk populations. People with a history of melanoma are at an elevated risk of developing new non-melanoma or melanoma skin cancers in the future. This is partly due to the lack of awareness and knowledge among patients about skin cancer risks and prevention. Furthermore, as a result of pandemic, patients are reluctant to visit doctors for a skin examination. The impact of the lockdown and a low number of dermatology consultations could have adverse long-term health effects on dermatology patients. It may also increase the number of melanomas and non-melanoma skin cancers discovered at advanced stages when their treatment is typically more costly and less curable. The study uses an innovative approach in clinical research to combine the benefits of in-person clinical care and teledermatology consultations. Patients at higher risk of developing skin cancer will attend either a virtual or in-person appointment with a dermatologist or nurse. Participants will be assigned to one of the three research groups in this study to better analyze the impact of virtual consultations on the management of high-risk patients. The research groups are: A group of patients undergoing routine follow-up visits with a dermatologist will continue to receive standard clinical care during their appointment. B group of patients who attend a virtual consultation with a dermatologist or nurse practitioner during the appointment, which will be followed by an in-person skin examination. C group of patients who attend an in-person consultation with a dermatologist or nurse practitioner during the appointment. The group that participates in virtual consultations, as well as the group that attends a face-to-face telehealth consultation, will continue to receive standard care from their dermatologist or nurse practitioner.

Interventional

Exclude criteria
=================
Individuals meeting any of the following criteria will be excluded from our study: those with a disease that might interfere with periodontal diagnosis or treatment, pregnant or lactating women, individuals with a history of allergic reactions to dental materials, and those receiving any medications that can affect the periodontium.

Primary Outcome
=================
The primary outcome is to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a selected panel of biomarkers in saliva as a predictor of periodontitis in healthy volunteers. 

Secondary Outcome
=================
The secondary outcomes are to evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of the diagnostic test for periodontitis in individuals with gingivitis, treated periodontitis, periodontitis Stages I and II, and periodontitis Stages III and IV. 

Abstract/Background
=================
Periodontitis is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by the destruction of the periodontium, which may eventually lead to tooth loss. Despite the availability of treatments for periodontitis, early detection and intervention are crucial to prevent the progression of the disease. 

Salivary biomarkers are substances present in saliva that can be used as indicators of periodontal disease. These biomarkers can be assessed using diagnostic tests, which have the potential to detect periodontal disease at an early stage. 

The current study aims to investigate the diagnostic accuracy of a selected panel of biomarkers in saliva as a predictor of periodontitis in healthy volunteers. Our hypothesis is that the diagnostic test can accurately predict the presence of periodontitis in healthy subjects and provide early detection and intervention. 

We plan to enroll a total of 60 subjects, divided into 6 groups: periodontally healthy, gingivitis, treated periodontitis (stable and unstable), periodontitis Stages I and II, and periodontitis Stages III and IV. Each group will undergo the diagnostic test for salivary biomarkers, and the results will be

For the gingivitis group, the intervention will be the application of a chlorhexidine mouthwash for a month. The biomarker test will be repeated to see if the levels of periodontal disease-related biomarkers in saliva have changed.

The treated periodontitis group will be a source of insight for us. We'll analyze their salivary biomarker levels to assess if there are any differences between the baseline levels and the post-treatment levels. This would allow us to evaluate the effect of periodontal treatment on the biomarkers.

The periodontitis Stages I & II group may not require any additional intervention or treatment, as their condition is relatively early and can be managed with good oral hygiene and routine professional cleaning. However, we may consider including them in the study to help us assess the predictive ability of salivary biomarkers in different stages of periodontal disease.

BACKGROUND: N‐methyl‐D‐aspartate (NMDA) receptor‐dependent mechanisms can potentially be involved in acupuncture‐induced neuroplasticity and pain‐relieving effects following needle stimulation. Evidences indicated that NMDA receptor activity could be regulated by local endocannabinoids (eCBs) endogenously released during needling. This study aimed to explore the possible neurobiological mechanisms by which endocannabinoids released during acupuncture at two different target sites (Acu and Lung‐10, LU10) modulate pain by modulating the brain's activity via NMDA receptors.METHODS: Twenty‐two healthy participants underwent an electroacupuncture stimulation (EA) session involving either LU10 (the control stimulation point, n = 11) or Acu (the target stimulation point, n = 11) for 30 minutes on one day, and the experimental condition was switched to the opposing condition the next day to explore the possible neurobiological mechanisms, followed by a transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) experiment. To explore the role of the cannabinoid system in acupuncture‐induced neuroplasticity, 10 mg of oral amisulpride was given to block cannabinoid receptors in all participants, and the outcome was compared with those from placebo drug (dexchlorpheniramine maleate, D‐CPMA) groups.RESULTS: TMS results showed increased short‐interval intracortical inhibition (SICI) induced by LU10 stimulation, but significant decreases in SICI and short‐interval intracortical facilitation (SICF) were observed to be induced after the Acu stimulation regardless of the drug administration. Furthermore, the alteration of SICF induced by needle stimulation at Acu site was blocked by the administration of amisulpride.CON

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Prostate cancer is one of the most prevalent and deadly cancers in men worldwide. It accounts for more than 1.1 million new cases and nearly 308,000 deaths each year, and prognosis remains poor in advanced disease stages. Although several therapies have shown great efficacy in treating prostate cancer, there is still a need for new therapeutic approaches to better manage its treatment. A subpopulation of aggressive prostate cancers harboring DNA damage response deficiencies (DDR) is emerging as an attractive therapeutic target. Tumors with DDR deficiencies are sensitive to platinum-based therapies (e.g. cisplatin), but the majority of patients develop drug resistance. Intratumoral heterogeneity is the main cause of drug resistance and may be exacerbated if tumors acquire DDR deficiencies. To counter this resistance, we propose that dual targeting of DDR pathways using a combination therapy that includes cisplatin will provide higher survival. In order for this combination therapy to be successful and minimize off-target effects, it is necessary to determine which DDR genes are most involved in the pathogenesis of prostate cancer and to understand their effects when targeted. Using a combination of genome-wide CRISPR screens and high-throughput single-cell transcriptomics analysis, our preliminary data suggested that multiple DDR-related genes (e.g. BRCA2, RAD51C, and MRE11A) are involved in the development of prostate cancer (PC). Here, we hypothesize that inhibiting these genes will be more effective in prolonging survival in PC. To validate our findings on an individual basis, we will use a panel of patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) and patient-derived organoid (PDO) models that recapitulate the tumor's heterogeneity. This combination will allow us to assess the therapeutic efficacy of cisplatin in combination with drugs targeting specific DDR genes in models that better reflect the patient's tumor heterogeneity. We will also determine how the combination of cisplatin and specific DDR gene inhibitors changes the response of PC to chemotherapy by measuring changes in various cellular features,

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In this project, we plan to use a new technology that would allow us to measure the levels of two proteins in saliva (alpha-amylase and IL-1beta) that we believe could aid in diagnosing pancreatic cancer at an early stage.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is the fourth common cause of cancer death. It is projected that 55,440 people will have been diagnosed with new cases of pancreatic cancer and 44,330 individuals will have died from the disease in 2019. It is one of the most difficult cancers to detect until it has reached an advanced state. At that point, fewer than 20% of patients survive 5 years, and even for those, there is often intolerable disease progression. If it is possible to diagnose pancreatic cancer in its pre-symptomatic phase or even in its early, yet asymptomatic phase, it is possible that pancreatic cancer could be treated with organ-preserving treatments, such as chemotherapy or radiation therapy. We have recently found in our laboratory that changes in salivary amylase could be used to diagnose pancreatic cancer at this early stage (15-20 days before the onset of the first pancreatic cancer symptoms). Moreover, in our laboratory we have also found that there are changes in the levels of certain proteins in other types of cancer, including colon and breast cancer, as well as in certain benign cancer mimickers, in the days and months before the onset of the first symptoms of cancer. We have developed a technology that uses a biochemical chip in conjunction with a microarray reader that allows us to measure the levels of two proteins in saliva, Alpha-amylase and IL-1beta. We propose to use this technology to measure these two proteins in saliva samples collected from patients who are being evaluated for possible pancreatic cancer. We hope that the data obtained from this project will lead to the development of a rapid, non-invasive, low-cost diagnostic test for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, that will be available within months of first symptoms. Abstract:
Objective To evaluate the effect of atropine eye drops on tear production during cyclophosphamide‐induced dry eye. Design A prospective, randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial. Methods Twenty‐seven patients with systemic sclerosis were enrolled. They were randomized to receive a daily dose of either atropine eye drops (1%) or a placebo for five days. We measured tear meniscus height, the tear break‐up time and the total and lipid‐loving tear secretion before and on days 3 and 5 of cyclophosphamide‐induced dry eye. Results Compared with the placebo, atropine eye drops significantly elevated the tear meniscus height and the total and lipid‐loving tear secretion. However, atropine significantly shortened the tear break‐up time. The average changes in meniscus height, tear break‐up time and tear secretion between treatment groups were small, and the 95% confidence interval of the difference between the treatments is large. Conclusions Atropine‐induced miosis can increase tear meniscus height and tear production, although it can also worsen subjective ocular discomfort. Further studies will be needed to determine whether the use of atropine improves subjective symptoms.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Current research on the treatment of food allergies has focused on food-specific IgE-mediated allergies. However, many studies have found that food-specific IgG4-mediated allergies are more significant than expected. In addition, patients with food-specific IgG4-induced allergic disorders often do not respond to traditional food-specific IgE elimination diets. However, research on food-specific IgG4-mediated allergies is limited, and it is unclear whether food-specific IgG4 can be used as a new marker of food allergy. This study aims to verify the effect of food-specific IgG4-targeted elimination diets on allergic symptoms and to identify factors that can be used as indicators for disease-specific elimination diets. Moreover, this study will provide basic data on the use of food-specific IgG4-guided elimination diet therapies for various diseases.

Abstract:
Background: Surgical intervention for primary open‐angle glaucoma (POAG) is the mainstay of treatment when it no longer controls patients, and the purpose of in‐depth exploration and control of risk factors is to improve its prognosis. This study explored the clinical application of 3‐dimensional (3D) intraoperative fluorescence angiography (FA) as a risk factor in the early stage of POAG after surgery. Method: A total of 166 cases of POAG undergoing trabeculectomy combined with anterior chamber depth‐controlling glaucoma drainage valve implantation were randomly divided into an observation group and a control group. The observation group used intraoperative FA to further explore the blood supply of the anterior ciliary artery (ACA) preoperatively, and at 1, 3, 6, 12 months after operation, and at 2 years follow‐up. The control group used FA to observe the blood supply of the ACA preoperatively. The two‐factor variance was compared from 1 month to 2 years of follow‐up. Results: After observation, the fluorescein angiography image intensity of the left eye in the control group 3 months after operation, the intensity of posterior iris vessels of the right eye and superotemporal iris vessels and posterior iris vessels of the left eye after operation in the observation group were more obvious, and the intensity difference was 61.32 ± 11.79, which was statistically significant (p < 0.05). Conclusion: Using FA to further evaluate the angle position of patients with glaucoma is beneficial to the operation, and for patients who have used FA, there is more information that is not observed in fundus imaging and fundus fluorescein angiography, which is of great diagnostic significance.

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo controlled study is to determine whether adjuvant oral chemoprevention treatment with PF-06252613 is effective in reducing the proportion of colorectal adenomas over 3 years in participants with a history of colorectal adenomas.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Subjects with a history of colorectal adenomas will receive oral dose of 800 mg PF-06252613 or matching placebo once daily for 36 months. Experimental: Subject glucometer measurement
   - Participant Group/Arm: Male or female patients with hypo-, eu- or hyperglycemia who have signed the written informed consent and are older than 18 years.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic test using different blood glucose monitoring systems (BGM) and a reference method to measure blood glucose concentration.
   - Explanation of the intervention: The subject glucometer measurement involves the use of different blood glucose monitoring systems (BGM) to measure blood glucose concentration and compare the results with a reference method. The blood glucose monitoring systems are devices that use a small drop of blood to measure the glucose levels in the blood. 
   - Endpoints/Measurement(s): The primary endpoint is the system accuracy of the blood glucose monitoring systems in comparison to a reference method. The system accuracy is assessed by comparing the results obtained from the different blood glucose monitoring systems with the results obtained from the reference method.
   - Duration of the intervention: One measurement per subject.

Control: Reference method measurement
   - Participant Group/Arm: Same participants as the Experimental arm.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Diagnostic test using a reference method to measure blood glucose concentration.
   - Explanation of the intervention: The reference method is a standardized method used to measure blood glucose concentration. It is considered the gold standard in blood glucose measurement and is used as a comparison method to evaluate the performance of the blood glucose monitoring systems.
   - Endpoints/Measurement(s): The primary endpoint is the system accuracy of the blood glucose monitoring systems in comparison to a reference method. The system accuracy is assessed by comparing the results obtained from the different blood glucose monitoring systems with the results obtained from the reference method.

That's a valid point. Having a separate group of participants for the control arm would indeed be ideal to eliminate any potential bias. However, in this particular study, we are focusing on evaluating the system accuracy of the blood glucose monitoring systems within the same group of participants. This allows us to directly compare the performance of the systems in real-world conditions. If we were to use a separate group for the control arm, there could be variations in individual physiology and glucose levels that would introduce confounding factors. By using the same participants, we can minimize these variables and ensure a more accurate assessment of the system accuracy.

Description
=================
In the knee, a combination of several different disorders can coexist, making treatment more complicated. In addition to osteoarthritis, more pathologies can be found such as ligament injuries, articular cartilage damage or defects, and periarticular tendon problems. Current treatment for these disorders focuses on symptom relief. A conservative approach is often not curative, but may increase the complaints over the years, because the (involved) structures do not heal as a result of the treatment. Treatment with growth factors in combination with stem cells has shown good results in several pathologies, and the current trend is that in addition to cartilage therapy, the use of PRP should be expanded to a large group of common complaints. The goal of this study is to study the effect of Platelet Rich Plasma (PRP) injection, followed by additional mesenchymal stem cell(MSC-MIPF) injection in case of persistent problems, on knee complaints. In this study, patients who have knee complaints due to several pathologies will be treated with PRP (platelet rich plasma) and mesenchymal stem cells (MSC-MIPF) if necessary.

## Abstract

We assessed the efficacy of a tailored text messaging health intervention to improve the diet and lipid profile in adolescents. The study population was formed by 123 adolescents selected from 743 eligible patients from three pediatric outpatient clinics. They were randomly divided using a random‐number table into two groups: 1) take a break (TAK group) and 2) the experimental group, which received the TAK intervention and regular follow‐up. The study period was 8 weeks. For patients receiving the intervention, a self‐help interactive booklet was used. The main outcomes were the percentage of adolescents with adequate nutrient intake and dietary patterns (KIDMED; Mediterranean diet score) and lipid profile. We found no significant improvement in the TAK group compared with the control group. The TAK group performed better in the KIDMED and Mediterranean diet scores than the control group. Introduction
Dietary education in adolescents is important to prevent unhealthy dietary patterns and their consequences. The Mediterranean diet is associated with several clinical benefits, including the maintenance of healthy body weight, as well as reduced risk of developing diseases such as cardiovascular disease, obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, metabolic syndrome, neuropsychiatric diseases, and some types of cancer . These benefits are attributed to the dietary approach of the traditional Mediterranean diet (TMD), which includes a high consumption of plant foods, such as fruits, vegetables, legumes, olives, nuts, and whole grains. These foods are rich in antioxidants and other substances with functional benefits. On the other hand, the TMD has a moderate to high consumption of fish and seafood, poultry, and eggs. These foods supply essential minerals and high-quality animal protein.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Smoking rates among rural communities are approximately double that of urban communities. To better understand how smoking is tied to poverty, lack of social support, and low employment, the investigators hypothesize that the relationship between mental illness and smoking will be more closely tied to negative financial circumstances than positive social relationships in the context of living in low-resourced environments. The investigators will determine the role of each of these circumstances in smoking initiation and maintenance. To test this, they are going to perform a randomized community intervention trial in the rural community of Dixon, California using community paramedics and other service provider as interventionists. The community paramedicine model has been used successfully to improve health outcomes and health literacy in rural communities. The investigators are adding a novel component to the existing program by randomizing participants to either a standard intervention (standardized assessment/evaluation followed by counseling and referral) or a standard intervention + additional behavioral health and social support interventions (a behavioral economist-based intervention tailored to the specific challenges facing participants in the Dixon community. This intervention will include providing participants with rewards to provide a strong incentive to quit and improve financial outcomes; increasing social support by linking these participants with job placement and resources for improved employment. The investigators will use the Take a Break (TAB) mobile health intervention as a motivational tool. This novel tool will be used to increase motivation for positive behavior changes in response to financial rewards by increasing self-awareness of negative behaviors that are financially costly and to build social support by connecting rural smokers with peers for support and rewarding healthy behaviors. The investigators will test whether this intervention will lead to a reduction in smoking in Dixon. The investigators will assess the impact of the interventions on short-term and long-term smoking cessation as well as other risk behaviors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Many rural communities in the United States lack access to primary and specialty care. The consequences of this are dire and well-documented. Individuals in rural communities tend to have higher rates of smoking, cardiovascular disease, mental health disorders, and death than their urban counterparts. To make this worse, communities with higher poverty rates have less resources to support residents who are ill. One such resource is community param

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the relationship between gait and spasticity in spinal cord injury patients. To investigate the relationship between spasticity and daily life difficulty and changes in the gait pattern.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The aim of this study is to investigate the relationship between spasticity and gait in spinocerebellar ataxia. The investigators will investigate whether the walking stability is associated with plantar flexor spasticity of the ankle. They will measure the electromyography (EMG) of the bilateral soleus and gastrocnemius muscles during walking. They will then measure the ankle joint torque when a voluntary torque is applied to the ankle. These tasks will assess spasticity, which is defined as the excessive resistance to passive stretching of a muscle by hyperactive stretch reflexes. Ataxia is assessed by the timed up and go test and the Berg Balance Scale, which are commonly used assessments of balance. The investigators will then administer a questionnaire on walking disability to assess the relationship between walking disability and the ankle plantar flexor spasticity, as well as the amount of joint torque. Finally, the changes in plantar flexor spasticity of ankle during walking are examined using a step-by-step gait analysis technique. In order to carry out these analyses, the investigators will take a step-by-step gait measurement with the participant wearing a pair of shoes that do not allow movement during walking. During the exercise, the participants will be asked to walk at a comfortable pace while maintaining good body balance.

Official Title

The Relationship Between Spasticity and Gait in Subjects With Spinal Cord Injury

By providing patients with the standard treatment of inhaled glucocorticoids (pulmicort inhaler), we can assess the additional benefits of the incentive spirometer program on asthma during pregnancy.

Study Arm 2 will be the experimental group. It will also consist of 30 patients. In addition to the drug pulmicort inhaler, this group will receive the incentive spirometer treatment. By including the incentive spirometer treatment, we aim to evaluate the additional impact of this intervention on asthma management in pregnant women. The incentive spirometer program will be provided 3 days per week for six weeks. This structured and consistent intervention period will allow us to assess its effectiveness. We will also educate the patients about the benefits of the incentive spirometer to improve compliance and understanding of the treatment.

1. Introductory Notes
1.1. Medical Need
Diabetic cardiomyopathy is a heart muscle disease characterized by heart failure and reduced ejection fraction. It is often associated with diabetes mellitus (DM) and can contribute to significant morbidity and mortality. Effective treatment is critical for improving the prognosis and quality of life for those with this condition. In addition, diabetic cardiomyopathy is a common reason for hospitalization and increases the overall burden on healthcare systems. Therefore, designing a clinical trial to investigate safe and effective treatments for diabetic cardiomyopathy is of great medical need.
The treatment of diabetic cardiomyopathy often involves a combination of lifestyle modifications, pharmacological interventions, and, in some cases, surgical procedures. 
(Table present) Lifestyle modification, such as weight loss, regular exercise, and a healthy diet, is important for reducing the risk of heart failure and improving cardiovascular health. Pharmacological treatment strategies for diabetic cardiomyopathy include the use of medications that can help to improve blood sugar levels, such as insulin and metformin. Surgical procedures, such as coronary artery bypass grafting, left ventricular assist devices, and heart transplantation, may be considered in severe cases. 
(Table present)
However, there is a need for more effective and safe treatments for diabetic cardiomyopathy, and research into new therapeutic strategies and interventions is ongoing. Clinical trials play a critical role in evaluating the safety and effectiveness of new therapies and ensuring that they meet the standards for regulatory approval and widespread adoption.

Abstract:
The impact of high‐efficiency particle air (HEPA) filter use by parents and young children on respiratory illness has not been studied in settings such as in high‐rise apartments. The objective of this study was to compare respiratory health indicators between young children of parents who use HEPA filtration systems in their residences to those of children whose parents do not use such systems. A randomized controlled trial (RCT) study was conducted from November 1999 to June 2001 in 96 residential apartments in Hanoi, Vietnam. Of these, 45 were provided with an electro‐mechanical HEPA filter (HEPA) and 51 received no intervention (Control). All children enrolled in the RCT (n = 232) were exposed to filter or control air 24 h per day. Respiratory health indicators investigated included respiratory symptoms, nasal secretions, and pulmonary function. We found no statistically significant differences between the HEPA and Control groups in the incidence rates of cough, cold‐associated symptoms, or wheeze, or in the levels of nasal secretion. There was also no significant difference in pulmonary function between participants in the HEPA and Control groups. In conclusion, home filtration of air in high‐rise apartments in a tropical environment did not prevent respiratory illness in young children in a controlled environment. The results suggest that the benefit of HEPA filtration for children should be reconsidered.IMPLICATIONS FOR PRACTICE: Home filter systems have been recommended as a preventive measure against respiratory illness for many years, and their use is increasing in high‐rise apartment buildings in East Asia's megacities. However, the few studies showing their efficacy had limitations regarding their study design and methods, as well as in the definition of the target population and study duration. Moreover, little is known regarding the benefit of HEPA filtration for children. The present randomized controlled trail (RCT) was conducted with a large sample size from 96 high‐rise apartments in Hanoi

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to compare the effect of minocycline and achlorhydromethylene blue as adjunctive treatments in a periodontal laser therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be carried out in two groups: The first group will consist of patients who will receive a combined treatment, that is, minocycline and photodisinfection (PDD). The second group will be treated with a placebo for minocycline and photodisinfection (PDD). The clinical parameters and samples will be collected before the laser treatment and at one month after it. Blood samples will be collected to determine the levels of proinflammatory cytokines and other proteins associated with inflammation and periodontal destruction (IL-1β, TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8, CCL-20 and osteocalcin).

Study Summary
=================
Background: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects about 10-15% population and can accelerate cardiovascular disease progression. Despite this, CKD patients have long-term poor follow-up and management of cardiovascular disease with many patients not reaching target treatment. The current study will develop and pilot an intensive, structured cardiovascular disease management program for CKD patients to optimize management of blood pressure, lipid, and glycemic control targeting 10-year CKD patients (eGFR >60 ml/min) with cardiovascular disease. Methods and design: The REDCAPS study (REnal disease Cardiovascular prevention Adjunct for Patients with stable hemodialysis) involves a 12-month prospective randomized controlled trial (RCT) for CKD patients receiving dialysis at The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center (UTSW). Participants will be randomized to either an intervention group (IG) that will receive additional assistance for medication compliance, cardiovascular monitoring, education, and other aspects of cardiovascular health, or the control group (CG) that will receive usual care. The primary outcomes of interest will include the proportion of participants meeting each of the target cardiovascular medications and targets. Secondary outcomes of interest will evaluate cardiovascular disease outcomes including death, hospitalization, new coronary disease, myocardial infarction, cardiac failure, stroke, or coronary revascularization. Discussion: The REDCAPS trial aims to evaluate the impact of an intensive cardiovascular management program on medication adherence and other established clinical cardiovascular outcomes in CKD patients. Successful completion of this short-term RCT will enable development of a protocol for a larger randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing CKD management with cardiovascular care to usual care alone.

Official Title
-----------------
Renal Disease Cardiovascular prevention Adjunct for Patients With Hemodialysis Trial

Conditions
-----------------
End-stage Renal Disease, Cardiovascular Risk Factors, Renal Disease, Diabetes Mellitus, Type II, Cardiovascular Diseases, Chronic Kidney Disease

Abstract:
To investigate the impact of a Vitamin Energy Shot on resting energy expenditure (REE) in young and middle‐aged adults. To compare the energy expenditure of caffeine and amino acids provided by a commercially available Vitamin Energy Shot with those provided by caffeine and amino acids provided by dietary supplements. 1 Methods Seventy adult subjects completed all 4 experimental conditions (Vitamin Energy Shot, Placebo Shot, Placebo Capsule, Placebo Drink; n = 6 per condition) in a randomized, crossover study. Data was collected at baseline and 30, 60, 90, and 180 minutes after consumption in each treatment condition. REE (kcal/day, measured in kcal/min) was estimated from indirect calorimetry measurements during the final 20 min of each 30 minute testing period in the laboratory (Freedom® ® Body Composition Analysis, Cosmed). 2 Results Dietary supplements containing caffeine with or without amino acids stimulated REE in a manner similar to the Vitamin Energy Shot. The total amount of metabolized energy in kcal following consumption of the Vitamin Energy Shot was 171 ± 32, which is slightly lower (p < 0.02) than the 188 ± 20 kcal following consumption of the caffeine‐only supplement. REE was significantly increased from baseline immediately following consumption, with effects peaking at 60 minutes, before gradually returning to baseline levels by 120 minutes. 3 Conclusion The energy expenditure of a typical Vitamin Energy Shot is comparable to the energy expenditure produced by other dietary supplements containing caffeine and amino acids, indicating that the energy expenditure does not depend on the delivery mechanism. REE can be elevated for 60 minutes after consumption of a Vitamin Energy Shot, providing a significant thermogenic effect.

Intervention
=================
SIB-Time is a web-application platform that promotes the behavioral health of typically developing children through an avatar-based intervention (Bell, 2020). The intervention consists of a series of animated videos, personal coaching and education, and social integration and engagement activities. The intervention is based on a comprehensive ecological approach that addresses the needs of the whole family to improve the sibling interaction and relationship, and provide a holistic solution to optimize the behavioral health of typically developing children with a sibling with a disability. The intervention will be delivered online through a web-application platform, which provides a personalized and interactive experience for the child and their parents/caregivers. The intervention program will consist of two modules: the SIB-Time Program and the SIB-Time Toolbox. The SIB-Time Program is a set of educational videos and guided activities for parents/caregivers to teach their typically developing children about the challenges and strengths of their siblings with disabilities. The SIB-Time Toolbox is a set of interactive games and activities for typically developing children to learn about their siblings' disabilities and develop social-emotional skills. The intervention will be delivered over eight weeks, with each module consisting of four weeks of content. Parents/caregivers will receive a link to the web-application platform, which will allow them to access the intervention program at their convenience. They will also receive weekly emails reminding them to participate in the intervention program. The content of the intervention program will be delivered in a progressive manner, with each module building upon the skills learned in the previous module. The intervention program will emphasize the importance of understanding and accepting their sibling's disability, and provide tools and strategies for parents/caregivers to help their typically developing children develop a positive attitude towards their siblings with disabilities. The intervention program will also provide opportunities for parents/caregivers to interact with other families of children with disabilities, to promote social support and connection. Intervention Description

Liver transplant patients who develop non-anastomotic strictures are difficult to treat. Surgery-associated inflammation, as well as an unavoidable rise of rejection medication, both impede tissue healing and encourage progressive fibrosis in patients with biliary strictures. With the development of endoscopy, balloon dilation and biliary stents have become important techniques for treating biliary strictures. They are minimally invasive, cause minimal trauma to the tract, and are capable of relieving jaundice. A randomized controlled study in Taiwan, which focused on biliary strictures not related to liver transplantation, found that more than 90 percent of strictures were manageable with ERCP, with 84.8 percent needing only balloon dilation and 13.7 percent requiring stenting. ERCP is safe and effective for the treatment of non-anastomotic biliary strictures in patients who have undergone liver transplantation. However

In Part A - Escalation, we will enroll patients who have either not received systemic therapy for advanced NSCLC or have received at least one line of systemic anticancer therapy for metastatic disease. This arm will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab. We will start with a small number of patients and gradually escalate the dose of Tepotinib to evaluate any potential adverse effects and determine the optimal dosing regimen.

This arm aims to evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab in a larger group of patients. By targeting patients with specific genetic mutations associated with NSCLC, we can assess the potential benefits of this targeted therapy approach in a population that may have limited treatment options.

In Part A - Escalation, patients will receive Tepotinib daily for three weeks. After three weeks, they will be given Pembrolizumab immunotherapy on a 21-day cycle alongside Tepotinib daily. Dose de-escalation of Tepotinib will be performed if necessary, based on the safety and tolerability assessments.

In Part B - Expansion, patients will receive the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab throughout the study. The safety run-in of Tepotinib will be tested in the first cycle, followed by the introduction of Pembrolizumab from cycle 2 onwards. This will allow us to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the combination therapy in a larger group of patients with NSCLC and MET exon 14 skipping mutations.

Effectiveness of the Communication Bridge™ Intervention: A Pilot Study for Individuals With Primary Progressive Aphasia
Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To pilot‐test the effectiveness of the Communication Bridge™ intervention in improving communication deficits in individuals with primary progressive aphasia and in reducing communicative frustration in individuals and their care partners. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: The Communication Bridge™ team consists of an interventionist, a neurologist, and a neuropsychologist. In a randomized, single‐group, single‐ and multi‐case experimental design, participants with primary progressive aphasia received 10 sessions of Communication Bridge™ and were assessed at baseline and post assessment using the Aphasia Quality of Life Scale and the Communicative Behavior Rating Scale for Family Members. RESULTS: We identified 4 participant dyads to participate in the study. Three completed the study, with another pending completion. Preliminary results showed statistically significant and clinically meaningful increases in participants' quality of life and care partners' satisfaction with communication. CONCLUSIONS: Based on preliminary results, this is the first pilot study to find evidence of the efficacy of the Communication Bridge™ communication treatment protocol in improving quality of life in individuals with primary progressive aphasia and reducing communicative frustration in individuals and their care partners. RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE: The Communication Bridge™ intervention is a promising, multi‐component, participation‐focused, dyadic treatment program designed to optimize communication in individuals with Primary Progressive Aphasia. It aims to enhance the quality of life for people living with PPA and improve communication challenges. PPA‐specific communication training is becoming increasingly important as more individuals with PPA live longer and continue to struggle with increasingly severe levels of disease.

Introductory Information
Primary progressive aphasia (PPA), also known as dementia without impairment in memory, is a neurodegenerative language disorder that predominantly affects frontotemporal areas (Rascovsky et al., 2007; Gorno‐Tempini et al., 2004; Lai et al., 2009). Eligible females who meet the selection criteria will be randomized into two groups. Patients in the first group will receive pulsed radiofrequency ablation in addition to the antispasmodic medicine, while this is not provided to patients in the second group, and they will only receive placebo. For the patients in the first group (treatment group), antispasmodic medicines, consisting of Baclofen 5-10 mg, Tizanidine 2-4 mg, and  Oxybutynin 5-10 mg will be prescribed and the treatment protocol will be adhered to. Before the radiological procedure, patients who need antispasmodic medications are given the necessary oral premedication, and in the case of lack of sedation, they are prescribed Diazepam 5 mg. To induce sedation and achieve the necessary analgesia, 1-3 mg Propofol diluted with normal saline with a volume of 20-25 cc per kg is given to all patients at the desired rate. An assistant monitors the patient's vital signs (heart rate, pulse oximeter, and capnogram) throughout the study. All patients are placed in the prone position on the operating table, and following this placement, the lumbar spine is washed with 25-100 ml normal saline. In the treatment group, two needles are inserted from L3 and L4 3mm below the laminae on the right and left sides and are visualized on fluoroscopy. Following the successful insertion of the needles, the superselective injection of 1 mL of contrast medium is performed bilaterally to ensure needle placement. After two minutes of contrast injection, the needle positions are fixed in 10mL of normal saline at a temperature of +37°C. The tip of both needles was in the posterior part of the superior hypogastric plexus in patients in the treatment group, and the procedure was performed using pulsed radiofrequency ablation with parameters of 45v peak voltage, 8-25 millisecond pulse width,

Abstract:
Background: Previous studies on exercise‐ induced muscle damage (EIMD) have mostly studied the effects of downhill running, with only a few studies using intermittent running. Little is known about the time course of pain and muscle damage markers after intermittent running. Purpose: To compare the kinetic and the kinematic differences between vertical sprinting and intermittent sprinting as measures of vertical and horizontal jumping abilities. Methods: 64 male soccer athletes (age 22.67±3.39 years, 174.00±6.02 cm, 76.38±9.92 kg, mean± SD) participated in the study. Participants who had history of injury and a low score on the AIS questionnaire were excluded. Participants performed 2 vertical jumps and 6 horizontal jumps before and after 90s of downhill running on different gradients (−1%, −3%, −5%), downhill repeated sprints with 10m shuttle runs (−2%, −4%, −6%) and control condition. Maximum jump height and jump time was calculated for vertical and horizontal jumps respectively. Vertical Jump height reduced immediately after downhill running at all downhill gradients (P<0,05). However, there were no changes in jump height reduction after the different downhill running gradients and control condition. Horizontal jump time significantly improved for 10m vertical jumps in all groups (P<0,05). Similarly, there was a significant improvement in horizontal jump time for 5m horizontal jumps in all downhill running conditions and control conditions, whereas vertical jump time improved only immediately after the intermittent sprinting. Conclusions: Exercise caused significant changes in vertical and horizontal jump parameters. The greatest changes were seen for intermittent sprinting. However, the differences were not associated with EIMD, and the exact mechanisms of change are yet to be clarified.

Cold compressing group (cool conditioning)

Effects of Vitamin D Supplementation in Patients With Moderate Periodontitis

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This research is designed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of vitamin D in controlling periodontitis and its effect on Vitamin D (25-hydroxy vitamin D) levels in the oral cavity and blood plasma.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Periodontitis is an inflammatory disease that affects approximately 20% of the adult population. Vitamin D is a steroid hormone that can be obtained from foods as well as synthesized from sunlight exposure. The body can store excess fat-soluble vitamin D in fatty tissues and metabolize it as necessary. People with vitamin D deficiency can be diagnosed with a low level of blood, the main source of the vitamin. The main action of vitamin D is calcium absorption, necessary for the mineralization of bones and teeth. Its primary effect is on the absorption, transport, and metabolism of calcium and phosphorus. Vitamin D deficiency causes a reduction in the growth of bone and teeth, causing poor oral health. Preventing vitamin D deficiency is important for preventing periodontal disease. The objective of this study is to investigate the effects of oral vitamin D supplementation in preventing and controlling periodontitis. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to evaluate the value of gallium-68-labelled fibroblast activating protein inhibitor-46 (68Ga-FAPI-46) regarding its ability to evaluate treatment response and predict disease free outcome in patients with solid tumors who were treated with conventional and/or molecular targeting agents. 68Ga-FAPI-46 is an investigational tracer that is able to target the fibroblast activation protein (FAP) protein, a cell surface protein, specifically expressed in activated fibroblasts. 68Ga-FAPI-46 can therefore be used to image activated cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) via positron emission tomography (PET). Although the normal physiological distribution of 68Ga-FAPI-46 has not yet been fully characterized, activated fibroblasts and their presence is expected to be significantly increased in tumors and in specific metastatic sites, i.e. in bone. Thus, 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET / CT is expected to show not only morphological, but also functional changes of CAFs that is related to treatment outcome.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In total, 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET / CT will be performed before (baseline) and after start of treatment with standard and /or molecular targeting agents, depending on patients treatment allocation. The assessment of the 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET / CT images in relation to treatment outcome is to be performed from a morphological and functional perspective. There will also be a qualitative evaluation of whether the patient can still be imaged with 68Ga-FAPI-46 PET / CT.

-----------------
68 Gallium-Fibroblast Activating Protein Inhibitor -46 Positron Emission Tomography-/Computerized Tomography (68Ga-FAPI-46 PET / CT) for Molecular Assessment of Fibroblast Activation and Risk Assessment in Solid Tumors

Abstract:
Background: At term, labor induction with a balloon catheter (BC) is mainly intended to reduce the rate of labor augmentation. The success of induction depends on the presence of an accessible upper segment, favorable for the passage of a vertex through the pelvic inlet and not by cervical insufficiency, as is usually thought. Objectives: The objective of this study is to measure the lower segment thickness, in the perineum, and to relate it to the success of labor induction using a BC. Methods: This study is an observational transversal analysis on a cohort of term births for the induction of labor (IOL). After the inclusion phase, in which a total of 203 births will be necessary for the power of the study, the births that did not result in a vaginal delivery will be excluded from the analysis. Statistical analysis will be performed using the Pearson correlation test and Spearman correlation for the association between the lower segment thickness and cervical dilatation by measuring the concordance between the two methods, using Bland‐Altman analysis and with the respective test of rejection of the null hypothesis. Results: The mean lower segment (4.57 ± 0.63 0 cm) thickness and the incidence (74.35%) of fetal scalp dystocia (FSD) were higher in labor induction by the balloon catheter than in labor induction with the mechanical route (2.99 ± 2.0 0 cm) (p < 0.05). Conclusions: The labor induction with BC does not seem to reduce the rate of FSD. The measurement of the lower segment thickness (LS) might be useful as a predictor for the duration of labor, FSD and possibly as preventive treatment of dystocia in labor induction.

Brief Summary

-----------------
The overall goal of this study is to investigate the ability of a machine learning model to accurately predict the level of residual sedation in pediatric patients with a history of medically complex respiratory conditions after emergence from a general anesthetic. The study will test a machine learning model designed to use patient data to accurately predict the level of residual sedation at 5 and 15 minutes after emergence from a general anesthetic. This study will provide information about the accuracy of this model, and the investigators' hope that the model will be able to improve the quality of care for these patients. The specific aims of this study are: Aim 1: To compare the accuracy of the machine learning model for predicting the level of residual sedation at 5 and 15 minutes after emergence in patients with a history of medically complex respiratory conditions. The investigators hypothesize that the machine learning model will be more accurate than previous methods. Aim 2: To examine the reliability of the machine learning model for predicting the level of residual sedation at 5 and 15 minutes after emergence. The investigators hypothesize that the predictive performance of the model will be stable across different sets of data. Aim 3: To assess the clinical impact of using the machine learning model to inform the level of residual sedation at 5 and 15 minutes after emergence. The investigators hypothesize that using the model to inform clinical management will improve the quality of care for patients with a history of medically complex respiratory conditions.

-----------------
The purpose of this study is to see what effects the study medication has on platelet activaiton in healthy volunteers. Certainly! The first arm, Experimental: Ampli-01, 3 mg nicotine pouch, is designed to assess the effects of a lower dose nicotine pouch on daily users compared to higher dose options. It allows for comparison of different nicotine strengths and their impact on pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and subjective effects. The second arm, Experimental: Ampli-01, 6 mg nicotine pouch, is essential to evaluate the effects of a higher dose nicotine pouch on daily users. By comparing the 6 mg pouch to the 3 mg pouch and a comparator product, researchers can determine the differences in outcomes between varying nicotine strengths. The third arm, Active Comparator: ZYN Cool Mint Mini Dry, 6 mg nicotine/pouch, serves as a reference point for comparison with the experimental arms. By including a well-established nicotine pouch product with a similar nicotine strength, researchers can assess the performance of the test products in relation to an existing standard. This arm helps to validate the study results and provide context for the findings.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to compare the efficacy of peribulbar steroid injections (PBSI) to a systemic (oral) steroid in controlling the symptoms of anterior segment ischemia (ASI) in patients with advanced diabetic retinopathy. It is postulated that the use of peribulbar steroid injections would more effectively control the symptoms of ASI than the oral steroid, thus improving clinical parameters in ASI patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients 40 years of age and older with vision-threatening ASI induced by advanced DR and who have not received any prior treatment (other than systemic steroids) for ASI will be randomized to either the PBSI group or the systemic steroid group. Prior to enrollment, all of the ASI patients will continue with the treatment protocol that they have been following for DR, which is either diabetic laser photocoagulation or anti-VEGF injections. Following inclusion into the study, all the patients will undergo a PBSI injection containing: 2 mls of 4% lidocaine (Xylocaine) subconjunctival injection bilaterally 2% Xylocaine will be injected in the tenon capsule 0.1 mls/ml dexamethasone (Decadron) injection in the tenon capsule 0.3 mls DMSO (Dimethyl Sulfoxide) injection in the tenon capsule. Sterile technique, and aseptic precautions to avoid contamination of the vial of steroid (Dexamethasone), will be carried out.

Official Title
-----------------
Treating Vision Loss With Complications of Advanced Diabetic Retinopathy and Anterior Segment Ischemia With Peribulbar Steroid Injections: A Randomized Trial Comparing the Efficacy of Peribulbar Versus Systemic Steroids Treatment in Advanced Diabetic Retinopathy Patients With Anterior Segment Ischemia (ASI)

Conditions
-----------------
Diabetic Eye Complications, Diabetic Retinopathy

groundtruth:
Thank you for providing the conditions and criteria. Now, let's start designing the study arms. Based on the provided information, I suggest the following study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation): QL1706H will be administered in sequential cohorts, each receiving 1 dose of QL1706H by subcutaneous injection on day 1 and QL1706 by IV infusion on day 22. From then on, they will receive QL1706 on day 1 of every 21-day cycle. Dose escalation will continue until the projected cohorts have been finished.
2. Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration): The PK parameters of QL1706H will be tested at different administration intervals.

Absolutely! Let's start with the first study arm. The Experimental: QL1706H Part 1 (Dose escalation) arm is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of QL1706H in patients with advanced solid tumors. By administering QL1706H in sequential cohorts with escalating doses, we aim to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the recommended dose for further studies. The subcutaneous injection on day 1 followed by IV infusion on day 22 allows for the assessment of different routes of administration and dosing schedules. This arm is necessary to establish the safety profile and optimal dosing regimen of QL1706H.

The Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration) arm focuses on exploring the pharmacokinetic parameters of QL1706H at different administration intervals. By testing the drug at various time points, we aim to understand its exposure levels, distribution, metabolism, and elimination in the body. This arm is essential for optimizing the dosing schedule and frequency of QL1706H to achieve the desired therapeutic effect while minimizing potential side effects. It will provide valuable information for future studies and clinical use of QL1706H.

This is a prospective, non comparative, open label, single-center pilot study of a combination of two drug delivery devices (Drug Dispensing Osmotic Pump and Microsphere-based Wound Care). Great question! The second arm will involve multiple administrations of BBC1501. We can call this arm the "dose escalation" arm. This arm will consist of three different dose levels: 2.5ug, 5ug, and 10ug. Each participant will receive a single injection at the start of the study and a second injection after 14 days. The specific dose level that an individual participant will receive will depend on the outcome of the previous dose level. 

The purpose of this dose escalation arm is to assess the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics (PK) of BBC1501 at various dose levels in patients with nAMD. We want to determine the optimal dose that maximizes therapeutic efficacy while minimizing adverse effects. The design of this arm follows a standard 3+3 design for dose escalation, which is commonly used in Phase 1 trials. 

In each cohort of 3 patients, we will administer drug at a specified dose level. If no safety or tolerability issues arise in the first patient of the cohort, the remaining patients will receive the drug at the same dose level. However, if a dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) occurs in the first patient, we will switch to the next lower dose level and proceed accordingly. This approach allows us to identify the highest dose level that can be safely tolerated by patients with nAMD. 

The dose escalation arm will be open-label and non-randomized, with a sequential design. We will monitor the safety, efficacy, and PK of BBC1501 in each cohort, and decide whether to escalate to the next dose level based on the pre-defined stopping rules.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The incidence of osteoporotic fractures is increasing. Bisphosphonates have not proved effective in secondary fracture prevention in clinical trials. Aims of our study were to assess the effects of intravenous zoledronic acid (ZOL) on bone turnover markers in osteoporotic fracture patients and to assess the effect of ZOL on the prevention of further fractures one year after treatment.METHODS: We carried out a prospective, randomized, placebo‐controlled, one‐year trial. Thirty‐four women with osteoporosis and a radiographically documented vertebral or trochanteric fracture were randomized in three groups. All received vitamin D(3) and calcium supplements for six months and were treated with ZOL (5 mg), saline or placebo three times a year. Patients were re‐evaluated with bone mineral density (BMD) measurements, serum osteocalcin, type 1 collagen carboxyterminal telopeptide of cross‐linked N‐terminal procollagen type I (CTX i), alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and BAP (bone‐specific alkaline phosphatase) assessments.RESULTS: Patients receiving ZOL had BMD increased at all measured vertebrae and at femoral neck significantly more than the placebo group. There were significant decreases in serum osteocalcin and CTXi in the ZOL group. ALP and BAP decreased significantly in the ZOL and saline groups, but not in the placebo group. One hip fracture was reported in the placebo group, and no further fractures occurred.CONCLUSIONS: Intra‐muscular and intravenous bisphosphonates have been shown to have similar fracture‐preventative effects. Intravenous ZOL seems to be a good alternative treatment for osteoporotic patients who have difficulties in compliance with oral medication.

OK, thanks for your collaboration! Can you tell us more about the study phases and types? 

Study designs are a set of guidelines that define how your trial may be carried out. Phase 0 studies refer to early drug tests that occur before the actual treatment, phase I describes how the treatment is tested initially for safety, tolerance, and dose finding in a small group of people. Phase II, also called Early Phase II, involves the treatment of a larger group of people to test whether the treatment is safe and how well it works. Phase III, also called Late Phase II, involves the treatment of a large group of people to compare a new treatment with the current one to see if the new treatment is more effective and safer. Phase IV, also known as Phase 1.5 or Phase 2, is when further studies on a new treatment are conducted involving much larger numbers of participants compared to phases I-III. 

We also use Phases to describe other study designs. Pilot and Phase 0 studies are performed in a small group of people to check if a treatment is safe and to learn more about how it affects the body; they are usually used at the start of a research program to help decide whether to do a full-scale study. Phase I exploratory (Phase I-E) trials refer to early studies on a small group of people that test the safety of a new treatment to understand how it will behave and identify side effects. 

A Phase I exploratory study is designed to detect potential adverse effects, side effects, risks, and efficacy of a new treatment. These studies are usually conducted with healthy volunteers who may receive the investigational drug for 4-5 days and are observed for up to 8 weeks. Phase II is typically considered a full-scale clinical trial and is designed to determine the efficacy (effectiveness) and safety of the new treatment. Phase III is the most common type of clinical trial, also called a confirmatory study, as it is designed to confirm the efficacy and safety of the new treatment and is typically conducted in large groups of patients. 


Phase IV exploratory (Phase IV-E) and Phase V studies are post-marketing trials conducted after the new treatment has been approved for use on the market and are designed to further evaluate its effectiveness and safety in large populations, assess its long-term impact on the body, and identify new uses for the treatment.
