Abstract:
Background and Aims: To find out whether acupoint seeds acupressure could increase the frequency and quality of defecation of chronic opioid users. Methods: An open, single‐arm exploratory study in three centers in Taiwan was conducted. 27 chronic opioid users were treated with one‐week baseline,1‐week treatment and one‐week follow‐up. Acupoints selected were 59(ST21), 9 (Liv3), 19 (Liv14), 20 (Liv3), 21 (Liv4), 23 (Liv5), 40 (Sp6), and 43 (CO6). Blanca (Cattleya aurantifolia) seeds were used as stimulants in acupoints for 1week. Frequency and quality of defecation were recorded according to Bristol Stool Form Scale (BSFS) and visual Analogue Scale (VAS). Results: One week treatment significantly increased the frequency and quality of stool (p <0.01, 0.05), and the results of BSFS were still better when using the VAS (p = 0.046). There were no adverse effects. Conclusion: The effect of acupoint seeds acupressure on chronic opioid users with constipation could be applied in clinical practice.

model_response: For the active comparator arm, I would recommend the following participant group/arm: "Standard Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block" In this arm, patients will receive the active comparator intervention of the standard FTB and IPACK block. The standard FTB involves injections of ropivacaine into the femoral nerve, and the IPACK block aims to block the superficial cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. For the experimental arm, the participant group/arm you've described (PACS block + FTB + IPACK block) will receive the following intervention/treatment: Before the surgery, an ultrasound-guided nerve block will be performed by an anesthesiologist. The FTB will be performed by ultrasound guidance, with ropivacaine injected into the interval between the sartorius and pectineus muscles, medial to the femoral artery. This will cover the cutaneous innervations of the anterolateral, mediolateral, and posterolateral knee from the ilioinguinal nerves. The PACS block involves injections of ropivacaine below and above the sartorius muscle to block the intermediate femoral cutaneous nerve. The IPACK block involves injections of ropivacaine on the posterior side of the knee in two locations: lateral to the tibial nerve and medial to the common peroneal nerve. The anesthetist will carefully identify the target areas using a high-frequency linear probe. 
For the active comparator arm (FTB + IPACK block), the participant group/arm will receive the following intervention/treatment: The same ultrasound-guided FTB procedure will be performed as in the experimental arm, as described earlier. The IPACK block will also be performed as in the experimental arm, with ropivacaine injections on the posterior side of the knee in two locations. 
In both study arms, the anesthesiologist will ensure that the target nerves are not injected directly, and only injections into the surrounding fascial planes are performed.

groundtruth: For the active comparator arm, I suggest the participant group/arm: "Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block." This arm includes patients who will receive the standard treatment of FTB along with the IPACK block, which is considered the standard of care. The FTB is a commonly used nerve block for knee replacement surgery, but it does not fully cover the skin component of the surgical incision. By adding the IPACK block, the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee are blocked. This arm serves as the control group to compare the efficacy of the experimental PACS block in improving postoperative analgesia.

Certainly! Here are the detailed interventions/treatments for each study arm:

1. Experimental: Para-Sartorial Compartment (PACS) Block + Femoral Triangle Block (FTB) + IPACK block
- Procedure: Para-Sartorial Compartments (PACS) Block
  - This intervention was selected because it has the potential to optimize analgesia by skin coverage of the upper third of the surgical incision. The intervention will be performed as follows:
    - The intermediate femoral cutaneous nerve will be visualized at the supralateral level of the sartorius muscle, in a duplicature of the fascia lata.
    - The needle will be inserted at the same puncture site as for the femoral triangle block, with a latero-medial orientation in the plane (intracanalar compartment).
    - In addition to the injection performed in the femoral triangle, two injections of 5 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 will be performed in addition, below the sartorius muscle (subsartorial compartment) and above the sartorius muscle (suprasartorial compartment).
- Procedure: Femoral Triangle Block (FTB)
  - The high frequency linear ultrasound probe will be positioned midway between the superior edge of the patella and the anterosuperior iliac spine. It will then be moved to visualize the apex of the femoral triangle, confirmed by visualization of the sartorius muscle laterally and the long adductor medially.
  - The needle will be inserted with a latero-medial orientation in the plane.
  - The initial injection will be a single injection of 15 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine + epi 1:400 000 under the sartorius muscle, lateral to the femoral artery, at the level of the apex of the femoral triangle.
- Procedure: Infiltration between popliteal artery and capsule of the knee (IPACK) block
  - It will be performed in order to block the sensory branches of the innervation posterior to the knee with 15 ml of ropivacaine 0.3% + epi 1:400 000.

To evaluate the efficacy of the new intraarticular (IA) anesthesia method using 40 mL of 1.5% lidocaine plus bupivacaine in patients with symptomatic, unilateral osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee requiring knee arthroscopy. Patients diagnosed with unilateral OA of the knee who required knee arthroscopy were included. Patients were assigned to receive either 40 mL of lidocaine plus bupivacaine or 40 mL of saline as a preoperative IA anesthetic. We excluded patients with hypersensitivity to local anesthetics and hematologic diseases caused by antiaggregation therapy or anticoagulants. Before the surgery, a total 40 mL of 1.5% lidocaine plus bupivacaine or saline was administered through the superior medial or lateral portal depending on the side of the OA knee. We then evaluated the operative time, time to the first analgesic requirement, total analgesic requirement, length of hospital stay, and degree of pain. A total of 65 patients were included, 45 in the lidocaine plus bupivacaine group and 20 in the control group. The mean operative time was significantly shorter at 19.7 + 7.6 min in the lidocaine plus bupivacaine group compared to 28.5 + 7.9 min in the control group (p<0.001). Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
DNA mutations in oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes may account for up to 20% of cancer mortality worldwide, as they result in uncontrolled cell division. Several such oncogenes (p53, BRAF, NRAS and EGFR) and tumor suppressor genes are known to be altered in human cancers.

Detailed Description
-----------------
DNA mutations in oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes may account for up to 20% of cancer mortality worldwide, as they result in uncontrolled cell division. Several such oncogenes (p53, BRAF, NRAS and EGFR) and tumor suppressor genes are known to be altered in human cancers. Patients with advanced lung cancer show a higher frequency of activating mutations in oncogenes (KRAS, EGFR, BRAF V600E, NF1, and ALK) and frequently alterations of genes involved in the tumour suppressor pathways (LOH, p53). The identification of these genes would permit patients to be selected for appropriate targeted directed therapies. Since these patients are likely to respond well to targeted therapy, but not to standard chemotherapy, the identification of patients with oncogene mutations represents an essential step in the implementation of rational therapeutic approaches. A retrospective analysis of the clinical database of 1348 (lung cancer) patients of the Geneva Cancer Registry shows a very strong correlation between activating mutations and the occurrence of second primary solid tumors, particularly lung cancer, esophageal cancer, and melanoma. In addition, 21% of patients with second primary solid tumors show a germline mutation in DNA repair genes such as p53, EGFR, BRAF, ATM, CHEK1, CHEK2, MLH1, MSH2, MSH6 and XRCC (DNA repair genes). Most individuals with germline mutations in DNA repair genes have no cancer history before diagnosis of their second primary cancer. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to retrospectively investigate patterns of adherence to anti-retroviral therapy (ART) and its impact on antiretroviral drug resistance using data collected in routine care for HIV patients in India.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to explore adherence patterns to antiretroviral therapy (ART) among HIV patients and examine factors associated with adherence in a nationally representative, diverse sample of HIV positive individuals. To this end, the investigators propose to utilize a retrospective database study design using a large, diverse, nationally representative HIV epidemiologic database in India. The investigators will identify HIV patients who started initial ART between 1 January 2004 and the start of nationwide ART scale-up in India in March 2006. The investigators will restrict the analyses to viral load data at 0 and 6 months, which are routinely collected as part of clinical care. This cohort will be representative of the HIV positive adult population in India and will enable analysis of important covariates. Additionally, the cohort will be sufficiently large, providing a unique opportunity to describe and quantify adherence patterns of patients receiving first-line ART in urban and rural settings across India. This information will be used to evaluate the potential utility of existing clinical guidelines (particularly the World Health Organization's [WHO] clinical algorithm for ART monitoring), and to generate hypotheses regarding intervention strategies to improve adherence, and consequently, reduce transmission and the incidence of drug resistance.

Official Title

Adherence to Antiretroviral Therapy and Its Impact on Antiretroviral Drug Resistance in India: a Retrospective Database Study

Abstract:
Background: SQY51 is an mRNA‐based approach to treat and perhaps cure Duchenne muscular dystrophy. This phase 1/2a trial assesses the safety, tolerability, and pharmacodynamics of intravenous SQY51 in pediatric and adult participants with DMD, a rare muscle disease. Methods: Participants with DMD will receive single escalating doses of SQY51 via intravenous infusion. Dose escalation will be carried out using classical pharmacodynamics (PD) design (cohorts of 6 participants). The aim with dose escalation is to find a therapeutic efficacious dose; additional safety and PK data will enable selection of the optimal dose to be taken into phase 2. An adaptive design will be considered for the second and subsequent cohorts to accelerate the clinical program. In addition, participants from an initial cohort (cohort 1) will be enrolled in four subsequent treatments at four different doses (phase 2a). The safety and tolerance of the four doses will be assessed and the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and exploratory biomarkers will be assessed (endpoints will be specified in the protocol). The primary outcomes for safety are the number of treatment‐emergent adverse events and changes in physical examination and biopsies. The primary outcome for pharmacodynamics will be the efficacy of exon skipping determined by the increase in dystrophin. Results: The primary endpoints will be reported in May 2023. Conclusions: This study will determine the optimal dose of SQY51 and will provide first data about the effects of SQY51 on dystrophin deficiency. Copyright © 2022 Elsevier Ireland Ltd

Study
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
There is a need for a non-invasive monitoring system that reflects the development of complicating infections that can be used at the bedside. The aim of this observational study is to evaluate the accuracy of a continuous skin temperature measuring patch (SteadyTemp®) in comparison to an invasive intervertebral body temperature (IBT) probe to detect early signs of infection. Hypothesis: IBT and an adhesive skin temperature monitoring patch are not significantly different in detection of infection. If the hypothesis is proven, the results can be utilised for possible improvements of clinical outcomes. 4 groups of participants (34 patients): 1. Patients with intra-abdominal surgery: Tumour, bowel resections, anastomoses, hiatus hernia repair Patients with intra-thoracic surgery: Lobectomy, sleeve resection, esophagectomy Patients with extra-abdominal surgery: Mastectomy, inguinal hernia, prostate surgery Patients without relevant surgical intervention: Elective surgery without visceral involvement

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an observational study. Study protocol: A total of 34 patients will be measured for skin temperature twice daily, from the day of surgery through a 7-day hospital stay. All patients will be connected to a vital system for continuous blood pressure monitoring. Patients with relevant temperature measurements (>38°C) will be assessed according to a 2 step protocol. Step 1: A chest x-ray (CXR) is taken on the 6th day after surgery. Step 2: If a CXR detects a pleural effusion or fever >38,5°C: Blood investigations (CRP), blood culture, urine analysis and urine culture are added to CXR. The aim is to recruit all patients from the 4 surgical groups and from the general medical ward without relevant visceral intervention. In addition, 12 participants can enrol from 05. to 09.2019 to investigate the efficacy of daily skin temperature measurements in relation to blood pressure fluctuations within 3 hours of surgery

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Steadytemp® is a wireless sensor device that measures and continuously transmits body temperature. It is intended for both inpatient and outpatient use, to improve prevention and detection of postoperative infection and improve treatment and reduce healthcare costs. The present study is a post market clinical follow-up study to be conducted in two stages within the framework of normal clinical practice at the Intensive Care Unit and inpatient ward at the University Medical Center of the Johannes Gutenberg-University in Mainz.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Introduction: Steadytemp® is a wireless sensor device that measures and continuously transmits body temperature. It was initially developed for critically ill patients. It is intended for both inpatient and outpatient use and features the following advantages: a) Continuous, accurate, wireless body temperature measurement b) Continuous, automated evaluation of body temperature evolution: fever > 38.2 ℃ (orally ≥ 38.4 ℃), persisting for more than 30 minutes, suggests an infection may be present. A temperature peak exceeding 40 ℃ increases the risk of complications and mortality in patients over 65 years of age and is therefore considered to be a significant and critical alert. c) Continuous, automated transmission of measurement data to existing clinical information systems, such as the patient's monitor (Carescape Vista® - USA eVita Medizintechnik GmbH - Germany) with immediate availability and display of the data for the attending staff. Methods: After obtaining informed patient consent from the patient or their legal representative, a Steadytemp® device will be attached to the patient as soon as possible after surgery and prior to admission to the ICU or inpatient ward. The study is divided into two phases. During phase 1 of the study (duration of hospitalization between 5 and 10 days), the focus will be on evaluating the performance of the continuous temperature measurement, as well as any additional effects of the Steadytemp®. Phase 2 is a non-interventional follow-up phase (duration of hospitalization > 10 days) during which the performance of continuous temperature measurement and the clinical relevance will also be evaluated. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and aggressive malignant primary brain tumor in adults, with a median overall survival (OS) of 12-16 months. While median OS can be achieved through standard treatment with maximum surgical resection followed by postoperative concurrent chemoradiotherapy plus adjuvant temozolomide (CT-T), GBM ultimately recurs almost exclusively within the first year. The best therapeutic interventions against recurrent GBM have yet to be identified, and current therapy is largely palliative. Crossover treatment with bevacizumab monotherapy demonstrated higher recurrence free survival (RFS) rate than best supportive care, but the survival benefit was not shown. Recent studies have suggested that upfront treatment with bevacizumab may improve therapeutic outcomes based on the fact that recurrent GBM after treatment with bevacizumab monotherapy was associated with poor survival outcomes. To improve therapeutic outcomes further, it is important to further explore the effect of bevacizumab in the recurrence of GBM. The investigators' research hypothesis is that, when used for upfront treatment, bevacizumab, monotherapy or combination therapy, can improve RFS and OS of GBM.

Study
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
There is a lack of research regarding the impact of behavioral therapy on patients' anxiety and stress. Thus, this study aims to investigate the effects of two behavioral therapeutic techniques, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) using distraction technique and mindfulness technique using relaxation breathing with muscle relaxation, on dental anxiety and dental stress in Iraqi adults seeking private dental care. The study will be conducted in two phases: a pre-intervention phase and an intervention phase. There are 5 steps within the first phase, whereby, the study population will be assessed in terms of dental anxiety and stress using the Dental Anxiety Scale (DAS) (short form Arabic version) and the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS). The second phase aims to assess the effects of the two behavioral techniques on patients' dental anxiety and dental stress. It includes a total of two stages. The first stage consists of applying the two techniques during dental treatment, specifically on patients with a high level of stress and anxiety. The second stage aims to assess the changes in levels of stress and anxiety after these two techniques are applied. The study will ultimately assess the effectiveness of these techniques in reducing dental anxiety and stress, and the results will be used to recommend the most effective technique for reducing dental anxiety and stress in Iraqi patients seeking private dental care.

Detailed Description
-----------------
RATIONALE: To the best of our knowledge, no previous research has examined the application of cognitive behavioral therapy using distraction techniques and mindfulness techniques using progressive muscle relaxation for dental anxiety and stress management in private dental clinic settings in Iraq. AIMS: To investigate the effects of cognitive behavioral therapy using distraction techniques and mindfulness techniques using relaxation breathing with muscle relaxation on dental anxiety and stress in private dental clinic settings in Iraq. STUDY DESIGN: A single-blinded, randomized controlled trial. SAMPLE SIZE: It is expected to recruit a sample size of 80 participants, 40 in each group. Intervention
=================
In this double-blind, randomized, single-dose, double-dummy, placebo-controlled study, after an overnight fast, 60 eligible subjects aged between 20 and 75 years will be randomized to one of two groups: DWJ1464 group (Group 1) or Placebo group (Group 2). 

The DWJ1464 group will receive a single 200 mg dose of DWJ1464 and two placebo tablets. The placebo group will receive two placebo tablets and a single 300 mg dose of DWJ1464. 
The study will end on Day 7 after the first dose administration. Study duration per subject is approximately 9 weeks. 

In the event that there is an adverse event, the principal investigator (the person in charge of the study) may determine it unsafe to continue the investigational product (IP), or the study itself. In this case, the principal investigator will make an early termination of the investigational treatment.

Study design
=================
This interventional trial is conducted following a single-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose finding study in adults who have been diagnosed with chronic liver disease. Following 2-week screening and a single dose on the first day(T0), participants will be randomly assigned to one of the following four DWJ1464 groups (A, B, C, and D) according to their ALT level at baseline and 100mg of DWJ1464 will be administered three times daily for 10 consecutive days. On the twelfth day (T1), the ALT level will be assessed to determine the dose and dose frequency for patients in groups A, B, and C. Patients will receive DWJ1464 at the same dose frequency and dose for a 8-week period. Assessment will be taken on Days 0 (before taking the trial), 4, 8, 12, and 21 and again on Days 16, 20, 28, 40, 45, 58, 65, 84, and 102.

Abstract:
Objectives: To evaluate the effects of two different doses of a local anesthetic (lidocaine HCl) for pain management following removal of orthodontic archwires. Methods: Prospective randomized parallel split‐mouth study, single blinded, comparing two doses of lidocaine, in the form of an intrasulcular injection, for the relief of pain caused by orthodontic archwire removal: 1‐g and 2‐g/kg body weight (Group 1 and Group 2). Pain intensity was measured at 2 hours, 1 day, 2 days, 3 days, and 7 days, using a 0‐10 Numerical Rating Scale. Statistical analyses were performed with R Studio and GraphPad software; P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Results: The sample consisted of 25 patients (age: 10.8 ± 3.6 years), distributed into the following groups: 28 and 29 in Group 1 and 2, respectively. Both groups were comparable in gender, side, archwire size, treatment time, and previous analgesic use (P > 0.05). The intensity of pain in the 2‐g/kg group was significantly lower than in the 1‐g group at Day 1 (2.17 ± 0.50 and 4.42 ± 0.78, respectively; P = 0.001) and at Day 2 (2.81 ± 0.63 and 5.17 ± 1.00, respectively; P = 0.003). The intensity of pain in the 2‐g/kg group was significantly lower than that in the 1‐g group on the 2nd, 3rd, and 7th days (P < 0.05). Patients in the 2‐g/kg group were considered pain‐free in 48 hours, compared to 72 hours in the 1‐g group (P = 0.001). No significant differences were observed in the total number of pain‐free days in both groups, although the 2‐g/kg group had significantly lower scores

Pain Neuroscience Education (PNE) involves providing patients with information about the nature of chronic pain and how the body responds to chronic pain, including how pain is processed in the brain and how it can lead to changes in the body and how physical activity can help manage pain. PNE can help patients understand the mechanisms of chronic pain and how to manage pain by modifying their beliefs about pain and applying appropriate coping strategies, such as physical activity.

For the patients in the Routine Education intervention, the educational material that they will receive includes a leaflet containing factual information about knee osteoarthritis, such as the structure and function of the knee joint, causes of knee OA, and its treatment. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This phase III, randomized, double-blind, active-controlled, parallel-arm, multicenter trial is designed to assess the efficacy of dupilumab in children as young as three months old with moderate/severe persistent atopic dermatitis

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase III, randomized, double-blind, active-controlled, multicenter trial to assess the efficacy and safety of 2 treatments with dupilumab versus placebo plus topical corticosteroids (TCS) in participants aged three months or older with moderate/severe persistent atopic dermatitis (AD). Approximately 380 participants will be randomized (1 : 1 : 1 ratio) to receive dupilumab 200 mg or dupilumab 100 mg at Week 0 and then subcutaneous (SC) q2w with or without TCS treatment or matching placebo SC injection q2w with or without TCS treatment for 16 weeks (Part 1 of the study). Efficacy will be assessed at week 16 and safety data collected at each study visit. Part 2, a long-term extension (LTE), will include participants who previously completed Part 1. Participants who completed Part 1 will have the opportunity to receive continued treatment with dupilumab 200 or 100 mg through Week 52, with a safety follow-up at 156 Wks follow-up.

Official Title
-----------------
A 52-Week Phase III, Randomized, Double-blind, Active-controlled, Multicenter Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Dupilumab in Children With Moderate/Severe Atopic Dermatitis

The primary and secondary efficacy endpoints in study 2 were changes from baseline in FEV1 and FVC, respectively, after 4 weeks and 12 weeks of treatment. After 4 weeks of treatment with 400 mg theophylline, a significant and sustained increase in FEV1 was found between days 1 and 42 (placebo 0.1%; 400 mg theophylline 3.7%, p = 0.015) ‐ no statistically significant differences were found in FEV1 after 12 weeks of treatment with 1500 mg theophylline. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
To find out the most effective way of treating patients with the infection Clostridium Difficile, by looking at the effect of two different types of probiotics on the infection. To discover whether treatment with one of the probiotics, compared to the other, has been more effective in controlling an initial breakthrough infection, and subsequent relapses.

Detailed Description
-----------------
CDI is a big and growing burden. Despite the use of specific antibiotics, such as vancomycin, CDI is not always treated quickly and effectively. Therefore, treatment of CDI has become an important and high impact clinical problem, and probiotics have been proposed as a therapeutic alternative, or as a treatment for preventing the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection. Prophylactic administration of probiotics is thought to reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile in the post-acute setting. The primary objective is to demonstrate whether treatment with a combined probiotic is more effective than treatment with Saccharomyces boulardii. A total of 391 participants will be randomised 1:1 to either treatment. Participants who developed a CDI during the course of the study will initially be prescribed Vancomycin, while the initial treatment will be Omeprazole for participants who are diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome. When participants are well recovered from their CDI, they will be discharged to the outpatient clinic, where they will be prescribed either of the treatment regimens. This follow-up will include telephone support provided by a nurse, and regular visits to the hospital for tests.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomised Controlled Trial Examining the Differences Between Two Types of Probiotics for the Treatment of Clostridium Difficile Infection

Conditions

Clostridium Difficile Infection

-----------------
* Drug: Vancomycin
* Drug: S. boulardii
* Drug: Saccharomycobulgaricus/Science bacillus
* Drug: Omeprazole

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to evaluate whether the combined oral administration of the 2 drugs would be safe and effective in the treatment of mild hyperlipidaemia. The study comprised 304 patients (202 men and 102 women) with mild hyperlipidaemia, mean age 63.4 years. Patients were subdivided into 4 groups of 100 apiece and then into 2 subgroups each. The groups were treated with different combinations of the 2 drugs — 75 patients with a combination containing simvastatin and fenofibrate, 75 patients with a combination that contained statin and nicotinic acid, and 100 patients who received only a statin. The drugs were taken for 4 weeks in amounts indicated in the respective combinations used. All patients underwent a medical examination prior to treatment and at the end of the 4‐week period of observation for the presence of symptoms and abnormalities in the blood and urine. Lipid metabolism and liver and kidney function were evaluated after taking the drug. The drug was well tolerated by the patients. Its use in monotherapy or in combined oral administration was effective for normalising the serum cholesterol level. The combined oral administration of simvastatin and fenofibrate was most effective in decreasing the total cholesterol, triglycerides, and «bad» cholesterol and in raising «good» cholesterol.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this registry is to assess the feasibility of obtaining prospective, observational clinical data, along with biospecimens, from patients who have not been randomized in a randomized controlled protocol and who are otherwise eligible for inclusion in this registry. By assessing the ability of the study team to successfully collect data, biospecimens, and consents from these subjects, we will establish a platform for future prospective observational clinical studies, as well as future biomarker-based interventional studies in the same protocol.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of obtaining prospective, observational clinical data, along with biospecimens, from patients who were invited to participate in a randomized controlled protocol but declined to do so. By assessing the ability of the study team to successfully collect data, biospecimens, and consents from these subjects, we will establish a platform for future prospective observational clinical studies, as well as future biomarker-based interventional studies in the same protocol, among patients with previously untreated, locally advanced, unresectable pancreatic cancer. We will also evaluate factors that affect study entry and retention, including patient characteristics and factors related to the study design. This registry is currently open to patients at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, Massachusetts. All of these subjects will be invited to participate in this registry at the time they decline to enroll in a randomized, randomized, controlled study in which we are currently enrolling patients. Those patients who agree to enroll in this registry will be eligible for enrollment in any subsequent observational and/or interventional studies to be conducted in this clinical protocol in the future.

Absolutely. The dose escalation strategy in this study is based on our previous clinical experience and will allow us to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and toxicity of RT for this patient population. The MTD is defined as the dose level at which 2 out of 6 patients experience Grade >= 3 toxicity, based on Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) version 4.0. The dose escalation scheme uses a 3+3 design, starting with a dose of 40 Gy at the 95% isodose line and escalating in 2 Gy increments until the MTD is reached. Once the MTD has been determined, the study will continue at that dose level to accumulate a total of 12 evaluable patients.

Certainly. Adaptive SBRT is a precise radiation technique that allows for the safe delivery of ablative radiation doses. It utilizes diagnostic quality onboard imaging incorporated within radiation treatment machines. This technology enables the generation and delivery of radiation plans specific to the patient's anatomy at the time of treatment. The goal of this study is to utilize adaptive radiation therapy to deliver ablative radiation with low toxicity rates in a patient population with technically challenging disease.

model_response: Of course. In both Trial Arms, patients would undergo leukapheresis and lymphodepletion using 1-flurouracil and cyclophosphamide. Approximately 2-4 weeks after lymphodepletion, they would receive the PSCA-CAR T cell infusion. Following the infusion, patients would be monitored for adverse events. For radiation therapy, patients in Trial Arm 2 would have radiation planned with oncologists to target lesions. The radiation would be delivered in 2 doses. In addition to these interventions, both study arms would include regular follow-up visits for response assessment, safety monitoring, and side effect assessment. Based on the trial design, we anticipate enrolling at least 15 patients in each study arm. We believe that each study arm has the potential to provide valuable data on the effectiveness and safety of PSCA-CAR T cell therapy with or without radiation therapy in patients with prostate cancer.
groundtruth:
Certainly! In Treatment plan I (PSCA CAR T-cells), patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer would undergo leukapheresis to collect their T cells. These T cells would then be modified in the laboratory to express the PSCA-specific CAR receptor. The modified T cells, known as PSCA-CAR T cells, would be infused into the patients intravenously up to 3 times during the study. Additionally, patients would undergo lymphodepletion therapy, bone scans, CT scans, tumor biopsies, and collection of blood, stool, and urine samples.

In Treatment plan II (PSCA CAR T-cells, radiation), patients would undergo the same interventions as in Treatment plan I, but with the addition of external beam radiation therapy. The radiation therapy would be administered in 2 doses and is intended to further target and destroy cancer cells. The rest of the procedures, including leukapheresis, lymphodepletion, imaging studies, and sample collection, would be the same as in Treatment plan I.

The group will be selected by random permutated blocks (block randomization). 
In this cluster randomization method, the control group and intervention group will be arranged according to the pre-specified random allocation, and 2 equal sized groups of the control and intervention groups will be formed in a certain order. Finally, the unit of random allocation such as individuals or groups that may have an intervention will be designated as an intervention unit or a control unit, and these groups will be formed sequentially. The random sequence will be generated using the Stata 12 software by two individuals who will be unaware of the process. Blinding description: This study is a double-blind and single-blinded clinical trial. Thus, at the end of each stage, the data in each randomized block will be evaluated by a statistician who is unaware of randomization and the control and intervention groups. Patients and physicians will also be unaware of the results of both groups during the trial. In this way, all of the participants, the principal investigator, the research team members, and the analyzer of the results will not know the allocation sequence and the corresponding allocation in each group.

[INV] The aim of this observational study is to determine whether exercise improves mobility in patients with COPD. [/INV] That sounds very important! Could you please explain this in more detail? 

[INV] Patients with COPD are often limited in their daily activities due to shortness of breath and fatigue. Exercise training has been shown to improve oxygen uptake, muscular strength, and exercise capacity in patients with COPD. However, the effects of exercise on mobility in patients with COPD are still unclear. In this study, we aim to determine whether exercise improves mobility in patients with COPD. The study will be conducted at the Pulmonary Rehabilitation Center at Dongtan Hospital, a tertiary-care hospital in Seoul, South Korea. We will recruit 50 patients with COPD who are eligible for exercise training based on the American Thoracic Society and European Respiratory Society guidelines. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the exercise training group or the control group. The exercise training group will undergo a 12-week supervised exercise training program. The control group will receive usual care and will not participate in the exercise training program. Both groups will be evaluated at baseline, 6 weeks, and 12 weeks in terms of spirometry, maximal isometric mid-thigh force, 6-minute walk test, lower-limb muscle volume and paretic lean mass, resting state leg electromyography (EMG), and leg EMG during walking. This study will provide important insights into the effects of exercise on mobility in patients with COPD. 

[INV] Participants in both groups will undergo a 3-minute sit-to-stand test, a 6-minute walk test, and an 8-minute walk test. The 3-minute sit-to-stand test measures the number of times a person can stand up and sit down in 3 minutes. The 6-minute walk test measures the distance a person can walk in 6 minutes. The 8-minute walk test measures the distance a person can walk in 8 minutes. All of these tests are commonly used to assess mobility in patients with COPD. 

[INV] In the control group, patients will receive usual care and will not participate in the exercise training program.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study aims to evaluate different therapies and physiotherapy protocols to compare their efficacy in rebalancing the body and posture and their influence on the progression of ataxia. The hypothesis is that these therapies are effective in alleviating the symptoms and signs of ataxia and maintaining balance, gait and posture. The hypothesis is based on previous studies on the influence of unstable surfaces in improving balance in patients with neurological impairments. Several previous studies have suggested that physiotherapy on unstable surfaces may improve ataxic control and balance. In fact, it has been shown that ataxic patients have significant difficulties maintaining balance on unstable surfaces such as a foam or a balance disc. This suggests that therapies based on unstable surfaces could improve ataxic control and balance. Another therapy, transcutaneous electrical spinal stimulation and exercises on an unstable surface, is used to improve balance by increasing muscle activation, motor reflexes and proprioceptive feedback. Transcutaneous electrical stimulation is a therapy that uses low electric currents to stimulate the skin to improve muscle control and coordination. The studies on this treatment have shown positive results, but there is no comparison in the literature of the effects of transcutaneous electrical stimulation and exercises on an unstable surface on ataxia control and balance. Therefore, the hypothesis was that these two therapies have a higher efficacy in improving balance and ataxic signs than regular balance exercises or conventional treatments.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In the study, they have evaluated the effects of different therapies and physiotherapy protocols in order to: compare the efficacy of the different therapies and improve postural control and balance. compare the efficacy of the different therapies and their influence on the progression of ataxia. The participants will be assessed at the beginning and end of the treatment with functional, gait, balance tests, neurophysiological tests and quality of life questionnaires. A clinical assessment scale and physical examination have been used to evaluate treatment progress and improvements in ataxic signs. Participants will receive all three treatments alternately and at different times to reduce the possibility of bias between the therapies. The study

Abstract:
This systematic review synthesized randomized controlled trial data to generate conclusions regarding the effectiveness of telemedicine as a strategy to improve blood pressure control of adults with hypertension. Studies were selected if they included participants with or without a diagnosis of hypertension; were adults (men or women, 18 years or older), and used clinical outcomes to assess blood pressure. The search strategy for this review resulted in 21 published studies. Two study authors independently abstracted information from the studies. Blood pressure control improved in 15 studies, although the evidence was not consistent across the studies. The studies varied widely, which presented challenges in meta‐analysis, creating limitations in the ability to generalize across diverse populations. Studies that were included in this review revealed a trend towards an improvement in blood pressure measures in those that used telemedicine. More studies are needed to provide clarity about the effectiveness of telemedicine as a method for improving blood pressure in the adult population. Copyright © 2016 Elsevier Inc. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Adenocarcinoma of the cervix (ACC) is a rare tumor. It is generally known as the most common malignancy in women in terms of frequency of uterine cancer. The aim of this study is to investigate the association of metformin and tamoxifen use in the adjuvant treatment of endometrial histology and advanced‐stage of primary diagnosis of ACC, and their prognostic effect on these factors.MATERIAL AND METHODS: A total of 53 patients who were diagnosed and operated between 2008 and 2021 were included in the study. The median age of the patients was found to be 46 (range 30‐59). For clinical and endoscopic examination of the patients, a histopathological examination was used. The data were taken from the database of the Gynecology Oncology Service of Turgut Özal Medical Park Hospital.RESULTS: Sixty percent (n = 26) of the patients were in the control group and received only adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel. Forty percent (n = 21) took metformin (500 mg 3 times/day) and tamoxifen (20 mg/day) in addition to chemotherapy after surgery. As a result of statistical analysis, it was found that there was a difference between the 2 chemotherapies administered to the patients after surgery. Median overall survival (OS) in metformin and tamoxifen group was 34 months.Median OS in the control group 25 months.CONCLUSION: The effect of metformin and tamoxifen administration on the OS of the patients is thought to be related to the regulation of the cell cycle and apoptosis. It was observed that ACC patients who were administered metformin and tamoxifen in addition to standard therapy had longer 5 year and 10 year OS.

The participants are recruited by posting advertisements in local gyms, running clubs, and media outlets. The advertisements provide information about the study's objectives, procedures, and eligibility criteria. Interested individuals are then required to complete a brief screening questionnaire to determine their initial eligibility. The questionnaire includes questions about the participant's running history, physical activity level, and relevant medical conditions. Participants who pass the initial screening are invited to attend an in-person assessment at the research center.
During the in-person assessment, the lead investigator performs an in-depth interview with the participant to determine their medical history, evaluate their physical condition, and confirm their eligibility for the study. If the participant meets all the inclusion criteria and does not have any exclusionary conditions, they are then enrolled in the study. Participants will then be randomly assigned to either the control group or the experimental group.
Once recruited, it is essential to ensure that the participants of this study remain in the study throughout the entire duration. However, it will be challenging to achieve complete follow-up and adherence, as some participants might not be able to complete the full study period for personal or medical reasons.
Recruitment is expected to take approximately three months, and the overall timeline of the study will be two years.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: We examined whether the use of a soft tissue stretcher during exercise can have pain reduction effects on people suffering from lumbar discomfort after exercise.BACKGROUND: Exercise‐related lumbar pain is a common concern among the general population. A soft tissue stretcher machine can ease muscular tension and increase tissue elasticity, but there is insufficient evidence regarding its effects on pain relief in people with exercise‐related back pain.METHODS: This study aimed to evaluate the effects of a soft tissue stretch on pain reduction and muscular activity in people with exercise‐related back pain. Thirty‐six participants with an average of 44.84 ± 13.37 years participated in this study. The participants were randomly assigned to two groups: the pain reduction group (n=19) and the control group (n=17). The participants used a foam roller for 90 seconds before and after exercise and a soft tissue stretcher for 10 minutes during exercise if they belonged to the pain reduction group. When performing a squat exercise, they wore a soft tissue stretcher for the lower back. In cases where discomfort or pain was experienced during exercise, the soft tissue stretcher was used for 10 minutes.RESULTS: In comparing the changes in visual analog scale pain scores before and after exercise in both groups, there was a significant difference between the intervention groups in pain reduction after exercise (P< 0.05). There were significant differences in the reduction of muscle activity in the pain reduction group compared to the control group (P= 0.051).CONCLUSION: The use of a soft tissue stretcher during exercise reduced pain and pain‐related muscle activity in participants with exercise‐related back pain.

Study design and overview
=================
Brief summary in scientific language
=================
This study aims to investigate thoracolumbar mobility, fascia flexibility, segmental thoracolumbar muscle strength, trunk range of motion, and flexibility of lumbar extensor muscles in recreational runners with running experience or without running experience. The results of the study should be used as a guide for preventing lower extremity injuries and lower back pain in runners and planning appropriate exercises. Also, the study will contribute to the literature by examining the effects of running experience on thoracolumbar mobility and thoracolumbar fascia functionality.

Brief summary in lay language
=================
Recently, sports injuries have become one of the most common reasons for seeking medical care. In particular, running is a sport that can lead to various injuries, mainly related to the lower extremities and the spine. Among them, injuries to the lower extremity and lumbar region are of particular concern due to their high prevalence and significant impact on daily activities and quality of life. As such, there is a growing interest in identifying effective strategies for preventing sports injuries, including lower extremity injuries and lower back pain, and promoting safe and healthy exercise participation. This study aims to examine the thoracolumbar mobility, fascia flexibility, segmental thoracolumbar muscle strength, trunk range of motion, and flexibility of lumbar extensor muscles in runners with running experience or without running experience. The purpose of the study is to provide valuable information to help develop prevention programs for lower extremity injuries and lower back pain in runners and to establish appropriate exercise programs. The study is expected to make an important contribution by examining the effects of running experience on thoracolumbar mobility and thoracolumbar fascia functionality.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
We aim to compare the treatment effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS), the combination treatment of tDCS and cognitive training, and cognitive training alone, on the executive function of children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)

Detailed Description
-----------------
In this study, 20 children of ages 8 to 12 with ADHD will be randomly divided into three groups. Each group will undergo 40 20-minute treatment sessions for 5 consecutive weeks. The first group receives tDCS to the prefrontal cortex. The second group receive tDCS to the prefrontal cortex and also performed cognitive training at home. The third group undergoing cognitive training only. The purpose of this study is to investigate whether tDCS over the prefrontal cortex in combination with cognitive training or cognitive training alone will improve the executive function of children with ADHD. The study will be performed in the context of a randomised trial. Participants will be randomly divided into three groups. Each group (n=20) will undergo 40 twenty-minute tDCS sessions conducted on 5 consecutive days a week, at 2mA, for a maximum duration of 30 minutes. The first group will receive anodal stimulation over the left prefrontal cortex. The second group will receive anodal stimulation over the left prefrontal cortex and cognitive training at home, while the third group will receive only cognitive training. Each group will be evaluated at the beginning of the treatment, one week after completion of the treatment, one month after completion of the treatment, and 3 months after completion of the treatment. Before and after the intervention, an electroencephalogram, a cognitive test, and a behavior test will be performed.

Official Title
-----------------
Clinical Trial for Evaluation of Safety and Effects of the Combination Treatment of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation and Cognitive Training Compared to the Mono-treatments With Either One on Improving Executive Function of Children With Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder

Abstract:
Osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee is the most common joint disorder worldwide. The current available treatments are limited in effectiveness with variable degrees of side effects. Ketamine, an FDA‐approved glutamate receptor antagonist with analgesic properties, has been demonstrated to have high efficacy in the treatment of OA pain both short and long term. The objective of this study is to conduct a phase I trial of ketamine for the management of OA pain, where the investigators will evaluate the safety and tolerability of intravenous ketamine in patients with knee OA. Participants will be randomized to receive a one‐time infusion of either saline or ketamine (0.1‐7.8mg/kg), and will be followed up for a period of four weeks post infusion to assess adverse effects and efficacy on arthritic pain.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Acute exercise (i.e. strength training) is generally not recommended in the hours immediately before and after major spine surgery. However, this is due to the lack of randomized studies investigating the effects of preoperative exercise on the rehabilitation of postoperative patients. In this context, the present study aims to determine whether four sessions of high-intensity and low-volume strength training 10 days before and 5 days after spinal fusion surgery can reduce length of stay in patients suffering from degenerative spine pathologies.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A 10-day resistance training protocol consisting of bilateral exercises of the lower limb (quadriceps and gluteus muscles) using the Nautilus (Med-X, MedX Biomechanics, Orem, UT, USA) device will be applied to the entire study population before and after spinal fusion surgery. The Nautilus device uses a pneumatic compression system that allows a single machine to accommodate patients of different sizes and body strengths, thereby allowing for highly individualized loading. The exercise program will be performed three times a week (Monday, Wednesday and Friday) during 10 days. Strength training sessions will last 20 minutes in total per training (10 minutes of warm-up and 10 minutes of a load-repetition series performed at 85% of the maximum load), under the supervision of a physiotherapist and an exercise physiologist, who will adjust the strength training sessions according to the specific characteristics of the individuals. These 10-day sessions will be followed by 8 days of rest prior to surgery. Following the surgery, resistance training for the same muscle groups (quadriceps and gluteus muscles) by the patient will be prescribed in conjunction with a standard physiotherapy rehabilitation program. This treatment program is routinely proposed in our medical center but is not yet prescribed in our country.

Official Title
-----------------
Effect of Preoperative Strength Training on the Rehabilitation of Patients Suffering From Spinal Fracture or Degenerative Spondylopathies: A Prospective Randomized Controlled Trial

Certainly! In the Experimental: Active tDCS arm, participants will undergo five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of active transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. The tDCS sessions will involve the administration of a constant anodal current of 2 mA for 20 minutes, targeting the primary motor cortex contralateral to the most painful site. The yoga program will be led by a certified instructor and will consist of centring, warming up, yoga postures, and guided relaxation.

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The combination with Zanubrutinib, Bendamustine and Rituximab was expected to show higher antitumor activity and safety and more durable response in the elderly and patients with TP53-mutation or chemotherapy intolerance.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Single arm study. The design was based on the results of a series of phase I studies of lenalidomide and high-dose chemotherapy combinations, which indicated that lenalidomide with ABT-89 or ABT-195, combined with bendamustine and rituximab, is highly effective and acceptable for patients with FL, MCL and SLL. The estimated incidence of Grade 3 or higher toxicity in the chemotherapy regimens without lenalidomide were 30-35% for FL, 15-25% for MCL and 0% for SLL. Therefore, we can expect that the incidence of Grade 3 or higher toxicity of our drug combination will be even lower. The combination of high-dose bendamustine and lenalidomide will also allow the effective elimination of bone marrow stem cells, and the safety risk will be controlled. The expected response rate of treatment with Zanubrutinib, Bendamustine and Ritxumab is more than 70%, and the expected 2-year PFS is more than 50%.

A Phase II Study of Zanubrutinib, Bendamustine and Rituximab in Patients With Newly Diagnosed Mantle Cell Lymphoma (MCL)

Title
=================
Investigative Analysis of Soft Tissue Sarcoma Clinical Trials: An Observational Study

Scientific title
=================
Investigative Analysis of Soft Tissue Sarcoma Clinical Trials: An Observational Study

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsSoft tissue sarcomas (STS) are a rare but heterogeneous group of tumors with an incidence of about 1 per 10,000. They originate within muscles, blood vessels, fat, nerves, and other connective tissues. STS include many different types of tumors and can be challenging to diagnose and treat. Currently, there are no proven therapies that improve overall survival (OS), and the current treatments are based on historical series with short follow-up. There is also a lack of patient-reported data regarding the treatment of STS. Therefore, there is a need for evidence-based methods and tools to address these challenges. This is where this study comes in. This retrospective observational study aims to investigate the impact and effectiveness of clinical trials for soft tissue sarcoma (STS). Specifically, the study seeks to collect patient-reported outcomes, such as health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and patient experiences, from patients with STS who have participated in clinical trials. The study also aims to understand the impact of clinical trials on patient outcomes, including treatment effectiveness and overall survival. Study design and methods This is a retrospective cohort study that relies on secondary analyses of data from the Connective Tissue Oncology Society (CTOS) registry, which collects data on patients with soft tissue sarcoma. The study will involve the following steps: Retrieve patient data from the CTOS registry: The study team will access patient data from the CTOS registry, which includes demographic and clinical parameters, as well as information on treatments received and outcomes. Collect patient-reported outcomes: The study team will also collect patient-reported outcomes (e.g., HRQoL, symptoms, treatment experiences) from patients who participated in STS clinical trials via telephone interviews or online surveys. These data will provide valuable insights into the patient experience and outcomes of participating in clinical trials. Analyze

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this randomized controlled trial, in three parallel groups, is to evaluate the effect of the autologous platelet-rich plasma in healing of intra-bony defects surrounding the root apices of teeth with irreversible pulpitis. This treatment would be performed in combination with apical surgery (curettage), the aim being the obturation of the root canal and its anatomical extension, the treatment of the intra-bony defect and the elimination of the bacterial focus (through drainage of pus and cleaning of the root apex area). The intervention with PRP will be performed intracoronally, in addition to the curative treatment of apical surgery. These participants will be compared with the control group, which will consist of participants who will only be submitted to curettage of the apical region. To validate the effectiveness of this treatment, patients, examiners and outcome assessors evaluators will be blinded after enrollment in the study.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a randomized, controlled blind clinical trial with evaluation of primary and secondary outcomes. Patients with irreversible pulpitis who present one or more teeth with apical periapical pathology will be included. All participants will complete the following steps as part of the study: inclusion step; randomization step (these subjects will be divided into the following three groups: control, PRP group and bone substitute group); intervention step: only subjects in the PRP group will be injected with autologous PRP intracoronally, at the moment of surgical treatment, along with other commonly performed interventions for the treatment of the intra-bony defect. This arm will serve as the control group, where participants will only undergo apical surgery without any additional treatment. This arm is important to compare the outcomes of the other treatment groups to the baseline of just apical surgery. What do you think?

Great! Moving on to the second arm, we have the "Experimental: bone substitute group". In this arm, participants will undergo apical surgery along with the implantation of a bone substitute into the area of the root apical bone defect. The use of a bone substitute aims to enhance bone regeneration and support tissue healing in the affected area. This arm allows us to assess the efficacy of the bone substitute in improving the healing process compared to standard apical surgery alone. What are your thoughts on this arm?

Wonderful! Now, let's move on to the third arm, the "Experimental: concentrated growth factors group". In this arm, participants will undergo apical surgery along with the implantation of concentrated growth factors (CGF) into the area of the root apical bone defect. CGF contains a high concentration of growth factors that can promote tissue regeneration and accelerate the healing process. This arm is designed to evaluate the potential benefits of using CGF in enhancing the healing of apicomarginal defects compared to standard apical surgery. What do you think about this arm?

Excellent! Now, let's move on to the fourth and final arm, the "Experimental: bone substitute and CGF group". In this arm, participants will undergo apical surgery along with the implantation of both a bone substitute and CGF gel into the area of the root apical bone defect. By combining these two treatments, we aim to maximize the regenerative potential and accelerate the healing process in the affected area. This arm allows us to evaluate the synergistic effects of using both bone substitute and CGF in improving the outcomes of apicomarginal defect healing. What are your thoughts on this arm?

Perfect! Now that we have designed all the study arms, here is the full list:

1. No Intervention: only apical surgery group
   - Participants undergo only apical surgery (including apicoectomy, inflammation debridement, and retrofilling of the root apex).

2. Experimental: bone substitute group
   - Participants undergo apical surgery plus bone substitute implantation.

3. Experimental: concentrated growth factors group
   - Participants undergo apical surgery plus concentrated growth factor implantation.

4. Experimental: bone substitute and CGF group
   - Participants undergo apical surgery plus bone substitute and CGF gel implantation.

These study arms will help us compare different treatment options and guide clinical physicians in the application of apical surgery. Is there anything else I can assist you with?

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a hospital-based observational cross-sectional study conducted to assess the magnitude, types, and associated factors of external abdominal hernias among adult patients in the surgical outpatient department.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Abdominal hernias are one of the most common surgical conditions encountered in the surgical outpatient and emergency department. Abdominal hernias lead to bowel strangulation and other life-threatening complications and require prompt surgical care. However, the majority of this population do not receive timely access to surgical care and undergo elective repair in resource-limited countries such as Ethiopia. This study aims to assess the magnitude, types, and associated factors of external abdominal hernias among adult patients in the surgical outpatient department (SOPD) at two hospitals in Eastern Ethiopia. The study uses a cross-sectional study design employing an online-based instrument distributed to adult patients visiting the SOPD at Hiwotfana Comprehensive Specialized University Hospital and Jugol Regional Hospital during the study period between September and November 2022. The instrument incorporates both closed- and open-ended questions to obtain comprehensive information about participants' demographic and clinical characteristics, as well as their experiences with abdominal pain in the past 4 weeks. In addition, the instrument evaluates the frequency and intensity of abdominal pain due to possible hernias, as well as the pain threshold, which is defined as the threshold of pain at which the participant cannot perform specific daily tasks. The study finds that the majority of participants in the study population had not received any previous treatment for abdominal pain. The study also finds that the age of participants was a significant factor in the development of external abdominal hernias, with the prevalence rate in adults under the age of 35 years (45.9%) being significantly lower than the prevalence rate for middle-aged participants aged 35-55 years (89.2%). The study recommends strengthening preoperative preparation and postoperative aftercare for abdominal hernias to mitigate the burden of hernia surgery. A description of the intervention(s)/treatment (if applicable):
=================
For this study, data collection, including demographic characteristics (age, sex, height, weight, body mass index, educational status, occupation, and residence), were obtained from patients, and their medical and surgical histories were reviewed. Patients' pain levels before, during, and after surgery were evaluated with the use of a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS score scale). This visual scale consists of a horizontal line of 10 centimeters. On this line, the patients were asked to mark their subjective pain status with a pen. In a case where a patient's pain score reached 3, analgesic intervention was initiated at the discretion of the physician. Postoperative sleep quality was measured using the PIMA sleep quality questionnaire. This includes eight sub-scores: subjective sleep quality on a rating scale of 1 to 4, sleep onset latency score of less than 2 hours, total sleep time greater than or equal to 6 hours, sleep efficiency greater than or equal to 80 percent, sleep onset and recovery problems sub-scales, and sub-scores of less than or equal to 2 on day-to-day sleep problems. The questionnaire consists of 4 options from strongly disagree, to disagree, to agree, and strongly agree. At the end of the study, PIMA's sleepiness sub-score will be rated on a scale of 0-3. Each sub-score was calculated by multiplying the frequency of response by the score of the item or sub-score to obtain the final score. Patients who were able to use the gel pillow without interruption for at least 6 nights over 2 weeks of the study slept with this pillow and were asked to fill out the questionnaire again on the third postoperative day and on the first postoperative week. After completing the 14th day, the gel pillow use was stopped, and the patients were evaluated using the questionnaires again. The sleep quality of the patients using pillow was compared to the sleep quality of the patients who were not allowed to use the pillow.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to provide post-operative care in the acute and subacute phase after bariatric surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Pain is the main complaint of patients after bariatric surgery. It is especially common after laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The pain after bariatric surgery is primarily caused by incision pain due to port placement through subcutaneous incisions during the procedure, and intra-abdominal pain or incisional pain caused by handling inside the abdomen. The pain is caused by the gastric band (LAGB) surgery, sleeve gastrectomy (SG), bypass surgery (BSD) itself, or other causes. Therefore, the main symptom to be alleviated is postoperative pain.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this single-center, single-blind, patient-randomized controlled study was to evaluate the effects of cooled air conditioning temperature on the nighttime sleep quality of patients scheduled for elective gastrointestinal (GI) surgery with general anesthesia. We investigated the patient's sleep quality through the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), Richard Campbell Sleep Questionnaire (RCSQ) and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) questionnaires.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In this study, patients aged 19-70 years undergoing elective GI surgery were included. Randomization was performed to allocate patients to the experimental group, which was placed on the ground air conditioning (GAC) temperature of 23-25°C, and the control group, which was place on the ground air conditioning temperature of 25-27°C. Sleep monitoring was performed the evening before surgery through the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), Richard Campbell Sleep Questionnaire (RCSQ), and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). In this study, data was collected before randomization and 1 day after surgery, and sleep quality is evaluated through statistical analysis according to pre- and post-operative changes in total sleep time, RCSQ, and PSVI-related items.

A Randomized Control Study on the Impact of Sleep Quality According to the Temperature of the Ground-air Conditioner on Patients Scheduled for Elective Gastrointestinal Surgery With General Anesthesia

Abstract:
PURPOSE: To compare the accuracy of a 3‐dimensional (3‐D) surface matching technique based on 3‐dimensional digitizing with a 2‐dimensional (2‐D) landmark‐based technique based on a computer‐assisted design/computer‐assisted manufacture system in the fabrication of a customized maxillomandibular positioner (MMP).MATERIALS AND METHODS: Study design was a prospective, randomized clinical trial. Eligible subjects received oral endodontic treatment for irreversible pulpitis of a non‐vital maxillary or maxillary‐mandibular molar tooth, the proximal contacts of which could be closed after pulpectomy. Forty patients were randomly assigned to group 1 (20 subjects) in which a customized positioner was fabricated using surface matching, or group 2 (20 subjects) in which a customized positioner was fabricated using a computer‐assisted design/computer‐assisted manufacture system. The accuracy of the positioners was compared using a customized jig and the amount of rotary movement required to open the proximal contact space was monitored using a dial indicator.RESULTS: The mean difference between the actual and planned positions for the contact points was 0.12 ± 0.19 and 0.19 ± 0.14 mm and the angular difference between the actual and planned positions for the contact points was 0.25 ± 2.23 degrees and 0.36 ± 2.93 degrees for groups 1 and 2, respectively. Mean rotary movement at the contact sites did not differ between treatment modalities (P = 0.33).CONCLUSION: Both treatment modalities produced positioners of similar accuracy.

It would be recommended to design a control arm that employs neutral or positive writing prompts as a control condition. Participants in this arm will provide positive words related to daily life, for example, expressing gratititude, positive daily happenings, and pleasant moments of their day. This will help us evaluate the specific impact of expressive writing focused on TNB identity and social connections on stigma and well-being. It is also important to include a TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition intervention arm to examine its effectiveness in our study.

It is possible to add one additional control arm that does not involve writing prompts for TNB Identity Affirmation or Social Connection. Participants in this arm may be asked to record a daily audio and/or video log focusing on their daily activities to capture a broader representation of the control group while remaining relatively neutral. This would allow for a better comparison between the TNB Identity Affirmation Conditions and the other study arms.

As for the duration of the intervention, you can consider assigning each arm a time frame corresponding to each intervention. For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition intervention, the IA task can be completed in a single sitting that lasts 15-20 minutes. The SSC+IA group would complete both tasks in the same session. The control group would engage in their daily writing or audio/video recording for a similar duration. It is recommended to set up a daily reminder using an app or email to encourage participants to complete their daily writing. Alternatively, participants can be allowed to choose the time of day or days of the week when they feel comfortable completing the writing exercises.

For the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. The first two days will involve engaging in the same TNB Identity Affirmation intervention as the first arm, where participants will write in response to a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. After that, participants will be asked to compose a letter of gratitude to someone who has provided meaningful support. Through the letter, participants will reflect on how their relationship with the person has been affected by their gender identity disclosure and how expressing appreciation may enhance their relationship. It is anticipated that the letter will help participants strengthen their social connections by acknowledging and appreciating the support they receive from others.

For the control condition, participants will be asked to complete expressive writing tasks about events of the day. They will be asked to reflect specifically on both positive and negative aspects of their day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections.

groundtruth: For the TNB Identity Affirmation (IA) Condition, participants will receive the same prompt for all four days of writing. This design, often used in expressive writing interventions, allows for deeper and continued reflection into specific thoughts and emotions. The prompt will involve reading a vignette that describes the experience and response of a young adult who experiences rejection from a close friend after a first disclosure of their gender identity. Participants will then be asked to write in response to three prompts: 1) identify expressions of internalized transphobia in the vignette character, 2) reflect on times the participant has experienced similar feelings, 3) identify thoughts and feelings that promote and support a positive and affirming identity in contrast to negative emotions and thoughts.

In the IA + Strengthening Social Connections (SSC) Condition, participants will complete the TNB Identity Affirmation intervention on the first three days, following the same prompts as the previous arm. On the fourth day, participants will be directed to compose a brief letter of gratitude to an individual to whom they have not previously expressed gratitude, and who has provided meaningful and affirming support to them as a TNB person. This additional component aims to further enhance social connections and gratitude, which are important factors in promoting well-being.

In the Control Condition, participants will engage in expressive writing about events of the day, without any specific prompts related to TNB identity or social connections. This neutral writing task will serve as a comparison to evaluate the specific impact of the TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing internalized stigma and promoting well-being, compared to general expressive writing.

Exactly! You have successfully designed the study arms. These arms will allow us to assess the impact of TNB Identity Affirmation and Social Connection interventions on reducing stigma and promoting well-being in TNB individuals. Well done!

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main part of the study tests the effects (on glycaemic and insulinaemic responses) of an intervention - in the form of a fruit-flavored juice drink, containing 4.3g D-Allulose per 120 ml, in comparison to 32g pure fructose, or 32g glucose - in a crossover set up.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The first three participant visits will be screening-visits to confirm eligibility, in particular fasting blood glucose, and to obtain consent from the subjects. During an additional two study visits, which take roughly an hour each (1-2 hours postprandial), participants will taste the 3 proposed interventions in randomized order within the same visit. Gastric emptying in the fasted state and postprandially is tested, using a scintigraphic 3 H-labelled glycohexose bolus method. After an 8-10-h fast, the radiotracer is given by mouth together with plain water to ensure proper washout of the previous isotope. A test meal will be consumed in all visits 40-minutes after the radioactive bolus, with samples given for insulin, glucose, and gamma counting at 0, 15, 30, 60, and 90 minutes. Participants will then return for a final 3-h visit approximately 72-hours after visit 3. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to develop an algorithm to help distinguish benign from malignant breast lumps in women with dense breasts at high risk of breast cancer, and to evaluate the potential diagnostic value of 3D breast ultrasound combined with elastography, breast density, and radiomics in identifying high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) and invasive breast cancer (IBC) in dense breasts. In clinical practice, a breast ultrasound scan is recommended as an additional examination in high-risk women with dense breasts, which has obvious diagnostic limitations and requires more extensive research on screening methods and diagnostic markers to improve its specificity and sensitivity. As a widely used medical imaging technique, ultrasound technology can dynamically observe lesion blood flow, morphology, vascular distribution, and other phenomena of blood vessels in real-time, which provides a powerful means for breast lesion detection, characterization, and monitoring. Breast elastography can obtain strain values in each section of the breast, which are converted from mechanical indices in the grayscale ultrasound image. With the assistance of image processing technology, it can improve its accuracy and reduce the rate of benign misdiagnosis of breast ultrasound.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Three-dimensional (3D) ultrasonography provides accurate information on lesion position and volume and helps characterize lesions in a qualitative and quantitative manner. The 3D ultrasonography was shown to be more effective than 2D in the detection of breast lesions, especially in the detection of microlumps and intramammary lymph nodes. Therefore, 3D ultrasonography should be preferred for the initial diagnosis of breast lesions. This study was approved by the medical ethics committee on May 27th, 2021. The study plans to enroll 800 healthy women with dense breasts with suspected breast lesions.
