Abstract:
AIMS: Prostate cancer (PCa) is the second most common malignancy and the cause of the tenth most deaths in men. Recent epidemiological and experimental studies indicate a correlation between PCa and environmental exposure to electromagnetic fields (EMFs). The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of an alternative to classical X‐rays on the course of prostate cancer.MATERIALS AND METHODS: We studied 95 patients who were diagnosed with prostate cancer by a digital rectal exam and standard biopsies and selected for a prostatectomy. The patients were randomly assigned to two groups. The first group underwent a standard prostatectomy and the other group an alternating magnetic field (AMF) and standard prostatectomy. We evaluated preoperative (PCa 1) and post‐treatment (PCa 2) prostate‐specific antigen (PSA), prostate volume (PV), the Gleason score, and the maximum tumor size by use, respectively, of ELISA and MRI analyses. The treatment period ranged from 3 to 6 months.RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: The treatment group showed less prostate tumor volume reduction (2.5 cm3 vs 0.9 cm3) and less PSA reduction (‐5.0 μg/L and ‐1.6 μg/L) than the control group (p < 0.005). The overall PSA reduction after standard prostatectomy in control patients was 82%, whereas in the AMF‐treated patients, it was only 73%. In cases of prostate volume greater than 60 cm3, PV reduction was greater in the AMF groups (p < 0.008). Furthermore, AMF resulted in a significant reduction in PSA in the 3 months following therapy in the treatment group (p = 0.0001).

Abstract:
We have described the D2S400 as part of the GSC mapping for the human genome and a linkage map for the mouse genome. To assess the chromosomal polymorphisms used for mapping and to verify the use of markers in human genetic studies, we have screened 103 and 281 chromosomes from human and mouse, respectively, by Southern blot analysis of restriction length polymorphisms. The polymorphism between human chromosomes 4, 6, 10, 13 and 18 and mouse chromosomes 15, 17, 13, 17 and 18 could be verified, and we identified chromosomal polymorphisms on human chromosome 16 and 21 as well as mouse chromosome 7, 9, 11 and 18. We obtained PCR‐based primers for D2S400 and PCR‐based assays with fluorescent or radioactive detection. We have used these markers in genetic linkage studies in humans and mice, and the assays are now available commercially.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The relationship between daily traffic-related air pollutant exposure and asthmatic airway inflammation has not been assessed. This study investigates the effect of traffic-related air pollution exposure and exercise among youth with physician diagnosed asthma. The investigators aim to identify the extent that traffic-related air pollution exposure during exercise exacerbates airway inflammation in asthma.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Asthma is a common respiratory disorder with an increasing rate of occurrence. Increasing evidence indicates that childhood is a critical period for development of asthma and that traffic-related air pollution may be a significant factor in its development and course. The current hypothesis is that a greater exposure to traffic-related air pollution is associated with greater airway inflammation. Recent studies show increased airway inflammation following exposure to particles of air pollution. In turn, inflammation may be a predictor of disease severity and asthma control. In particular, exercise, which can increase the burden of air pollution, may be an important contributor to inflammation and lung injury in asthma. The objective of this study is to determine the effects of indoor versus outdoor cycling on changes in asthmatic airway inflammation. The investigators will compare indoor vs. outdoor exercise on changes in FEV1, FEF25-75%, spiral airway density (SAD), airway eosinophils counts (a marker of inflammation in asthmatics) and exhaled nitric oxide levels (a marker of airway inflammation). Indoor cycling will be completed in a controlled environment using a portable cycling machine (Exergame® G4), which is mounted with a ventilation system designed to remove all airborne pollution created from pedaling during exercise. Additionally, the same cycling machine will be used for all indoor exercise bouts, thereby removing inter-bout variation, a limitation of previous studies. Background and Objectives
-----------------
Asthma affects around 13.9%, with over 4.3 million adults and 1.1 million children affected in the UK. Asthma is a major cause of morbidity, reducing day-to-day health and quality of life, and is the third most common reason for hospital admission. Additionally, asthma is a major cause of premature mortality, with a fifth of all deaths in asthmatic smokers linked to active or passive smoking. Cigarette smoke is a combination of toxic and potentially beneficial substances. However, it is not the cigarettes as such that cause asthma, but the inhalation of their smoke, which can cause respiratory symptoms in young and old alike and often leads to wheezing, coughing, and breathlessness. Passive smoking is an increasing cause of these respiratory symptoms, especially in young children.
Purpose of the study
-----------------
The primary outcome of this study will be to investigate the impact of short-term exposure to non-tailpipe mode PM of varying concentrations on adult participants with asthma on: (1) daily and 24-hour mean peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) and FeNO (fractional exhaled nitric oxide), and (2) inflammation of the airway (measured by FeNO). The secondary outcome will be to investigate whether the study participants' airways respond differently to varying levels of PM exposure by investigating the relationship between FeNO and the concentrations of non-tailpipe course mode PM in the same air samples for an assessment of: (1) any change in FeNO and PEFR for 24 hours post exposure, and (2) any change in FeNO and PEFR on the following mornings. # The effect of exercise on pain and function in individuals with lumbar disc herniation; a prospective, randomized, controlled pilot study

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To determine the effect of intensive cardiovascular exercise therapy on pain, disability and central sensitisation in patients with chronic low back pain with L4‐5 lumbar radiculopathy and diskectomy.METHOD: A prospective, randomized, controlled, single blind study. A total of 22 patients with radiculalgia were randomized into 2 groups. Preoperative, 6 weeks and 3 months post‐operatively the patients of the control group (n = 11) remained sedentary while the patients of the intervention group (n = 11) participated in 8 weeks of aerobic exercise. The outcome measures were; Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), visual analogue scale for pain, and quantitative sensory testing.RESULTS: The VAS in the exercise group decreased from 71 mm to 26 mm and in the control group from 72 mm to 44 mm. The ODI of the exercise group improved from 57% to 24% and in the control group from 59% to 43%. The Quantitative Sensory Testing decreased from 49.9 mm/s to 37.3 mm/s in the intervention group and from 44.0 mm/s to 36.2 mm/s in the control group.CONCLUSION: Lumbar disc herniation causes pain, disability and sensory disturbances at several body levels. Intensive cardiovascular exercise therapy decreases radicular symptoms and disability. Central sensitisation in the spine as well as local sensitisation in the leg might be associated with chronic pain in this condition. These symptoms might be decreased by intensive cardiovascular exercise therapy.

groundtruth: Great. The first arm will focus on participants with biallelic OTOF mutations. As for the participant group/arm, we'll include pediatric participants with these mutations. The intervention/treatment will be an observational study to observe the impact of digenic mutations on hearing loss over 4 years. This arm is crucial to understand the effects of digenic mutations on hearing loss, as this is a more complex genetic scenario compared to single gene mutations. By studying this group, we can gain insights into how multiple genetic factors interact to contribute to hearing loss in pediatric participants.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Although previous research has shown the efficacy of trigger point manual therapy for trigger points in the shoulder musculature, few studies have investigated the effectiveness of this treatment modality for latent myofascial trigger points (MTrPs) in the hand and forearm musculature. The Flexor Digitorum Brevis (FDB) has been identified as a frequently occurring MTrP site for which a pressure release technique, manual trigger point compression, may be effective. The objective of this study was to determine the changes in FDB bilateral Trigger Point (TP) tenderness after this intervention.METHODS: A convenience sample of 40 asymptomatic students who presented with bilateral FDB TPs was recruited for this study. Two 15‐minute interventions were performed using a graduated compression technique. Each subject received a pre‐ and a post‐test for pain sensitivity at five locations of FDB, as well as for active range of motion (ROM). The pressure release technique was assessed subjectively by a five‐point Likert scale. Data analysis was performed using descriptive statistics, paired t‐test, and repeated‐measures analysis of variance.RESULTS: All subjects reported immediate pain reduction after the intervention. The 30‐minute post‐test pressure release measure was 3, 3.5, and 3, respectively. An effect size of .79 was achieved after the intervention. Significance was found in the immediate post‐test ROM for all directions of finger extension and flexion (P < 0.05). Subjects reported an average of 62% ROM improvement at 5 minutes and 92% at 15 minutes from pre‐test.CONCLUSIONS: We found that bilateral FDB TPs decreased and the subject's active ROM improved immediately after pressure release.
The intervention/treatment in this trial is progressive pressure release.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The Scleroderma Action Network (SAN) is the world's largest voluntary, not-for profit patient organization (1). Scleroderma is a rare and complex autoimmune condition that affects the skin, lungs, and other major organs. There are no known causes of, or cure for, scleroderma. SAN has created the Scleroderma Patient-Powered Research Network (SPPRNet) with over 2200 active participants (2). Through SPRRNet, SAN patients voluntarily share data on how the disease affects them, their participation in research studies, and their quality of life (3). Through these efforts, SAN has successfully built research infrastructure to empower its members to participate in and influence their own care (4,5). This proposal will build upon SPRRNet's existing data-sharing infrastructure and focus on enhancing it, particularly by integrating new sources of information that can supplement and strengthen our understanding of how the disease affects patients over time. Specifically, this study will: (1) leverage the SAN database to conduct two large-scale, longitudinal patient surveys to examine the impact of scleroderma symptoms and healthcare utilization over time from the patient's perspective, (2) evaluate how patients perceive and respond to scleroderma treatment options in clinical trials and how these impact personal outcomes, (3) evaluate the role of patient self-advocacy on treatment decision making. Our team will also create open-source analytic platforms to support these aims. The information from this study will help us gain a comprehensive understanding of how the disease affects patients, and the role that patient self-advocacy plays in the treatment and management of scleroderma. Our findings will also help us understand how patients respond to treatment options and inform future research efforts in scleroderma. The results of this study could have important implications for understanding the disease and developing effective treatment options for scleroderma patients. The team has expertise in data analytics, patient engagement, and the design and conduct of patient-centered outcomes research.

Official Title
-----------------
Scleroderma Patient Engagement in Clinical Research

Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: To investigate the relationship between serum biomarkers of iron homeostasis and cardiac function in patients with sarcoidosis and to evaluate whether iron therapy can improve cardiac function or other organ‐specific involvement.METHODS: We conducted a retrospective longitudinal study in 53 patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis. We determined laboratory measurements and transthoracic echocardiographic, nuclear imaging, and cardiac MRI parameters to estimate iron metabolism within different compartments. Echocardiographic images were analyzed manually and semiautomatically.RESULTS: Patients with reduced right ventricular (RV) function (n = 24), left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction (n = 44), and impaired diastolic function (n = 40) had increased serum ferritin and, in some cases, decreased tissue‐bound iron. We found high levels of serum hepcidin with and without elevated iron uptake in the RV of the sarcoidosis group and in controls. Elevated levels of inflammatory factors (interleukin 6, C‐reactive protein, or monocyte chemoattractant protein‐1) were associated with high tissue‐bound iron in RV tissue samples. In vitro studies showed that interleukin 6 stimulation of myocarditis patient‐derived macrophages increased mRNA levels of hepcidin, whereas interleukin‐10 stimulation reduced hepcidin secretion. Hepcidin increased myocardial iron loading in vitro.CONCLUSION: Elevated serum hepcidin levels induced by elevated inflammation can increase tissue iron in the right chamber of the heart causing RV dysfunction. These data may support the possibility that anti‐hepcidin therapy would be useful for the treatment of heart failure in patients with sarcoidosis.

Study Arm 2: Other: Speech therapy. 

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Objective: To assess the effect on language development and quality of life in children with cleft palate. Study Design: A prospective, controlled, randomised interventional clinical trial. Subject Type: All Participants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Cleft lip and palate (CL/P) is one of the most common congenital anomalies with a prevalence of 1:600, 1:563 and 1:200 in the Indian subcontinent, Africa, and Caucasians respectively. CL/P cause a plethora of functional problems including feeding, hearing, speech, as well as social and emotional abnormalities. Speech abnormalities in these patients are the most frequent among other problems occurring due to CL/P and are the most common cause of communication disturbances . The most common speech disturbance reported in post cleft patients is hyper nasality (abnormal production of sounds by vibration of the soft palate causing increased airflow through the soft palate and nose) . The other speech problems are nasal emission and resonance disturbance. These speech disturbances lead to articulation disorders, communication disorders, stuttering. Due to the speech differences, there is the problem of social isolation and communication impairment for children. This ultimately affects their psychological development. Children with CL/P have less quality of life (QoL) because of psychological problems and communication disturbances. Thus this study aims to examine the effectiveness of speech therapy and its ability to reduce social isolation, psychological difficulties and communication problems and to improve the overall quality of life of children who have received surgical repair of the cleft.

Cleft Lip and Palate Impacting on Children's Language Development and Quality of Life: An Interventional Clinical Trial

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Respiratory weaning is the process of gradually decreasing the ventilatory support required by patients after mechanical ventilation. The use of peripheral spinal cord stimulation (pSCS) may be beneficial in promoting a more consistent pattern of breathing and improving respiratory weaning outcomes. METHODS: The study included patients older than 18 years who met the criteria for ARDS or were having elective surgery for upper abdominal organs. Patients were randomly allocated to the pSCS group or the control group, which received standard care. The outcomes of interest were the time required for mechanical ventilation weaning, ICU and hospital length of stay, and oxygenation parameters. RESULTS: A total of 82 patients were enrolled in the study (45 patients in each group). In the intensive care unit, ventilator free‐days was significantly higher in the pSCS group than in the control group (5 vs 1; p = 0.0001). The mean duration of weaning before extubation was significantly shorter in the pSCS group than in the control group (37 vs 80 hours; p = 0.004). There were no significant differences in other weaning or extubation outcomes between the groups. CONCLUSION: This study suggests that pSCS may be a beneficial adjunct to weaning in patients with respiratory insufficiency. Future investigations should evaluate the optimal pSCS parameters for weaning and the potential benefits of pSCS in other patient populations.

Participants from group A will receive a 10-minute exercise prescription which includes upper limbs exercises (curls, press, extensions, raises and shoulder flexion) plus core musculature exercises (knee raises). They will perform 5 sets of 10 exercises on alternate days for 4 weeks, and their workload will be progressively increased by adding more plates to the dumbbell if they can execute at least 12 repetitions of each exercise in 2 minutes. The participants from the control group will receive a 10-minute exercise prescription which includes only core musculature exercises. These participants will perform 2 sets of 10 repetitions of each exercise 3 times a week for 4 weeks. If they are able to execute in a row at least 20 repetitions for 75 seconds, they will change the resistance, but will not exceed the maximum dose of 5kg. Objectives: Sepsis is one of the most common causes of intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and mortality in patients with sepsis remains high. Methods: This is a single‐center, randomized, double‐ blind, and placebo‐controlled clinical trial that was conducted in Zanjan City's Intensive Care Unit, located in a public medical center in Zanjan, Iran. Patients were randomly assigned to two groups: the experimental group and the control group. Both groups were administered vitamin B6 (1000 mg/day) and 0.9% saline, respectively, for seven days. Serum creatinine (SCr), urea levels, neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR), C‐reactive protein (CRP), and interleukin‐6 (IL‐6) were tested daily until the seventh day after admission or death. The Wilcoxon test, t‐test, chi2‐test, repeated measured analysis of variance (ANOVA) in the Friedman test with Bonferroni correction was used for data analysis. Results: This study included 56 patients. Two patients died due to severe infection (one patient in the experimental group and one patient in the control group) and were excluded from further analysis. Abstract:
AIM: This randomized controlled study evaluated the use of an audio‐visual aid and non‐painful stimulation (stroking hand on the cheek) as a behavioral management program for children under local anesthesia.METHODOLOGY: Thirty children (7‐11) undergoing their first dental visit received infiltration anesthesia at three sites (buccally, lingually or palatally). Each child was randomly assigned into one of three groups: hand stroking group, audio‐visual aid group and control group. The patients were divided into one of the three groups using sealed envelopes and an independent nurse delivered the treatment according to the protocol. The hand stroking group (n = 10) underwent nonverbal behavior management during infiltration anesthesia. The audio‐visual aid group (n = 10) listened to a nursery rhyme through headphones. The control group (n = 10) had no behavioral management program. The behavior of the children was assessed by the Frankl behavior rating scale.RESULTS: This study detected a statistically significant intergroup difference regarding behavior (P < .001). The least amount of behavioral upset occurred in the hand stroking group (mean = 1.00; SD = 0.55); the greatest was found in the control group (mean = 2.20; SD = 0.65) and was statistically significant (P = .000). There was also a statistically significant intragroup difference regarding behavior; the least amount of behavioral upset was found in the hand stroking group (mean = 1.80; SD = 1.17) and the greatest was found in the control group (mean = 2.20; SD = 1.03) (P < .001).CONCLUSION: This study has shown that children receiving nonverbal behavior management (the hand stroking group) demonstrated high acceptance of the infiltration anesthesia technique. This technique was found to be a noninvasive and easily applicable behavior management intervention. This method could be a useful management strategy

Background
-----------------
Tumor microenvironment (TME) plays an important role in tumor occurrence and development. Myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) are a heterogeneous population of myeloid cells that suppress T cell-mediated immune responses. They have been found to be increased in tumor tissues or peripheral blood in patients with cancer, and their overabundance is associated with cancer progression and poor prognosis in patients with various malignancies . TME has been considered to be an important aspect and target for the treatment of cancer. To date, various therapeutic agents have been assessed and approved to improve prognosis of cancer patients. However, despite remarkable advances in therapy, the vast majority of patients experience recurrence after primary therapy, underscoring the urgent need for new targets and molecules to improve survival outcome and quality of life in these patients. CXCL12/13 are chemotactic cytokines of the C-X-C chemokine family that have been implicated in myeloid cells recruitment and TME formation. Blockade of the CXCL12-CXCR4 interaction using AMD3100 has been reported to enhance tumor antitumor immunity by reducing immunosuppressive regulatory T cells and MDSCs in the TME . Furthermore, other studies showed that AMD3100 alone induced significant reduction and reversal of immunosuppression in patients with breast cancer , advanced ovarian cancer , and non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) , and combination therapy with chemotherapy has shown anti-tumor activity in an advanced ovarian cancer and NSCLC clinical trial . In addition, MDSCs are a major component of the TME in patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) . Our previous study showed that AMD3100 could significantly reduce the MDSC counts in the blood of patients with advanced solid tumors who were not candidates for systemic chemotherapy . However, none of the previous studies conducted on AMD3100 in advanced solid tumors investigated changes in CXCL12, which plays a vital role in modulating the TME . However, it is still unclear if shorter cycles (SC) with higher ventilation have the same effects. Moreover, both conditions increase the patient/ventilator asynchrony, and it is not known what to expect during these ventilator settings.OBJECTIVES: The goal of this randomised parallel design study is to investigate the effects of PEC and SC, delivered in combination with pressure support (PS) ventilation, on inspiratory effort and airway resistance.METHODS: This study will recruit 70 patients receiving invasive PS ventilation. Patients will receive 4 randomised breathing patterns: 15% PEC, 25% PEC, 15% SC and 25% SC for a maximum of 5 minutes. The primary outcome is a non‐parametric Kruskal‐Wallis test with a pairwise Dunn's test with Bonferroni adjustment (adjusted alpha ≤0.0084) to assess the difference between the 4 conditions. Study design
=================
Prospective, non-randomized, comparative cohort study

Description
=================
Introduction
The management of enteral nutrition and feeding in critically ill patients requires careful attention. Gastric residual volume (GRV) is a commonly used marker to assess gastrointestinal tolerance and the risk of aspiration pneumonia. High levels of GRV may indicate poor feeding tolerance and require feeding suspension or modification. However, GRV is subject to variability and a previous study has shown that feeding suspension based on high GRV values may be unnecessary and result in undernourishment and worse outcome (1). Therefore, it is important to establish an appropriate and evidence-based range of values to guide clinical decision-making. 
The standard gastric residual volume (GRV) threshold for holding or modifying feeding is 200 ml. However, a recent randomized clinical trial found that using a higher GRV threshold (300 ml) for holding enteral feeding could improve nutritional intake without increasing the incidence of aspiration pneumonia or other complications (2). Therefore, we propose to explore the effects of higher GRV thresholds on nutritional outcome in our population. 
Objectives
The study aim is to assess the effect of different GRV thresholds on the nutritional intake and nutritional status of critically ill patients. The study includes a clinical research assessment with a blinded outcome assessment to prevent possible bias. 
Endpoints
Our primary endpoint will be the mean gastric residual volume per shift in ml for the first 48 hours, measured by abdominal radiography. 
Study population
All patients admitted to our Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) will be screened for inclusion in the study. Patients will be included if they meet the following criteria: 
• Adult patients admitted to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) 
• Require enteral nutrition within 24 hours of admission 
• Anticipated

Control group: The control group will follow the current standard and hold enteral feeding at 200 mL gastric residual volume.

Experimental group: The experimental group will hold enteral feeding at 300 mL gastric residual volume. 

Both groups will receive standard nutritional support, but the gastric residual volume criteria for holding enteral feeding will differ.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Sodium channel blockade may be useful in suppressing seizures during the anesthetic period in children. Sodium bicarbonate infusion in conjunction with anesthetic agents will be used in 12 children during cardiac surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Sodium channel blockade is widely used in anesthetic procedures to slow the heart rate and reduce blood pressure. It has also been shown to suppress seizures associated with anesthesia use in some cases. However, its effectiveness in suppressing seizures during cardiac surgery is unknown. Sodium bicarbonate infusion can be used in conjunction with anesthetic agents and may potentially suppress seizures during the anesthetic period. In this study, the investigators plan to infuse sodium bicarbonate in 12 participants undergoing cardiac surgery in order to assess the efficacy of sodium bicarbonate in suppressing seizures during the anesthetic period. The investigators hope through this study, to provide valuable information about the efficacy of sodium bicarbonate in suppressing seizures and improving the prognosis of seizure patients

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary aim of this study is the reduction of cancer recurrences and mortality of patients treated by laparoscopic radical resection or cystectomy with or without urethrectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy for muscle invasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy, and maintenance therapy with atezolizumab. Secondary objectives are to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the maintenance therapy with atezolizumab, as well as the quality of life (QOL).

Detailed Description
-----------------
At least 600 patients are planned for randomization in the clinical trial. The randomization takes place 1:1:1 among the study arms. The randomization is stratified by gender and type of neoadjuvant chemotherapy (i.e. platin + Gemcitabine or Cisplatin + Methotrexate + Vinblastine). The study arms consist of: laparoscopic surgery with standard chemotherapy and maintenance therapy arm: laparoscopic radical cystectomy with lymphatic drainage. In combination with cisplatin-based neoadjuvant chemotherapy and atezolizumab maintenance therapy; laparoscopic radical cystectomy with lymphatic drainage. In combination with cisplatinbased neoadjuvant chemotherapy and placebo maintenance therapy; laparoscopic radical cystectomy with lymphatic drainage. In combination with platin + Gemcitabine neoadjuvant chemotherapy and maintenance therapy arm: laparoscopic radical cystectomy with lymphatic drainage. In combination with platin + Gemcitabine neoadjuvant chemotherapy and atezolizumab maintenance therapy.

During surgery, polypropylene‐coated mesh, Mersilene mesh, and Marlex mesh were placed using the tension‐free vaginal tape procedure under direct vision. Symptoms, surgical complications, and adverse events were evaluated during predefined visits at 3, 6, and 12 months after surgery.RESULTS: The mean follow‐up was 12.4 months. Of the 66 patients enrolled, only 22 (33%) were lost to follow‐up at the primary outcome measurement (12 months). There were no differences among the 3 groups in the mean baseline symptom scores (P = .228). After 12 months, the rate of subjective cure was higher in both polypropylene mesh groups than in the Marlex mesh group: Prelastic mesh, 11 (79%) of 14; Mersilene mesh, 11 (100%) of 11; and Marlex mesh, 3 (50%) of 6 (P = .144 and P = .045, respectively). Brief summary
=================
This is an observational study to validate the utility of a new clinical scoring system to predict the risk of developing Microscopic Colitis in patients with chronic watery diarrhea. Chronic watery diarrhea is a common clinical presentation that often remains undiagnosed due to the lack of specific diagnostic tests. Microscopic Colitis is one of the potential causes of chronic watery diarrhea, but it can be a challenging condition to diagnose. Clinical diagnostic criteria for Microscopic Colitis have been developed based on a subset of features, such as the presence of symptoms, endoscopic findings, and histological features. However, these criteria are not always accurate, and they cannot be used to predict the risk of Microscopic Colitis in patients with chronic watery diarrhea. To address this unmet need, we have developed a novel clinical scoring system that combines several clinical and laboratory features to predict the risk of Microscopic Colitis. This scoring system has been designed to help clinicians stratify patients with chronic watery diarrhea into high-risk and low-risk groups for Microscopic Colitis. In this observational study, we will evaluate the performance of the scoring system in a real-world setting. We will recruit patients with chronic watery diarrhea and clinical suspicion of Microscopic Colitis who meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria and obtain informed consent. The study will involve a single-arm, observational design. Enrolled patients will be evaluated clinically and endoscopically according to established criteria. A bi

Abstract:
Soliris, developed by Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. in Boston, Massachusetts, USA is a drug used as a treatment option for patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (gMG). It has been known to be a successful treatment for gMG in adults and children by stabilizing its symptoms and reducing relapse rates. Recently, solira has also become a standard treatment option for gMG children without contraindications. Given its efficacy, soliris is listed on the Health Insurance Review and Assessment Service (HIRA) drug list that approves coverage for patients who meet the criteria, including gMG children. This study aimed to investigate the sociodemographic characteristics, clinical characteristics, treatment experience, and cost of treatment for gMG children based on data from the National Registry. As of March 15, 2018, of 154 children that have been diagnosed and treated with soliris so far, 42 (27.2%) were boys, 112 (72.8%) were girls, 107 (69.6%) were under 10 years old, 77 (50.0%) came from lower‐to‐middle‐income families, and 142 (92.2%) received private treatment in the hospital. The average total cost of soliris treatment per patient was estimated at around USD15,000 per month, regardless of the type of health insurance coverage, and 49 (32.0%) of the children had no disease activity at baseline. The result of multivariate analysis showed that treatment costs for children with disease activity (β = 97.9, p = .001) and private health insurance coverage (β = 6.96, p = .001) were significantly higher than those of children without disease activity or public health insurance coverage, respectively. Our study showed an increase in treatment costs in children with gMG before and after the introduction of soliris. This was not only due to the increase in the treatment fee of soliris itself, but also the increase in the treatment fee because the patient had a longer stay, longer dose, and prolonged administration after infusion. Abstract:
Background: The prevalence of diabetes mellitus in people living with HIV (PLHIV) aged 18 years and over is estimated to be up to 16 times higher than in the general population. HIV and diabetes mellitus share common risk factors and complications, and PLHIV are also subjected to some of the additional challenges of living with HIV/AIDS, such as antiretroviral (ARV) medications and substance abuse. This may worsen insulin resistance, which may lead to diabetic complications. Despite the increasing prevalence of diabetes, diabetes mellitus remains uncommon in PLHIV in Uganda with only 7% reported. This is due to the fact that PLHIV patients are not screened for diabetes mellitus. Also, PLHIV with asymptomatic diabetes mellitus have no access to care, treatment and support services which could improve their diabetes mellitus condition hence decrease the risk of related complications. Diabetes mellitus prevention and management services are not offered in most HIV care and treatment centers in Uganda. Aim: To develop a strategy to provide diabetes mellitus prevention and management services to PLHIV. Methods: Study design:This will be a nested prospective cohort study. Study setting: The study will be conducted at three health facilities: the Uganda Virus Research Institute, Jinja Regional Referral Hospital and Jinja Regional Referral Hospital Health Centre (III). Eligibility criteria: All PLHIV aged 18 years and above attending the care and treatment clinic of the study sites. Data collection methods: Plasma glucose testing will be performed and the information from HIV clinic records/ registers will be used to collect the participants' demographic details, and HIV related information (age of HIV infection, ARV regimen, CD4 count, Viral load and HIV risk factors). Study outcome: The primary outcome will be incident diabetes mellitus diagnosed using the American Diabetes Association (ADA) criteria for HbA1c between 5.7% and 6.4% [39‐46 mmol/mol] or use of antidiabetic medications. Primary outcome

Mortality rate is the primary outcome and will be measured by the number of deaths up to 30 days after surgery.

=================
Complications, time until return of gastrointestinal function, length of hospital stay, cost, quality of life. Cost of surgery was estimated by analyzing expenses related to the patient's stay in the hospital. Quality of life was measured by EORTC QLQ-C30.

PURPOSE: To assess the efficacy of an intervention designed to improve the accuracy of pediatric emergency physician impressions about the probability of clinically significant injury and the need for further evaluation for children who present with minor limb injuries. The aim of this study is to determine if the intervention will improve emergency physician diagnostic ability and appropriateness of referral decisions for this patient population. This will be a feasibility and pilot study, to help determine the feasibility of conducting a large trial. METHODS/DESIGN: Eligible participants in a pediatric emergency department who present with an isolated limb injury will be eligible for study participation. At each assessment point, study participants will complete two separate questionnaires: 1) the first questionnaire will collect demographic and presentation data; 2) the second questionnaire is an outcome assessor-independent questionnaire to assess self-perceptions of child injury and need for orthopaedic follow-up. Immediately after obtaining study consent and prior to the treating physician examining the child, study participants will watch a brief educational video. This video will present one of the 4 possible case scenarios with 8 levels of injury, and will serve as a teaching tool that will act as a control or intervention for this study. Once the video has been shown, the study nurse will proceed as per regular hospital protocol to obtain the patient's baseline vital signs. The treating physician will then examine the injured child as per usual practice. The treating physician will provide a treatment plan and will subsequently complete a treatment plan questionnaire. Participating physicians will then be given the opportunity to watch the educational video. After viewing the video, a questionnaire will be administered to the physician for assessment of physician impressions of child injury and need for orthopaedic follow-up. The treating physician will then repeat the diagnostic and care plan questionnaires. An interim assessment will be conducted using a short, post-exam questionnaire to assess the treating physician's opinion of the case scenario's severity. This questionnaire will be administered prior to the physician performing the diagnostic assessment. A follow-up visit with the orthopedic surgeon will occur within seven days to perform objective medical testing and finalize the diagnosis using plain films and other imag

Primary outcome measure

The primary outcome is the comparison of smoking cessation behavior, decisional balance, and self-efficacy before and after the intervention. We will measure these outcomes using a validated questionnaire before the intervention (baseline) and after the intervention (4th week). The questionnaire measures the number of cigarettes smoked per day, the degree of decisional balance regarding smoking cessation, and the degree of self-efficacy in quitting smoking. 

Secondary outcome measures
=================
We will also measure the degree of satisfaction with the health education and counseling intervention. We will ask participants to complete a self-report questionnaire after the intervention to assess their satisfaction with the intervention. This will provide us with valuable information on the efficacy of the intervention from the patient's perspective.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Smoking is a leading risk factor for coronary heart disease, accounting for about 40% of deaths from coronary heart disease in China. Smoking cessation is a critical factor in reducing these deaths, but many smokers find it difficult to quit smoking. Health education and counseling interventions can help improve patients' knowledge and skills for smoking cessation, but there are few studies on the effect of health education and counseling interventions on patients with coronary heart disease. In this interventional trial, we aim to determine the effect of interdisciplinary health education and counseling intervention on smoking cessation behavior, smoking decisional balance, and self-efficacy among patients with coronary heart disease. Methods/design
-----------------
This is an interventional trial taking place at the Guangzhou Women and Children's Medical Center in China. We plan to enroll 200 participants, aged 18–80 years, with a diagnosis of coronary heart disease, who are habitual smokers. The intervention group will receive standard nursing care in the first and fourth weeks, and health education and counseling in the second and third weeks. The control group will receive standard nursing care throughout the study period. The primary outcome is the comparison of smoking cessation

Single-center, randomized controlled trial with two arms - one which will receive routine care and one that receives routine care, self-control diary, telephone consultation and cognitive behavioral therapy.
The randomization procedure will be carried out with pre-coded cards and balanced by a random number generator. Allocation to the groups will be carried out in advance according to the stratification of age and sex. We will register the date, time, number of cards and the result of the randomization. Randomization will be performed by an independent researcher outside the team performing the study. The researcher will perform the entire procedure for randomization with the help of an assistant and the entire process of opening and assigning cards will be observed by the other members of the team.

Intervention
=================
Cognitive-behavioral therapy


Intervention description
=================
The intervention is performed in three stages: an educational-diagnostic step and two intervention steps. The first step is carried out over two sessions (sessions 1 and 2, about an hour each), the second (sessions 3 to 7, two sessions per week in weeks 1 to 4, with 1 session in the fifth week) and the third (sessions 8 to 12 - sessions 1 to 3 in weeks 5 and 6; sessions 4 and 5 in the seventh week and session 6 in the eighth week).The content of the educational-theoretical class starts with the following information: disease of the lungs and its effects on the respiratory system and on other organs; smoking effects on the individual, the social and familiar environment, and the economic impact of smoking; the effects on pregnancy and the fetus; the benefits of smoking cessation.
The second step involves two phases: the first aims to encourage the person to commit to quitting, develop a smoking treatment plan, and encourage them to adopt a healthier lifestyle. The second is aimed at maintaining smoking abstinence. Thus, in phase 1, during the sessions, the patient will discuss their level of commitment to quitting, the benefits of smoking cessation and the use of treatment, and the possibility of relapsing into smoking again will be discussed. In the second phase

Which doses of chemotherapy are being used in this trial, and why have they chosen these specific doses?
Dacarbazine is already approved for the treatment of metastatic uveal melanoma, so it is an established therapy in this patient population. Additionally, we chose tislelizumab and nivolumab as chemotherapy agents because they have demonstrated efficacy in other cancer types and have been shown to have synergistic effects when combined with anti-VEGF therapies (such as bevacizumab) in preclinical models. 


What is the duration of the study?
Subjects will be followed for a duration of approximately 3 years. This will include a screening period of up to 4 weeks, a treatment period of 24 months, and a follow-up period of 24 months. 


What is the primary objective of this study?

The primary endpoint of the study is Progression-Free Survival (PFS), defined as the time from the start of treatment to disease progression or death from any cause. The secondary endpoints of the study include Overall Survival (OS), Time to Tumor Progression (TTP), Objective Response Rate (ORR), and the safety and tolerability of the combination of cemiplimab and ziv-aflibercept.

It was designed to mimic what happens in clinical practice, where patients may switch to combination therapy after progressing on monotherapy. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The study is expected to explore the effectiveness of E-PIPO in improving sleep quality among obese individuals, as well as its influence on sleep quality and body weight. The primary research objective is to determine the effect of E-PIPO on sleep quality among obese people. The secondary objective is to explore its effect on improving sleep quality and body weight.

Detailed Description
-----------------
E-PIPO is a home-based, guided, behavior modification program integrated with the Internet platform and mobile phone application features. The intervention comprises of two parts: a home-based exercise for self-exercise and monitoring and self-care modules for weight control and behavior modification. The exercise program was developed by a team of exercise experts from the Chinese University of Hong Kong and was delivered by a video clip embedded in the mobile phone app. The self-care modules included two dimensions: weight reduction and lifestyle intervention. Based on the weight management program of the Department of Health, the participants of E-PIPO were guided through the intervention process through the app to set action plans and record weight reduction plans; and participants were given a healthy lifestyle booklet.
